name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 3 May 2018.

name: Le Président. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, it is with great emotion that, on behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to express an affectionate thought today to Nicole Fontaine, who left us a few days ago, after a long political life devoted to society and fighting for the ideals which were his own. A memory full of gratitude and gratitude. First elected in 1984, she was an eminent member of our Assembly for twenty-three years, with a two-year break during which she served as a minister in France. During these many years, it has gained deep knowledge of Parliament and the political and institutional environment of the Union and has worked tirelessly to strengthen our institution. As Vice-President for Conciliation, she worked passionately to consolidate the codecision procedure and strengthen the role of Parliament. We owe him a lot. On 20 July 1999, twenty years after another woman, Simone Veil, she was elected President of our Assembly. “In varietate concordia”, United in diversity. This motto, which was his and became ours, was adopted eighteen years ago during his presidency. I refer to this page of our history because beyond the symbol, there is the strength of a commitment. This motto expresses all thought and represents the guiding thread of its political action. Of course, we are different, but our diversity enriches us. They are only the declination of a common European culture, three thousand years old. Yes, sometimes we have different interests, but we share the same fundamental values: united, we could defend them and make them thrive on the world stage. That was Nicole Fontaine's state of mind when she signed, on behalf of Parliament, the Charter of Fundamental Rights eighteen years ago. It was convinced that it is up to our Assembly to carry our values all over the world, especially in areas where democracy is flouted or struggling to assert itself. From this perspective, she had a special look at Africa. We are the only region in the world where the death penalty is no longer applied. It is to us that the world turns when journalists are imprisoned, when women are subjected to violence and their rights violated, when political opponents are threatened or deprived of their liberty. We have an obligation to remain a benchmark, a beacon for fundamental rights. That was Nicole Fontaine's conviction. During his election as President of this House in 1999, Nicole Fontaine also affirmed the need for greater proximity to European citizens. I want to pay tribute to his incessant work, which is expressed both in his numerous works and by his regular and intense presence on the ground, as close as possible to the citizens. During her presidency, she will go to all walks of life to give more than 100 lectures and interventions. This presence, this proximity to the people, which were vital to Nicole Fontaine, was accompanied by an extraordinary ability to listen and persuade that was decisive in many respects, especially at the historic time of the adoption of the single currency, when the euro aroused very strong apprehensions among Europeans. I would also like to recall the Fontaine report, with which it was decided to grant financial aid for twinning between European cities. A small concrete gesture that has helped bring millions of European citizens closer together. This imperative of proximity is, today, more essential than ever. Nicole Fontaine was a courageous and farsighted president. While the madness of the Taliban ravaged Afghanistan, it invited Commander Massoud to the European Parliament, against everyone's opinion and despite the reluctance of Western Chanceries. A year earlier, the President of the Palestinian Legislative Council and the President of the Knesset were jointly received in our Chamber. This was a great time for our House. At the Nice Summit on 7 December 2000, she succeeded in convincing Tony Blair of the need to sign the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. In her opening speech in 1999, she said: “There is an urgent need to restore meaning to the Union”. Things have hardly changed from this point of view. Now it is up to us to continue the work of our distinguished colleague who knew how to speak to people. It is up to us to awaken enthusiasm and to revive this sense of belonging to a great project that transcends us. On behalf of the European Parliament, I thank you, Madam President, dear Nicole, for what you have been, for the passion, courage and coherence that have marked your work at the service of citizens throughout your life. As you often said, to conclude a long-lasting meeting: “Everything is said. Thank you.” (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as the EPP, we are deeply saddened about the loss of Nicole Fontaine. My most sincere condolences go first of all to her family and friends. The EPP family lost one of its greatest members, and we lost also a true friend who was by our side in this House for almost 23 years. Throughout her career, Nicole Fontaine was very active in education policies. She knew that our societies need values, and she knew the key to values is education. This is a fundamental idea of Christian democracy. Nicole Fontaine was a great Christian Democrat. And Nicole Fontaine was a convinced European. She was the EPP Group’s first woman to become President of the European Parliament, and she was such a strong woman. Just recently, Nicole Fontaine called upon us to relaunch Europe. She told us to turn Europe once again into a project that the people can dream of. Let us take up this call of Nicole Fontaine in memory of a great Christian Democrat, in memory of a strong woman, and in memory of a convinced European. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, as of Friday our personal data and private lives are better protected from abuse and manipulation. This is due to the entry into force of new data protection rules promoted by the European Parliament. I would like to thank all my colleagues who have worked on this important regulation, and in particular the rapporteur Jan Philipp Albrecht, who will shortly leave us to become a minister in Germany and whom I do our best wishes. The General Data Protection Regulation is the largest reform of privacy legislation since the birth of the Internet. It is a decisive step in ensuring that citizens use the Internet with serenity in Europe, but also in the rest of the world. With this regulation, we have demonstrated that we can set global standards on privacy and the European Union is leading the world for protecting citizens. From now on the companies and online platforms to which we entrust our data will have to make their intentions known when they use it. They will have to get our explicit consent, regardless of which country they operate in. No more tacit consent, shadow zones or shortcuts that allow rules to be circumvented. These rules will help prevent the recurrence of scandals, of data from millions of users used to influence election results. For example, any form of unauthorized use of data must be notified within 72 hours. Heavy penalties are expected for those who fail to comply with the new rules, up to 4% of total annual turnover. For web giants this could amount to fines of up to billions of dollars. The European Parliament has played a central role in setting cutting-edge privacy standards, but also in calling for online flatforms to be accountable to citizens Europeans. I am delighted that the world's large digital flatforms are committed to our rules. But our task is not over, our priority is to achieve true governance of the technological revolution by introducing a proper framework of rules. We must ensure the correct functioning of the digital market with clear responsibilities for online operators. This includes, in addition to the protection of personal data, a fair tax system and the protection of copyrights and consumer rights.

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, pursuant to Rule 149a of the Rules of Procedure, I would like to propose, on behalf of the European People’s Party (EPP) Group that the vote on the report on the interpretation and implementation of the interinstitutional agreement on better law-making takes place on Wednesday instead of Tuesday. Ms Hübner, Chair of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO), as well as Richard Corbett, my co-rapporteur for this report, have indicated that they agree with this request. The report contains some paragraphs on the ongoing interinstitutional negotiations on improved practical arrangements for cooperation and information-sharing regarding the negotiation and conclusion of international agreements. Elmar Brok and Bernd Lange, who were nominated by the Conference of Presidents as Parliament negotiators, therefore made this request for a postponement, and I hope that our colleagues will agree to this request.

name: Presidente. –
text: The Greens Group requested that the debate on the Commission's statement on the duties imposed by the United States on steel and aluminium and the Union's response be concluded with a resolution which will be voted on Thursday. I give the floor to Mr Ska Keller, to submit your group's request. Please, honourable.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the reason why we would like to propose a resolution is very simple: on 1 June, there will be some sort of decision about whether tariffs will be applied to EU products, and the Commission is already in negotiation with the US side about that, but as with every trade negotiation, it is really important that Parliament takes a decision and does not just hold a debate. Debates are very important, but Parliament must also make clear what its position is on the matter: what we want the Commission to do and what we don’t want the Commission to do, or else we don’t have any voice at all as the European Parliament. Therefore, we would like to propose a resolution and we hope that we can count on your support.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our group is against this motion for a resolution for a simple reason for the effectiveness of our action. As has been mentioned, the deadline for this transitional phase of the exemption of duties by the United States to the European Union is June 1, and until then we do not know exactly what the line will be to keep. In parallel, the INTA Committee is committed to contributing to the opinion on the overall nature of trade relations between the European Union and the United States, and therefore we believe that it is more effective to make the debate tomorrow because, of course, is a theme that will touch us, and then possibly decide what position to hold in a resolution in two weeks.

text: The GUE/NGL Group for Tuesday asked to add as a third item on the agenda, in the afternoon, the Commission Council's statements on measures to implement and preserve the plan overall joint action. I give the floor to Mr Ernst to make the request.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. I think it is important that we agree on the withdrawal of the United States from the nuclear deal with Iran. If you look at this as a whole, we have to say that this exit will also promote the threat of war in this region. I believe it is important that we as Parliament reach an agreement. There is one more point to be mentioned here: that we will also see a crisis of confidence in international treaties, which we in the EU have supported — treaties from which you simply step out, as the American President does, and thus contribute to escalation and not to de-escalation. I say quite frankly: we are urging us to discuss this now because there really was hope in Iran that this agreement will also bring about changes and open up society. And the ones that are now being hit by the United States's exit from this agreement are precisely those who have set hope. We think it's important to talk now about agreoning what action we are taking to save the agreement, to do something here, and not to allow those in Iran to practically hang down — to hang again, it would not be the first time. Regardless of whether Mrs Mogherini is absolutely unable to be there now, we are asking for this debate. The debate is necessary and we will not have spoken about Iran for the last time when it comes to concrete measures. So we are really asking for it. It is important, as a Parliament, to give this signal.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, no-one challenged the importance of the nuclear deal with Iran and the historical role played by our Union, but for the effectiveness of the debate, I will invite you all to think first. Such a debate can be beneficial when having a real contribution from the Commission and the Council, with the High Representative in the Plenary. And secondly, we have already decided to have a debate on Iran in June. This is why I warmly invite you to think of the possibility of having a debate with the High Representative in June.

text: The Group of the European United Left has called for an oral question to the Council on the Treaty on the Interdiction of Arms to be added as its fifth item on Tuesday afternoon's agenda Nuclear. I give the floor to Mr João Pimenta Lopez to make the group's request, please.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Mr President, there are times of increasing international tension which make real the risks of a nuclear confrontation that would happen would have unimaginable consequences. Almost four months have elapsed since the representative of the International Campaign for the Abolition of Nuclear Weapons, ICAN, Nobel Peace Prize 2017, has been here in this plenary, alluding precisely to this discussion, calling, at the end, for the ban and elimination of nuclear weapons, words that standing applauded here throughout the Chamber. Since December, we have been proposing, by means of an oral question which, moreover, has been subscribed by several groups, that this discussion should be held, that we should hold an urgent and necessary debate on the abolition of the nuclear arsenal and the nuclear weapons ban treaty approved by the United Nations in 2017, anticipating the high-level conference that that body is preparing. This is the second time that we have put this request here and ask that the applause that has been standing here should be reflected in this necessary discussion tomorrow, Tuesday, as the fifth point, and we also ask that the vote be carried out by roll-call vote.

name: Presidente. –
text: Then I put to the roll-call votes the proposal of the Group of the European United Left to add to the now fifth item on Tuesday afternoon's agenda a question to the Council on the treaty on the interdiction of nuclear weapons. (Parliament rejects the request) On Wednesday The GUE Group asked to add as a second item on the afternoon agenda a statement from the Council and the Commission on excessive use force towards refugees and emigrants in the Mawda case. I give the floor to Mr Zimmer to make the Group's request.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. As you have just said, this is a statement by the Council and the Commission on excessive efforts against refugees and migrants, in the context of the Mafda case. To remind colleagues once again, Mafda is a two-year-old girl from the Kurdish part of Iraq who was recently shot in Belgium during a car chase. Although investigations are still ongoing, the prosecution has clarified that it is clear that the girl died through a bullet by the police and that no weapons were found in the pickup truck that was being pursued. I am, of course, aware that this is a question that needs to be resolved in Belgium. On the other hand, however, the handling of so-called “transmigrants” in particular also makes it clear that the issues go much further. For us, on the one hand, the question arises: how can a car be pursued for 70 kilometers to be shot at, even though it is clear that there are refugees in there who fear for their lives? Secondly, we are concerned with the question of how to deal with so-called 'transmigrants' in general. Ultimately, this is also a consequence of the Dublin Regulation — a majority here as Parliament we have voted in favour of reform. We need this debate once again to initiate this and to make it clear that it can have just such consequences if, in the end, clear conditions are not created here. And we point out that repressive asylum policy is strengthening gangs on smugglers benefiting from this despair, especially of course, refugees and migrants. Without legal and safe ways to apply for asylum, we will not live up to our responsibilities here in the European Parliament. We must enforce this right so that it is possible: anyone who wants to apply for asylum legally must be able to do so — they must be able to do so without running the risk of losing their lives.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the Commission decision adopted on the third mobility package (2018/2601 (RSP)).

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to address you on the first plenary since we adopted the first Mobility Package. This was the last set of proposals under the Energy Union, and I am proud that we managed to deliver on this ambitious project well ahead of the end of the mandate. This should leave us enough time to negotiate the entire Energy Union into law and leave it as a significant legacy of this mandate. Miguel and Violeta will explain the Third Mobility Package in detail, but allow me to set the tone and the context. I am sure that, whichever constituency or political party you come from, you will appreciate the main objectives: road safety, clean mobility, inclusion and boosting of our industrial competitiveness. First, on safety. The number of fatalities on EU roads has been, unfortunately, still the same for some years already. It is simply too high. 26 000 fatalities per year or 70 fatalities per day is simply too many, and we know that today we can definitely save more lives, and it is our duty to do so. That is why we propose infrastructure improvements, and we will have new advanced safety features which will become obligatory in three years. These include automatic emergency braking, lane-keeping assist and distraction recognition or technology facilitating the use of alcohol interlocks. This is also one of the reasons why we are paving the way for connected and automated driving. Of course, the advantages are numerous: serving to increase the inclusion of people who cannot drive or have no access to a car, boosting Europe’s competitive advantage and creating new, quality jobs. By 2025 we expect automated mobility to generate revenues of EUR 620 billion for the EU automotive industry and EUR 180 billion for our electronic sector. The majority of Europe’s population is in favour of trying driverless cars, but of course there are still legitimate concerns. Surely, a lot of work remains until we can rely on this technology. Significant investments will be needed to develop and deploy the key technologies and to create the necessary infrastructure support. That is why we need a joined-up EU strategy. From safety to connectivity. Let me move on to sustainability. Transport is responsible for almost a quarter of Europe’s greenhouse gas emissions, and this share is growing, as opposed to other sectors. That is why, for the first time, the EU is proposing CO2 standards for new heavy-duty vehicles. Other major economies like the US, Canada, Japan and China already have them, so it’s about time we caught up. Our proposals for 2025 and 2030 are both realistic and ambitious, and they incentivise the trade users to catch the low-hanging fruit of existing solutions, but they also leave enough time for new technologies to be developed. This brings me to the strategic action plan on batteries. I think by now we all realise that battery production is a strategic imperative, and we have to move fast in this global race. It has huge potential for investment and jobs – we are talking about EUR 250 billion per year as of 2025. With this Action Plan we put forward a robust set of measures, for example ensuring access to critical raw materials and limiting their use; stepping-up EU research and innovation to better link it with industry’s future needs; establishing robust regulatory requirements for safe and sustainable battery production to comply when placed on EU markets; developing the skills we need in Europe to deploy the next generation of high-performing, sustainable battery technology. As you might know, we are already working with Member States, the European Investment Bank (EIB) and industrial consortia to support large-scale manufacturing projects in Europe as a part of the EU battery alliance, and I would like to thank the honourable Members of this House for setting up the ‘Friends of Batteries’ group, because I am sure in the future months and years it will have a lot to discuss. To conclude, I would like to underline that this is the last time a legislative package will be proposed under the Energy Union strategy. It is clear that the Energy Union and its transition to clean energy will have a strong, long-term positive impact on all of us and on the future of our mobility. Together, with my colleagues, we are looking forward to discussing with you this package in greater detail, and I hope we can accelerate the legislative adoption of the Energy Union files. We now rely on you to make sure that you transform these proposals into binding laws.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is the first time ever a proposal has been made to set CO2 standards for heavy-duty vehicles. We need this new legislation for three key reasons. First, we need to tackle the growing emissions of this sector, which are set to increase by almost 10% by 2030. Second, we want to support transport operators and help them to reduce their fuel costs. Third, we want to keep Europe’s industrial leadership, as other key countries such as the United States, China and Japan have already regulated this sector. To address these challenges, we propose ambitious and realistic targets: a mandatory target of -15% for 2025 and an aspirational target of at least -30% for 2030 compared to 2019. The European Commission is convinced that the targets proposed strike the right balance. The 2025 target can be achieved with technologies which are already available on the market but are not yet widely deployed, even though their costs are low. Furthermore, an early review is foreseen in 2022 to set the 2030 target based on additional information on the new technologies needed to meet this target. The proposal will apply initially to the four most representative categories of vehicles, which are responsible for almost 10% of heavy-duty vehicle emissions. The review will also be the occasion to expand the scope of the proposal to all remaining categories of heavy-duty vehicles, including buses and coaches. The package also contains additional policy measures to help us meet these targets. Manufacturers will be able to put on the market more rounded and aerodynamic heavy-duty vehicles, reducing emissions and improving road safety. Tyre labelling will be improved and extended to heavy-duty vehicles generating significant annual fuel savings for consumers and transport operators. Besides the targets, the proposal includes an incentive system to speed up our transition to zero- and low-emission heavy-duty vehicles. Today around 98% of our trucks rely on diesel. There are virtually no large zero-emission trucks on European roads, and few zero-emission buses in cities. We want to support these technologies and foster innovation by proposing an incentive scheme. This system of super credits will reward those manufacturers who will invest more in innovative technologies while preserving the environmental integrity of the CO2 targets. It also includes zero-emission buses, which are needed for cleaner air in cities. In conclusion, the key benefits of these proposals are that we will fight climate change and improve air quality; transport operators, mainly small and medium-sized enterprises, will save money at the pump – this proposal will help them save EUR 25 000 in fuel costs in the first five years of the use of a new truck; we will keep and create new jobs here in Europe; we will use and import less oil, and the proposal will in total save more than 200 million tonnes of oil up to 2040; and last but not least we will set the right conditions to invest and innovate here in Europe. I look forward to continuing our fruitful cooperation with the rapporteur Mr Turmes, the shadow rapporteurs and the whole Parliament, to ensure swift progress and the adoption of this proposal before the end of the mandate of this Parliament.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am really pleased to be here with colleagues to present to you yet another set of important mobility reforms, the third and final package of its kind by the Commission. As the Vice-President already highlighted, the objective of the Third Mobility Package is to let all Europeans benefit from safer traffic, less polluting vehicles and more advanced transport technologies, while simultaneously supporting EU industrial competences and competitiveness. Concretely, the package sets out measures to support the transition to mobility that is safe, clean, connected, automated and inclusive. Let me first say a couple of words on safety. Safety is always our top priority. I am a firm believer in Vision Zero, our ambition to reduce death and serious injuries on European roads to zero by 2050. We have made some progress lately: we recorded the lowest fatality rate ever last year, roughly a 2% decrease compared to 2016. But still, last year, 25 300 Europeans lost their lives on EU roads. All these lives lost are irreplaceable. And this comes with an enormous cost to society, emotional and financial. This is why the EU needs a fresh approach, and this is what we are delivering. With the Third Mobility Package, we set out principles for a new road safety framework for the next decade based on the so-called Safe System. This idea is to build a number of protective layers that protect all road users. It takes into account all factors: infrastructure, vehicle safety and design, and people’s behaviour. In this framework, we are setting new targets on the way to Vision Zero. Between 2020 and 2030 we want to cut the number of deaths and serious injuries by half. There is an action plan in which you can see all the measures that we are planning. The first two elements that are already part of the package are legislative proposals on infrastructure and vehicles. We are proposing to make a number of new vehicle safety technologies mandatory, and the Vice—President has already mentioned many of them so I will not repeat them. This will make sure that all road users will be able to benefit from the latest developments in technology. This will bring important benefits and pave the way to automated mobility. We are also proposing to improve the rules on infrastructure safety management, not only applying these rules to the roads of the TEN-T networks, which are already by far the safest ones – only 8% of fatalities happen on the core corridors – but also extending them to other main roads where 39% of all fatalities happen. This is the largest share of all, and that is why we are introducing network-wide risk mapping which will show us which EU roads are the safest and which ones are less so. But more importantly, that will set priorities for our future investments in infrastructure. Second, let me say a couple of words on autonomous mobility. With the Third Mobility Package we are proposing a strategy to make the EU an engaging global leader in autonomous mobility systems. Autonomous mobility holds the enormous promise of making transport safer, more accessible, inclusive and sustainable, and on cooperative, connected and automated mobility the Commission sets out a clear forward-looking and ambitious European agenda based on three core pillars. First, a legal framework that creates a single market for autonomous mobility covering road safety, cyber security, access to data and data protection. Second, financial support to establish a new partnership for a sector-wide approach towards research and development. And the third pillar is an in-depth assessment of the socio-economic and ethical aspects of autonomous mobility. We are also proposing to digitalise and simplify the communication from business to administration, and from administration to administration in freight transport. The regulation on electronic freight transport information will ensure the wide use and acceptance of electronic documents and information exchange among all players involved in cargo transport operation. For example, e-consignment notes will now follow the cargo from source to final destination regardless of the transport mode used. The potential for efficiency gains in all transport modes over 2018 to 2040 are estimated at EUR 20-27 billion. The regulation on the European Maritime Single Window environment will establish harmonised reporting interfaces, procedures and data formats for ships calling at EU ports. This will cut red tape and contribute to multimodal solutions even further. Very quickly, on clean mobility, it has been really well described already by my colleague Mr Arias Cañete, but let me add that to facilitate further CO2 reductions, the Commission also proposes to allow manufacturers to bring new heavy goods vehicles earlier onto the market with more rounded and aerodynamic-effect cabs and help reach the future CO2 standards for trucks. Such cabins will also be safer, give better visibility to drivers, as well as improved comfort. We also propose improved labelling for tyres. Last but not least, investments and infrastructure. Infrastructure is a vital tool for the deployment of clean, safe, digital and connected solutions in transport systems. To make sure we deliver the core trans-European transport network on time by 2030, the package proposes a regulation on streamlining measures for advancing the implementation of the trans-European transport core network, the so-called Smart TEN-T Regulation. It aims to simplify permit granting, cross-border public procurement and other procedures, with a view to delivering better administrative efficiency. Our initiative will significantly reduce delays as permits should be granted within three years and cut the related costs. I am also pleased to announce that the Commission’s proposals in the Mobility Package are accompanied by an additional EUR 450 million of CEF funds to support safe mobility and digitalisation across transport modes. The outcome of this CEF Transport call should be announced in the first quarter of 2019. I hope for your strong support for these ambitious measures and look forward to working with you on all these proposals.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner. Ladies and gentlemen! It is rare for the Commission, in the form of speeches by three Commissioners, to promote its proposals to us. So you have addressed us, and now, please, listen to what we have to say in this room. Traditionally, Mr Wim van de Camp will take the floor on behalf of the group of the European People's Party.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (NL) Mr President, first of all I would like to offer my sincere congratulations to the three Commissioners. I know that, with three Commissioners and perhaps 20 DGs, it is very difficult to put together such a package. That is also my only criticism: I think that the package has come too late, especially if you look at this legislature. On the other hand, if we can achieve this package, European transport, as well as energy, will be cleaner, safer and better digitised, better infrastructure and more interests for European industry. Anyone who has read it knows that there is a huge package and we need to see how far we get in this period. Finishing with mobility packages 1 and 2 will be difficult, but I promise the European Commission: we will do our best.

name: Ismail Ertug
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner. First of all, on behalf of the Socialist Group, thank you for this third package. In fact, there are a lot of forward-looking topics in it. That's very gratifying. If I may briefly go through the issues: in terms of driving safety, I was particularly pleased to be able to finally improve or dissolve this blind spot when detecting pedestrians and cyclists. Every year, far too many cyclists and people die in road traffic precisely because of this lack of these technologies. With respect to the battery strategy, I believe that this is one of the best and the most far-reaching that has been presented in recent years. Thank you very much, Mr. Šefčovič, for this topic, also because you have taken into account the entire value chain from raw materials to recycling and focus on research and development. My question is: how can Parliament support you in this? Because it is still very general, and we do not yet have a specific timetable for action. Finally, on autonomous driving: Commissioner. Commissioner, too, the course has been set in the right direction. What is crucial is that we now need to present legislation in a timely manner and ensure that it works throughout the European Union and is implemented in the same way so that this is a reality for everyone in the European Union. Many thanks again to the Commission.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would also like to express my appreciation for the efforts made by the Commission because the Mobility Package is – even with some difficulties, maybe some disagreements – quite impressive, and this is something that businesses will feel, industries will feel, our citizens will feel and consumers will feel. I think that this needs to be said.  I especially appreciate that on the Third Mobility Package, we might be short on time, but still the emphasis is on safety. This is an element which is clearly new, an element where the Commission has made a real effort and which I think, in the past, has been left aside.  On emissions, I will leave the figures aside, but I do appreciate what Commissioner Cañete has said on the question of incentives. I think that without incentives, we will not manage. Another issue in this respect is that we could overemphasise just one source of energy, and that is electricity – not in the proposal, but in general. We know that we’ve got hydrogen, we’ve got a synthetic, and if we want to make a real change then we need to manage with those vehicles which are on the market, and this is not primarily about electricity.  It is complex. Let’s treat it that way. Good luck, we will work with you on that.

name: Karima Delli
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, we are presented a little late with this package, which brings together a series of measures that are a little catch-all for the road sector. You are right, we can have agreements on road safety and that will be a priority, but I would like to emphasize two main points. First on the issue of climate: the CO2 standard is too low for trucks. You say less 30% for 2030, when we all agreed at COP 21 — and you were there — on a minimum target of minus 40%. Moreover, according to the roadmap, trucks weighing less than 16 tonnes will not be affected, while the entire road sector must make efforts against global warming. Second point: Mrs Bulc, you are right on the issue of autonomous car. We can't see it arriving on our roads until there is no specific legislation. These vehicles need to be supervised from the experimentation, because they pose real questions, especially on cybersecurity, access to data and liability in the event of an accident. Their control cannot be entrusted to the current European system, very largely failing?? , who did not see the “dieselgate” coming. It is therefore under these conditions that the future of the autonomous vehicle will be able to approach the future of the autonomous vehicle, which will replace individual mobility with shared mobility.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, we approach the debate on the third and final package of mobility measures with great expectation. I am pleased that the Commission is responding to the initiative from the European Parliament and is dedicated to the safety of our citizens. In 2017 alone, over 25 thousand people died on European roads and 135 thousand suffered severe injuries. The new age provides the possibility of new security features that should be affordable and save the lives of all Europeans. And in that sense, I hope that the Commission has prepared its proposals. Europe must also prepare for the future of autonomous vehicles and become a pioneer in this field. However, from the point of view of the Czech Republic, I greatly appreciate the initiative to simplify the procedure for granting authorisations for trans-European transport network projects. Where the Commission tragically overslept, however, were CO2 standards on trucks. That the Commission is presenting them to us now is reprehensible and completely incomprehensible.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, infrastructure projects are a key instrument for development for all the Member States of the Union. I must admit that this decision by the Commission has some positive elements. There are forecasts for environmental protection, although not as much as we would like. Nor can anyone dispute the particularly positive impact that some of these projects will have, in particular, on the lagging states in the field of infrastructure. In addition, the emphasis placed on railways ensures cleaner and safer transport of goods. We recognise that safety in transport in general is extremely important. Thousands of people are killed every year on European roads, but the measures taken must have a real impact and not just be obstacles that do nothing to citizens. In addition, even greater efforts are needed to protect the environment. However, all actions must be well planned and the possible negative impact that they may have and may not harm the competitiveness of the economies of the States, as well as not to create excessive burdens on smaller or individual enterprises which have been are active in transport.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Mr President! Commissioners, I very much welcome the third part of your mobility package. He is the most important for me, without wanting to mitigate the others, because it is directly used to save human lives. The revision of the regulation on general vehicle safety is of immense importance for road safety, which has been particularly close to my heart for many years. Even 92% of all accidents are due to human misconduct. The mandatory installation of safety-relevant driver assistance systems such as the emergency braking assistant with bicycle driver and pedestrian detection on all new vehicles or the turn assist on trucks and buses is almost a necessity. We need these silent co-drivers who can not only warn us in dangerous situations, but can also intervene to prevent an accident or to minimise accidents. I want to do everything possible to ensure that we can adopt legislation by the end of this parliamentary term. We owe it to the 25 300 killed and 135 000 seriously injured who are recorded on European roads every year.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Mr President, dear Trio of Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen. I think it's great that there are three Commissioners here to present this, which shows the importance of this package, and a fourth Commissioner, Mrs Bieńkowska, has even co-published the press release. This is actually a great thing — it's pretty late, that's right — but if we make an effort, we'll still be able to get through this mobility package. You said that Europe should indeed be the world leader in automated and connected transport. We have the chance to do so, that would be good for Europe. We have already tested this on subways, platooning, for example in the truck sector. This is more environmentally friendly, it is safer — especially when it comes to the dead, for example — it is more efficient. It would also be good for people with reduced mobility. It would also be good for rural areas, which is often forgotten, but it also has a chance. It is the last mile of the supply chain, probably very much changed in the future. The real problem is that we should approach this in a technology-open way, which is also better for emissions. Only electromobility, my colleague Pavel Telička said, is not the only beatifying one. We really need to make progress with digitalisation and the Connecting Europe Facility. We need an infrastructure for alternative energy and digital things, and also a transport infrastructure. We have to work on this decisively, so we can also manage to be a leader in Europe.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first I would like to congratulate the Commissioners for achieving this great deal for delivering all parts of the Mobility Package. Let me give you three short remarks. First I would like to commend your efforts to increase the overall road safety by the initiative to include new advanced safety features into cars and trucks. Now we must make sure that they are going to be accessible to every future car owner, because safety must not become a privilege of luxury-car owners. Secondly, while I fully agree that heavy-duty vehicles’ (HDV) CO2 emissions should be decreased, I must say that, if we really want to make a change, we must not focus only on tailpipe CO2 emissions. Instead we have to use a broader well-to-wheels analysis for tackling emissions. Thirdly and finally, I do regret that your proposal for a regulation on electronic freight transport information did not come a little bit earlier, in the first mobility package, because it could have served as a solid legal base for the enforcement part of the lex specialis on posting or for the Cabotage Directive. This way we might end up creating legal discrepancies which may hamper efficient enforcement in practice.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioners, I am sure to congratulate her that, behold, we have a harmonisation between three Commissioners who were going to offer us, put the third mobility package on the table. As has resulted from what Commissioner Bulc said, surely, we want safe, clean and connected mobility, but, of course, these things are under certain conditions: first of all, the quality of infrastructure. In order to have transport security, we need an infrastructure - at European level, at national level - on which vehicles can operate. Then we need a high-performance machine-building industry that can offer new models. We need research and innovation in the machine building industry and, last but not least, for sure, we need to support the potential of SMEs to enter this industry and be able to produce at European level and, why not, to be pioneers in alternative fuel cars. Recently I participated in a test with hydrogen cars in my country, and I was able to drink the water from the outlet, clean. So here we are also able to touch this problem of clean air that we breathe!

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE).
text: Mr President! I'm afraid I see the praise a little different. The car manufacturers and their supply industry are the industrial backbone of Europe. Here we are still the main continent. More than 50% of the world's patents for autonomous driving come from Munich, Ingolstadt or Stuttgart. And at the same time, it is the only IT sector where Europe is the measure of things. We know that autonomous driving will massively change our society. And then you should think that the area is a priority. It is not really insignificant for jobs, trade, energy, environmental policy and research. However, nothing came from the Commission for a long time, and now that the hat is burning, something is quickly patched up here or there, as with platooning, or at least once a strategy is announced. Flapsig is noted that the data of the cars would also be of interest to the authorities or to third parties. Yes, of course! But it is not enough for various stakeholders to see this in the background, as the Commission announces it, and the car vendor must then simply swallow the wisdom. This is precisely the paternalism, the backroom policy that is difficult to swallow even for convinced Europeans. Better lawmaking is different, and I believe that the approach is bordering on contempt for Parliament.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D).
text: — Mr President, I have only three specific comments on this third part of the mobility package. First, meaningful electric mobility is contingent on the use of electricity from renewable sources. Electromobility, which uses electricity generated from fossil sources, only solves a local problem, at the cost of large efficiency losses caused during conversions and energy transmission. Secondly, if we want to talk about zero emissions, the entire production chain, the entire carbon footprint, including production, must be taken into account, not just the operation of the vehicle itself. Third, the wide use of renewable energy is impossible without its efficient, technically advanced storage. We need to support European innovators, reduce the leakage of new technologies to third countries and develop the entire battery production chain. In this context, I thank Vice-President Šefčovič for taking an active approach to this issue and I welcome the EU Battery Alliance initiative of the European Commission. In the European Parliament, the Friends of Batteries working group, which I initiated, will be dedicated to this particular area and I am very much looking forward to further cooperation.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D).
text: Mr President! Everyone likes to talk about climate protection. But at the same time, it is a fact that CO2 emissions in the transport sector continue to rise as more and more goods are transported by road. Talking only about climate protection will not be enough to drive climate change mitigation and reduce emissions. It's gonna take action! With the presentation of the proposal, the Commission has recognised this and finally comes into action from speaking. Strict emission requirements for heavy commercial vehicles and an industrial initiative for clean battery production in Europe are long overdue. It is high time that you no longer kneel before the interests of the car industry, which has been lying to European consumers for decades. The ecological transport transition has to come, and there is no way around this. The Commission's proposals focus on reducing greenhouse gases in the transport sector. I am positive and optimistic that we can turn the tide.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioners, this package aimed at ensuring that, in this industrial sector, which is strategic, the European Union remains on the technological frontier, is positive, responds to key issues of security, standardisation and regulation of automation and data exchange, extends the objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to trucks. They are therefore very important lines of action, but whose effectiveness depends on the success achieved in the two structuring frameworks of this package. Firstly, the Strategic Plan for batteries and, secondly, the harmonisation of procedures for authorising projects in the trans-European network. The EUR 450 million, which will be invested through the Connecting Europe Facility, will be made available for Member States to promote road safety, digitisation and multimodality, and therefore cannot be exhausted in individual projects. I hope that is the meaning of three Commissioners here. We must have joint projects to help catapult the European Union again for leadership in a key industrial and technological field, which we have already led, but in which over the last two years we have been losing leadership over the main competitors.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: — Mr President, it is very good that the Commission has now finally seized on this reduction in transport emissions, because we know that transport is the only sector where emissions have only increased, and when traffic volumes are constantly increasing, it means that what is needed now. really big reforms to the entire transport sector. This proposal, which also proposes emission standards for reels, is welcome and complements previous proposals and is certainly contributing to the innovation of the sector. We know that the automotive industry is the most significant industry in Europe and the largest research and product developer and investor in Europe. It is very important that it remains engaged in global competition because Europe can still be a pioneer of clean transport in the world. At the same time, as we develop vehicle technology, it is important to continue to promote renewable, alternative fuels. They play a very significant role, as does the whole logistical chain. In this case, both Member States and regions need support for their own innovations because these logistical challenges are very much resolved at local level.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: Mr President, decarbonisation of our economy, if we are to meet the Paris objectives, has a fundamental objective, which is to ensure that 94% of fossil fuels, which is what transport consumes, move decisively in decarbonisation. That is why the package that the Commission has just announced to us is important. This package joins the other we are working with, the winter package, and in particular the Renewable Energy Directive, which will also set a decarbonisation target for the transport sector in order to promote clean mobility and achieve greater penetration of renewables. I think that is the path on which the European Union has to continue. All Europeans must benefit from safer, cleaner traffic and more advanced technological solutions, while supporting the competitiveness of our industry, the automotive industry, as important in countries like mine, Spain.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the third mobility package contains proposals with particular interest. But they need specialisation and a specific timetable for implementation is needed. I consider the issue of road safety to be the most important issue at the moment. As has been said, 25 300 of our fellow citizens in Europe die every year as a result of road accidents. Of course, measures must be taken, particularly in the case of accidents caused by lorries. This means that measures should also be taken for third-country lorries. In particular, at the moment, lorries from Turkey are operating within the European Union and Greece, mainly in Egnatia, are running with worn tyres, with problems of mechanical condition, and their drivers are not qualified. I have also asked the Greek Government to take specific measures. Specific measures should be taken to ensure that third-country lorries actually meet safe traffic standards.

The mobility package pursues the objectives of consolidating the single market, of speeding up the privatisation process of what still remains in public control, to further undermine states' sovereign decision-making capabilities in defining their transport policies, of benefiting merger processes capital while increasing the exploitation of workers. The proposals under discussion do not promote the improvement of working or safety conditions. On the contrary, by increasing the periods of work between rest periods contribute to increased fatigue. The unlimited increase in cabotage operations feed and legitimize labour exploitation, based on low wages and very large and unregulated working hours, how often paid per kilometre and under unacceptable pressure from the operator. The main objective of this package is not to improve working and social conditions. It is to make them worse in the name of profit by providing services and cheap labour from countries like Portugal to large European companies and powers.

name: Michael Cramer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President! Transport is the only sector in which emissions have risen since 1990 — by 28%! In industry, we have managed to reduce them by 35%. So transport is eating up everything that has been achieved with billions of our taxpayers' money in the other sectors. And within transport, road transport accounts for 72%. That is why we need relocation, prevention and improvement. But we also have to see where does the electricity come from? It does not come from the socket, but we have to look at the whole cycle — production, use and recycling. That's where we have to go. And above all, we need fair competition — as has already been said — because if we practically make rail transport, which is environmentally friendly, constantly expensive and constantly cheaper road transport, which is harmful to the climate, we will not achieve our goals. We will not stop climate change without changing mobility. But we need to stop him so that our children and their children have a perspective of living on this planet.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the third package on mobility is essential to enable all citizens to benefit from the benefits of safe mobility, less polluting vehicles and advanced technological solutions. Although the number of casualties on the road has more than halved, 25 300 people lost their lives in 2017 and as many as 135 000 were seriously injured. Therefore, the importance of equipping vehicles with advanced safety devices, such as automatic emergency braking, is therefore descended. Essential are the rules on clean mobility, particularly those relating to fuel quality and the reduction of emissions from new heavy vehicles, which I believe are necessary to enable us to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement. Useful in this regard is the action plan for batteries to facilitate the spread of the electric car. In order to enable Europe to become a world leader for connected and automated mobility systems, we should be able to quickly implement an all-digital environment for exchange of information in freight transport.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: — Dear Chairman, the third mobility package offers a set of measures that will make traffic on European roads safer, cleaner and more comfortable. Joint efforts to design and implement these measures are extremely important because the movement of people and goods in Europe today is easier than ever before and has significant cross-border effects. In this context, the ruling of the German Administrative Federal Court in Leipzig in February that allowed German cities to ban the traffic of older diesels should also be observed. The ban would refer to all diesel vehicles up to the Euro6 ecological standard. If German cities really start to ban the traffic of older diesel vehicles, Croatia and other under-developed Member States can expect a significant increase in their imports from Germany due to falling prices for such vehicles. This would be contrary to the objectives of the third package and the Commission must, in cooperation with national authorities, do something so that individual members do not become a kind of warehouse for vehicles that do not meet environmental standards.

text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first I really would like to thank you for the positive reaction and what I feel was overall support. You are right, there are three of us here to demonstrate how important the mobility issues and all the packages we presented to you are for the Commission, and you are also right that it was a collective effort and the result of very good Energy Union team spirit. I would like to assure you that we are ready to use this positive spirit to work with you, day and night, and if you are talking about trilogies, you’re speaking mostly about the night sessions. But we are ready to work with you to make sure that we use every single day. We still have almost a one year ahead of us to make sure that all the proposals we put to you for the area of modernising mobility will be approved. So we can really start the next decade to be the new framework and with all the efforts which are necessary to make sure the citizens are safer, our roads are better and our industry is much more competitive. If you allow, Mr President, I know that we are running out of time, so I just wanted to save some time for my colleagues, for Miguel and Violeta, also to contribute to the debate with their responses.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all of you for your contributions in the debate on your support for the Commission proposals. Following the intervention of Ms Dalli regarding the achievement of our target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% compared with 1990 by 2030, let me start with some clarifications and explain how the transport sector will contribute. For sure, the Commission is putting forward a different set of proposals in order to achieve those targets, but in the new Effort Sharing Regulation, we set out binding national greenhouse gas emission targets for the period 2021-2030 for Member States. These targets cover all the sectors of the economy that fall outside the scope of the European Union Emissions Trading System, including road transport. No sectoral targets are set under the Effort Sharing regulation. Nevertheless, the analytical work underpinning the Effort Sharing Regulation proposals shows the cost—effectiveness of a European Union-wide emission reduction of 25% compared with 2005 for road transport by 2030. Under the baseline, emission reductions are around 70%, so there is an eight percentage point difference.  With our 2017 proposals for post-2020 emissions standards for cars and vans, this difference gets significantly smaller – it shrinks to four percentage points, and the gap could be progressively closed by one percentage point with the implementation of the proposed CO2 standards for lorries, which have to reduce their emissions by 30% compared with 2019 by 2030. The remaining gap will be addressed through other additional policies with impact on road transport greenhouse gas emissions. These concern, for example, the minimum share of renewable fuels in transport, which is proposed by the Commission in the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive as well as the proposals for the Eurovignette, Clean Vehicles and Combined Transport Directives.  With all this legislation, we will make sure that transport also contributes to achieving our 40% minimum reduced emissions target by 2030. To conclude, let me stress that the Commission has tabled ambitious and realistic proposals which we think strike the right balance between environmental, consumer and employment objectives. That is why the Commission would like to call on our colleagues later and all the stakeholders to work closely together to ensure the swift adoption and implementation of the proposal for CO2 emissions standards for lorries – so that the benefits for European Union industry, businesses and citizens can be maximised and generated as soon as possible.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for all your comments and the real support for the Mobility Package. I take on board your criticism that we might have introduced this package a little bit late into our mandate but, believe me, it was done in a very systematic and comprehensive way, so I do believe that together we can really deliver on it, with the confidence that we will also deliver on the results, and we are all really looking forward to those results.  I am very much in favour of removing silent killers from European society, and transport is contributing a few of them, so please give your full support to three very clear vision zeros. Zero fatalities on European roads, zero pollution from European transport and zero red tape in mobility solutions by 2050.  I know it’s ambitious, but it is achievable if we join our forces and we are really serious about delivering on this objective. For that reason, I’m very much looking forward to engaging immediately with you and seeing how far we can get under our mandate, and I'm sure that the Commission and the Commissioner that will come after me will be equally devoted to these goals and we will deliver on those so badly needed objectives by 2050.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: in writing. — (NL) With the third mobility package proposed by the European Commission on 17 May, we are taking an important step towards drastically reducing the number of road casualties. The main objective of this package is not to improve working and social conditions, it is to make them worse in the name of profit by providing services and cheap labour from countries like Portugal to large European companies and powers.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on: the report of Ulrikei Rodust, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for demersal stocks in the North Sea and fishing activities exploiting those stocks and repealing Council Regulation (EC) 676/2007 and Council Regulation (EC) 1342/2008 (COM (2016) 0493 - C8-0336/2016 - 2016/0238 (COD) (A8-0263/2017))

name: Ulrike Rodust
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner Vella, ladies and gentlemen. Tomorrow, Parliament will vote on the trilogue to the multiannual plan for the North Sea. We were pretty fast with four trilogues. This does not mean, however, that the negotiations were easy. We had to make some compromises and compromises on the EP position agreed last year. And yes: compromises can hurt. Nonetheless, this second multiannual plan under the Baltic Sea Management Plan is a very important step at the right time. As we all know, the North Sea stretches between Britain and mainland Europe. A multiannual plan for demersal stocks in the North Sea and for the fisheries exploiting these stocks should be automatically linked to or seen against Brexit itself and its various stages of negotiations. As rapporteur, it was important to me to lay down a management basis for the relevant Brexit negotiations. A basis that was only possible and made possible through compromises, both between the political groups here in the House and between the Council and the European Parliament. As far as relations with third countries are concerned, we have now enshrined in the plan that the objectives of the common fisheries policy should be primacy for agreements on jointly exploited stocks. This is where the stocks that are shared with Norway, but soon also those fished with the UK. What I currently know about the position of the British on their envisaged future fisheries policy, the UK would like to adhere to the MSY principle and to areas of value based on international and scientific advice. There too, discard practices should be a thing of the past. Much now depends on the development of future fisheries cooperation between the UK and the European Union. I would like to see a lasting solution for quota distribution and access rights for sustainable management. Returning to compromises, fisheries fishing for demersal fish stocks are so-called mixed fisheries in the North Sea. I have to say here that a lot of new mixed in the negotiations — I must even say: mixed up. Ultimately, as in the Baltic Sea Plan, we included the so-called MSY Fupper ceiling. For some, this is a really red cloth, a red line that has been crossed. Environmental NGOs have therefore also called for voting against this trilogue result. Two groups have tabled amendments to this effect. I shall vote against these amendments tomorrow. Yes, we had something different in the EP report in July 2017, and yes, I would be able to live better with a different result in this regard. But there are majorities, and these majorities, including the Commission and the Council, have been strong supporters of these ceilings. The risk of no North Sea management plan was very high. I could not be responsible for this to either the fish or the fishermen. In this context, the Commission and the Council have repeatedly used the argument of so-called limited species. The integration of “MSY Fupper” would be essential to cushion effects for limited types. This argument haunted my mind in committee the other day when I heard during the landing obligation and limited species workshop that limited situations have not de facto occurred yet. I also have a clear answer to the impact of various instruments from the CFP toolbox, such as selective measures, interspecies flexibility and so on. However, back to the objectives of a multiannual plan under the basic Regulation. These will be based on scientific, technical and economic advice. Neither the Council nor the Commission should accept a definition of best available scientific advice in the available part. Why was a definition so important to Parliament? Here too, as is so often the case, we are talking about quotas, in particular how they are negotiated. The incentive for the Council seems great to use the ceilings. There are three conditions for this — three conditions that we use when at all, only on the basis of the best available scientific advice. A clear reference or understanding of the expert reports to be used is also essential in view of the fact that we only envision the principle instead of defined numbers in the value ranges. The value ranges can be adjusted regularly to the best available scientific advice. In plain language, this is due to ICES opinions. We also had to reach a compromise on the by-catch, as the notorious limited situations also played a decisive role in this issue. What else is in the plan: recreational fishing. For reasons of control, the Council has long been reluctant here. The relevant section of the plan provides that, in the event of a significant impact of recreational fishing on fishing mortality, the Council may take recreational fishing into account in terms of fishing opportunities and limit its fishing opportunities. Well, there's a lot of good in the plan. Against the background of the Brexit negotiations, I consider rejecting the plan to be the absolutely wrong signal.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like first and foremost to thank the rapporteur, Ulrike Rodust, and also to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their dedicated work. The agreement that you have reached in the trilogues together with the Council is a very good result, and I would like to thank you all for working tirelessly to ensure a solid, sustainable result that works in practice. I also want to thank the rapporteur for ensuring a timely adaptation ahead of the full implementation of the landing obligation. We have used the Baltic Sea plan as the blueprint for the North Sea plan, but where improvements were necessary, the co-legislators wisely agreed to find new approaches. For example, by introducing flexibility through the concept of ranges, which allows us to quickly adapt, following the most up-to-date scientific advice to the benefit of stake-holders and also to the benefit of sustainable stocks. The North Sea plan is very important, as it provides for reaching MSY for the demersal fisheries in the sea basin, and it also paves the way for the next multiannual plans yet to come. Let me highlight that the landing obligation enters fully into force in less than one year, and we are all aware of the challenges it entails for our fishing industry. The North Sea plan contains a range of tools to help towards this transition, and I would like to call on all Member States to use the flexibilities which exist in order to ensure smooth implementation. We need to ensure that fishermen have the tools to sustain sustainable fishing practices; for example, by adapting their gears so that they can alleviate choke situations in mixed demersal fisheries in a way that is in line with the CFP objectives. It is now for the stakeholders of the North Sea to put these tools into practice and also to ensure tailor-made solutions to the specific challenges in the different fisheries of the North Sea.

name: Jens Gieseke
text: Mr President, Commissioner Vella, Mrs Rodust, shadow rapporteurs. Thank you for the good cooperation. 21 months of negotiations are behind us, and it can be said today that we have a good and balanced negotiation result. For our fishermen we have simple and unbureaucratic rules along the model of the Baltic Sea plan. According to the latest scientific findings, sustainable fishing will continue to be possible in the future. And — as Mrs Rodust has just said — this plan now provides a good basis for the further Brexit negotiations. This is very important. Unfortunately — and this has been mentioned — there is now a call from very unilaterally arguing environmental associations to vote against this plan. I consider this call to be extremely negligent. We in the EPP can agree to the outcome of the negotiations. Many compromises have been made, but as a result, we can now agree to this plan, and that is why we will agree to the plan. Thank you for the good cooperation.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to emphasise the commitment and work of the rapporteurs, particularly my colleague, Mrs Rodust, in this crucial document for implementing the Common Fisheries Policy, and also to echo the words of previous speakers and the Commissioner. I would like to emphasise the strengthening of the importance of the most up-to-date scientific information, as well as the inclusion of recreational fishing data in the scientific information to be taken into account in the scientific councils of the International Council for the Exploration of the Seas and the Scientific Technical and Economic Council for Fisheries of the European Union. European Commission. It is important that we approve the multiannual plan and put it into action, despite acknowledging that it has come out of the diminished trialogue of some provisions adopted in the European Parliament at the time it was adopted. One of the handicaps that seems to me to be somewhat problematic is that the political agreement reached has reduced the ability to keep fishing limits below FMSY benchmarks. Another is the lack of emphasis on the recovery of the springs of ancillary species, thus concentrating this concern in the target species only. But we have to counterbalance the great with the viable, with the negotiable. After several months of negotiation, turning back a plan which, being not perfect, is, however, a very, very important step forward, would be a mistake. In this context, I consider it absolutely essential that the multiannual plan should continue at this stage. It seems to me that the possible and important foundations are laid for the plan of specific measures to be presented by regional organisations, taking into account not only the sustainability of stocks, but also the protection of susceptible species and, of course, the income of fishing communities with interests in this area of fishing.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, the North Sea is one of the most complex fishing grounds in the world. We are dealing with almost 100 different species, and fleets from eight Member States. I am in favour of regionalisation in fisheries, because the various fishing areas in the European Union have different species and conditions. So you have to take these differences into account, and that is what we do in the new policy. That started with the Baltic Sea Plan: that was the basis for this North Sea plan, and that basis is good. That is why we wholeheartedly support the North Sea Plan as it stands today. We also very much appreciate Mr Rodust's attitude and work. We can do that now, because this plan continues the development of a more successful North Sea policy. After all, all the large fish stocks in that sea are up to date. There is still a concern, Mr President, and that concerns the hearing we held last week in the Committee on Fisheries. Then we saw that there are still many questions around the landing obligations. We have to solve these questions together, otherwise untenable situations may arise.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start with a thank you to Ulrike Rodust. Once again with her good cooperation we have been able to achieve something which is acceptable, if not perfect. The CFP clearly sets out that all fish stocks shall be fished at sustainable levels before 2020. The North Sea map, just like the previous one for the Baltic Sea, unfortunately includes provisions allowing for fishing efforts up to F upper, under certain conditions. So, even if we are not very satisfied with this, we will vote for this agreement. Special thanks goes to my colleagues from the Greens and the GUE: they have had the good taste to reintroduce one of my amendments. I’m sorry to say I won’t vote for it because that would lead to the agreement falling, but big thanks to you Ulrike, and we’ll try to go further in this direction.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking Ulrike Rodust for the work that she and her team have done on the North Sea management plan. It was difficult because in several cases the fishing stocks in the Commission proposal did not match the subdivision that ICES makes in its stock advisory. Our objective within the EU is for our fishing stocks to be restored and preserved above levels that ensure maximum sustainable returns. It's an excellent target for it would mean more fish-rich stocks, well above today's levels. Our oceans are the lungs of our earth and we need them to manage for future generations. More fish in the sea also leads to more profitable fishing. It will be easier to catch the fish, we spend less time and fuel and that way we make more money. We are disappointed with how the Commission formulated its question for stock estimation to the marine research council ICES. ICES advice allows us to fish more intensively than is stipulated in the basic regulation. The North Sea Plan permits it, and thus violates the basic regulation. Parliament long tried to hold against the Council of Ministers in the negotiations on this particular point, in both the Baltic Sea Plan and the North Sea Plan, but failed. The positive is that recreational fishing in the North Sea should be included and counted off against quota, as suggested by us Greens. The problem is in Article 4 (4) of the North Sea Plan, and we Greens have tabled an amendment to vote out this article. The Greens cannot support a plan that allows such intensive fishing and will therefore vote against the plan if the article is not expelled.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (NL) Mr President, the North Sea is a beautiful nature reserve. It is even the largest nature reserve in the Netherlands, with a large variety of species that deserves protection. Unfortunately, the North Sea is not protected as such, and this plan also does not give the North Sea and the animals living in it the protection they deserve. In fact, protection measures for sharks and rays have been completely removed from the original proposal and a trick will make it possible to continue overfishing even after 2020, contrary to the common fisheries policy and contrary to development goals of the United Nations. Mr President, we as a Parliament cannot accept that. In September last year, a large majority of Parliament voted in favour of stopping overfishing. The Member States refused to talk about this. Now it is Parliament's turn to stand firm. We do not give permission for overfishing. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, I told you in committee how the UK fishermen feel abused. You replied by telling me that you did not understand this. If you were being honest, that makes you particularly ill informed and unimaginative. If you are not, then it makes you a tendentious, disingenuous politician embodying everything wrong with the EU and its political class. To be frank, I think that trying to get you, Commissioner Vella, to understand how and why British fishermen feel abused is a little like trying to explain how to ride a bike to a shark. So let me be clear, or try to be clear: if you want Members to stay in a club when they feel abused, unhappy and invisible you first listen to them – especially the complaints about abuse; you have an honest discussion about change; you agree changes, which recognise their critique, especially when you know it is accurate and makes sense; and you make the improvements as quickly as you can. You do not: deny the validity of what they say; tell them they agreed to this and cannot question it; tell them that they have no justification for feeling abused; be unpleasant and nasty to them in the departure discussions from the EU, in the belief that it might cause them to change their minds or ‘pour encourager les autres’. This North Sea plan exposes this place for what it is: an abuser in denial. The fishermen of Britain will no longer be oppressed; the fishermen of Britain will not be denied. We reject the plan. We reject the Common Fisheries Policy. Now the SNP in Scotland want to hand over our fishing to the EU. Ruth Davidson’s remainer Conservatives want to hand fishing over to the EU as well. But UKIP wants our fishing grounds controlled by Britain and by nobody else. And I have a little book here I shall send up to my SNP colleague Mr Hudghton for his edification, I’m sure he’ll enjoy it.

name: President. –
text: That reminds me that some sharks have been discovered with bicycles in their bellies.

name: Sylvie Goddyn
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, shared between seven Member States and Norway, the North Sea is quite representative of European fisheries. There are many species fished. We can mention, for example, cod, black place, whiting, sole, flounder or langoustine. And it is this variety of species that makes the North Sea a mixed fishery, that is, a fishery where several species are captured at the same time. Paradoxically, this poses a challenge for fishermen, who are confronted with so-called “limiting quotas”. This technical term refers to a practical problem.
