Each time a vessel raises its fishing gear, its catch consists of a mixture of different species. In principle, fishermen must cease their season as soon as a single quota applicable to a species is exhausted, especially since the landing obligation prohibits them from rejecting any catch exceeding the quota. That is why this plan, despite its imperfections, technicality and constraints, is ultimately a lesser harm for fishermen. It limits the impact of limiting quotas by easing the management of by-catch, in particular by allowing, to some extent, discards at sea, but also by allowing the exchange of fishing opportunities between Member States and with third countries. Finally, of course, this plan is multiannual in nature, which should give fishermen more stability and visibility. It is important that the fluctuation of fishing opportunities for a particular stock is not abrupt from year to year. All these measures thus converge towards greater flexibility and visibility for the benefit of fishermen. We will therefore vote in favour of this plan.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the North Sea plan is the second in relation to multi-year plans after the Baltic, and the fundamental concern about the precedent it might entail for future Atlantic plans is that the problem of mixed fisheries is not — let alone solved — are not addressed. Fishermen in the European Union will have to deal with these complexities as a matter of priority and, fundamentally, after the landing obligation. Always taking into account the perspective of these precedents, if we consider Article 5 thereof, which states that other non-target demersal species should be managed on the basis of maximum sustainable yield, or Article 6, according to which other accompanying species shall be based on the precautionary approach, the effect achieved is that the fishery of the main species will be managed through the most limiting species, by combining insufficient TAC with the landing obligation. This is not fixed and will be aggravated. In a more positive tone, I would like to thank all those who have worked on this issue and welcome the establishment of ranges of values that are consistent with the achievement of maximum sustainable yield and, in addition, considering socio-economic aspects and achieving sustainable levels of all populations covered by the plan.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, four decades of the CFP have been marked by failure, and the impact of that failure on attitudes towards the EU in our fishing communities should not be underestimated. Ironically, just as the CFP is moving, albeit slowly, towards a more regionalised and decentralised model, the UK is leaving the EU. Nonetheless, the provisional agreement on the North Sea does offer a potential improvement in the management of the EU’s North Sea fisheries. But this multiannual plan will inevitably become less important when the UK leaves the EU and when the majority of North Sea stocks become shared stocks within the terms of international law. It is therefore imperative that meaningful progress is made in planning for post-Brexit fisheries management and therefore that the UK Government makes up its mind what its attitude will be in such negotiations. But ultimately, in my view, my hope is that Scotland will choose to become a normal independent nation again, able to set and pursue our own priorities and negotiations with our neighbours. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Ian, for taking my question. We may be opponents but we always get on fairly well. But, Ian, how can you call yourself a Scottish Nationalist when you want to hand over our fishing grounds to the European Union? Surely what you really are is a Euro Nationalist, not a Scottish Nationalist? Please enlighten me. (Interjection by the President: ‘If it’s possible’)

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – It may be useful to put some facts on record, and not for the first time. Some 20 years ago my predecessor as SNP MEP for the North East of Scotland, Allan Macartney, led in our Fisheries Committee a report calling for zonal management of fisheries. At that time the Commission and the Council, including the UK Government, failed to embrace the idea. Again, a little over 10 years ago at the previous CFP reform I voted against Parliament’s position at that time, because it did not go far enough in calling for decentralised management of fisheries and therefore more input for Scotland. Again that was not embraced by the Council, including the UK Government. One of the principal reasons that the CFP has been a failure for Scotland and indeed for many other areas is because successive UK governments have helped to construct it that way.

name: Mireille D’Ornano (EFDD).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, since the management of fish stocks is an exclusive competence of the European Union, the legislative acts adopted must be the most scientifically relevant. I therefore agree with the desire to define the concept of “best available scientific advice”, linking it to the scientific advice reviewed by the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea, which is responsible for this matter. I also support the idea of concerted stock management with third countries, such as Norway or the United Kingdom, which will soon leave the European Union. In fact, the management of demersal stocks in the North Sea concerns only a minority of Member States and, at the same time, requires joint management beyond the European Union alone. Thus, the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources is evidence that concrete action between States is evident and that the European Union is therefore not the alpha and omega of cooperation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the multiannual plan for the management of fish stocks in the North Sea is an important initiative because, of course, it concerns eight states, which are not all Member States of the European Union. Secondly, it is also based on the experience we have had with the Baltic Sea plan. There are technical problems which need to be resolved, such as mixed catches and restrictions on landings, because a distinction should be made between basic catches and by-catches. From then on, I believe there are political problems which will arise mainly after Brexit, as it is assumed that a solution will have to be found on how to manage fish stocks. We must not forget that even before the United Kingdom acceding to the then EEC, we had a number of problems and conflicts between, in particular, the United Kingdom and France.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, multiannual plans are instruments for fisheries management with indisputable virtues, capable of providing some temporal stability to fishing activity, by nature marked by instability, which the mere adoption of the taxi quota system alone does not guarantee, but the approval of more This multiannual plan makes it inevitable that, once again, the limits imposed by an institutional framework which wrongly defines the management of marine living resources as an exclusive competence of the European Union. This has essentially led to the persistence of a centralised fisheries management system, which is inappropriate in the interests of local fisheries, particularly small-scale fisheries, which favours industrial fisheries, together with a definition that is not always solidly sustained from a scientific point of view of management goals. The so-called objectives of regionalisation or even decentralisation of the common fisheries policy have resulted in a handful of nothing, a reality inseparable from the deepening of the economic and social suffocation of fisheries and coastal communities.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for your interventions and also for your valuable views. I have taken due note of this very interesting debate and also of your general overall support. Let me reiterate: it is of utmost importance that the multiannual plans are made fit for purpose. To ensure this, they must focus on the tools to ensure a practical and sustainable management framework which also allows for flexibilities for our mixed demersal fisheries. The co-legislators have achieved this with the North Sea plan, and I didn’t see any major substantial divergences. So finally, let me express also my hope that the European Parliament would also work – and we are prepared to continue working with the European Parliament – on the other multiannual plans as well. Multiannual plans that we have proposed so that they can be adopted and also so that stakeholders can make full use of these plans as well as to agree on tailor-made decisions, for example for the multiannual plan for the Western waters. Again, my thanks to the rapporteur, Ulrike Rodust, and also to the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 29 May 2018.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on the reports: — the report of Clara Eugenia Aguilera García, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on optimisation of the value chain in the EU fisheries sector (2017/2119 (INI)) (A8-0163/2018), — Linnéai Engström report, on behalf of Committee on Fisheries on the implementation of control measures to establish compliance of fishery products with the criteria for access to the EU market (2017/2129 (INI)) (A8-0156/2018).

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Union's fisheries sector is facing increasingly difficult and complex challenges, such as the state of resources, increased expenditure, downward variations in fishing quotas and competition from imports of products from third countries. All this conditions the income of our fishermen and causes fishing communities to face difficult situations. This report analyses the key points for optimizing the value chain of fishery products in the European Union, that is, to identify what can be improved so that local processors and fishermen retain most of the value generated. Among the proposals, some of them should be noted. The important role played by producer organisations in this sector should therefore be noted. It is necessary to facilitate the creation of producer organisations, eliminate bureaucratic barriers and provide them with greater empowerment, facilitating access to financial aid. An essential element is that the value chain be included within the production and marketing plans of producer organisations, with the aim of adapting supply to demand, ensuring equitable income for fishermen and that European consumers find products that meet their needs. Another key issue is that the labelling system be reviewed in an aspect that I will mention to you. For example, the FAO zoning that is included in that labeling. This zoning was created over seventy years ago with the aim of reporting catches, but it is not intended or designed to guide the consumer. Therefore, it does not point and abounds in the information. On the other hand, there is a need to establish mechanisms to improve the sales price, in order to benefit fishermen, increase remuneration for their work, and promote fair and adequate distribution of value added throughout the sector's value chain. The Union's fisheries sector needs inter-branch organisations, which is an essential instrument for strengthening producer organisations and providing them with greater bargaining power. Another claim we want to make from this Parliament, and which Parliament has always been making, is that, as envisaged in Community legislation, real preferential access to fishing opportunities for small-scale and artisanal vessels in the European Union is being given real preferential access to fishing opportunities for small-scale and artisanal vessels in the European Union, something that the Member States do not do. A scourge that fisheries professionals today have, and especially important for young people, is that they currently do not have access to training programmes, and therefore the needs of the sector cannot be met. We also call for the inclusion of the gender approach across all Union policies, and in this case, specifically in the common fisheries policy. It is essential that the important role of women in the Union's fisheries sector be visualized and their position strengthened in this way. In addition, there is a need to improve and coordinate, at EU level, the fight against unfair trade practices. I take this opportunity to denounce, also from here, the cut in funds for the new financial framework that this sector is going to suffer in the Union. This is a very small fund — for which a cut of EUR 260 million is envisaged in the proposal for the financial framework — and which I hope Commissioner Vella will defend before the rest of the College of Commissioners. Finally, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and all those who have worked to achieve a good end result, which I hope will be approved by the majority.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner! Fish is one of the most widely traded raw materials globally, and the EU represents the largest and most lucrative fish market in the world. In 2016 we imported 8.8 million tonnes of fish and aquaculture products, comparing with EU production of 6.2 million tonnes. Our dependence on imports is high as 60% of the fish we eat are fished outside Union waters. The EU's great need for fish and aquaculture products has a clear impact on trade policy within the EU. EU fishing fleets are governed by a complex regulatory framework; the common fisheries policy with the related control regulation. In addition, EU vessels must also respect a range of other regulations such as labour standards, training requirements, ship safety, environmental legislation, taxation rules and sanitary requirements. All this is so that we as consumers can feel confident about the quality of seafood, but also that fish have been caught in a way that respects our labour laws, environmental standards and other rules that are standard within the EU. But in the fish counter, there are also products that have a different origin, the imported products. It applies to both fresh and frozen fish but also processed products such as fish sticks, fish grains or imported seafood and squid. For several of these products, the requirements for production are lower, allowing them to compete with a lower price than fish caught within the EU can. We create a market imbalance that in many cases disadvantages EU-caught fish, which is drawn with higher costs to meet all requirements and standards. Much of the fish imported comes from countries that fish responsibly, but still the industry is drawn with major problems with illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, and in some cases it involves products based on pure slave activities in the fishing industry. In the light of the fact that more than 30% of the world's fish stocks are overfished and almost 60% are fished on the verge of what is sustainable, it is reasonable that we review the requirements we must impose on the fish that will access the EU market through imports. This report has made a review of the requirements imposed on imports today and comes up with proposals to fill the gap in the regulatory framework we have drawn attention to. I would like to be sure to thank all colleagues who have taken part and tabled amendments to improve the report. The requirements imposed by the EU on imported fish are mainly that it must be legally caught — and we are trying to ensure that through our IUU regulation — and that the fish meet sanitary requirements. As regards timber, the EU requires traceability and that operators in the sales chain should be able to ensure, as far as possible, that the product is legally harvested, known as due diligence. The same system is to be introduced for conflict metals. The Commission should examine whether fishing could also benefit from similar requirements for due diligence to discourage illegal fishing and to allow EU consumers to feel safe that the fish they buy is legally and sustainably fished. Consumer information needs to get better. Today, there are no requirements for processed, canned or processed products. For example, it should be mandatory to specify the flag state of the vessel that caught the fish. As far as labour standards are concerned, many Member States still need to do homework and urgently ensure ratification and introduce different conventions that apply to fishermen. It is important that the Commission continues to pressure other states to implement measures that prevent illegally caught fish from entering their markets. As the largest market for fish in the world, the EU can make demands, and that is how we raise standards for fish management globally. We have come up with a series of proposals and improvements in this report, but I have no time to go through all of them now. There is an incredible amount to be picked up here and I sincerely hope that the Commission uses this report and takes them further.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, in this joint debate let me follow your order. I would like first to thank MEP Aguilera Garcia, the rapporteur on optimisation of the value chain in the European Union fishing sector, and the Committee on Fisheries for their report on this very important issue. I fully concur with many of the points made in the report, and I would highlight three main areas where we have to continue working in order to deliver efficient value chains that allow fishermen to share the opportunities of our internal market. These three points are: first, strengthening the structuring of our sector; second, providing fishermen with adequate tools to operate in the market; and third, ensuring an adequate legal framework. First point: strengthening the structuring of the sector. I share your opinion that producer organisations and inter-branch organisations, by increasing the bargaining power of fishermen, can help them to take the most from the fishery value chains. I believe the common market regulation has already simplified procedures for the recognition of such organisations and reduced the administrative burden significantly. First, the minimum representativeness criteria for producer organisations are no longer set at EU level but at national level, which allows Member States to take into account local specificities. Second, the production and marketing plans as provided under the common market regulations give full flexibility to the producer organisations concerning the tools available to improve their management and marketing activities. Support to these plans is provided under the EMFF. Thirdly, we are also aware that more cross-border cooperation is needed, since we have an EU single market. Therefore we welcome the European Parliament’s request to carry out a pilot project to promote transnational cooperation among professional organisations. The second point: providing fishermen with adequate tools to operate in the market. I believe we should provide fishermen with the tools which allow them to choose what is best for them – but we should not make that choice for them by imposing measures. Production and marketing plans are the most flexible tool we can give to producer organisations to design better sales strategies that increase the profits of their members. I believe the flexibility of these plans should stay as it is, precisely given the complexity and variety of value chains across the EU. I recognise that the issue of market transparency is a critical one if we are to empower small-scale fishermen to exploit the value chains. The Commission has been producing a lot of information through its market observatory for fishery and aquaculture products. But here again, we can do more. Let me also recall that we will begin in a few days to survey EU consumer habits regarding fish products. This will allow us to detect trends in demand. And we are also planning to provide analysis on online sales strengths. Funding is also an important element. The current EMFF provides a wide array of measures to small scale fisheries to become more competitive – especially to young fishermen – and I think we should build on these positive elements. The recent proposal for the next MFF confirms this trend in terms of simplification, and I think this is a positive development for both Member States and the sector. The third point, which is the legal framework: as regards the need to ensure the adequacy of the existing legal framework, we have recently launched an evaluation of the marketing standards that apply to fishery products to see whether they can ensure fair competition in the EU market to improve the profitability of production, and whether they can deliver a level playing field with imported products. We have also started to collect evidence on the labelling of fish products and in particular on the provision of information on the origin of the fish, which is an essential element for consumers to adequately value local products. However, I do not think that the Commission should create a specific logo for small-scale fisheries. Consumer demands varies significantly across the EU, and the relevance of such logos must be measured against the market that operators target. I also do not think that we should take a more interventionist approach and impose caps on the profits that operators in the supply chain make. If these profits are the result of effective marketing activities, the operators should be rewarded for their work. If the profits derive from unfair behaviour, action is needed, and this is precisely why fishery and aquaculture products are covered by the recent Commission proposal on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. I believe the EU internal market offers great opportunities to fishermen. We all share the obligation to support our fishermen in making full use of these opportunities and to ensure that the conditions in which they operate are fair. The EU is the largest market for fisheries products in the world, absorbing a quarter of all imports, and that brings me to the report of MEP Engström. I would like to thank MEP Engström for the report, which touches upon a variety of important issues across different policies such as fisheries, trade, food safety and labour standards. The points addressed in your report are of great relevance today, as the EU depends on imports for almost 60% of the total consumed fisheries and aquaculture products. Plus there is a high number of non-EU vessels authorised to export fishery products directly to the EU. Let me briefly share with you where we already concentrate our efforts to regulate imports and to ensure that imported fish products meet high standards. The fisheries control system and our policy to fight illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing play a key role in this regard. The introduction of the current control system clearly improved the control of fisheries and compliance with the CFP, but more efforts by Member States are necessary to ensure full compliance. As you know, we are finalising the revision of the control system to improve the current rules, including in areas highlighted in this report, such as the sanctioning and enforcement system and traceability rules, as well as better use of new technologies, including for small-scale vessels. We will adopt this proposal still this week. The Commission is also working on the development of an EU-wide database for the management of IUU catch to support Member States’ risk-based controls. This should lead to a reduction in the opportunities for fraudulent imports, and it should ease the administrative burden for Member States in terms of verifications. One of the purposes of this system is to ensure that illegally-caught fish does not enter the EU market, neither at the first port of entry nor at any other port of entry subsequently. As regards marketing standards, I take note that your report calls for an improvement in the labelling of fishery and aquaculture products, including those prepared and canned products that today are excluded from the obligation of informing consumers about where they come from. On sanitary requirements, your report acknowledges that the system and the procedures for inspecting and authorising the placing of fish onto the EU market generally functions well. The EU system has indeed been very successful in granting a high level of consumer protection for almost 30 years. Only third countries demonstrating that the legislation on fishery products and their control system are equivalent to the EU are allowed to export to the EU. The EU verifies the application of the EU rules in third countries via audits that are regularly carried out in the exporting countries with respect to hygiene requirements for vessels and establishments, but also their enforcement. Controls at the EU borders are very strict for all imported commodities and especially for food of animal origin. The Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed informs all Member States and third countries as regards non-conformities found at the moment of import or on the market and allows them to take the appropriate actions. And finally, as regards labour standards, the Commission attaches high importance to the social dimension of the CFP, in particular to ensuring fair and safe working conditions in the fishing sector. The Commission welcomes the references in the report, reminding Member States of the need to ratify international conventions related to safety and working conditions and to promote ratification internationally, as well as to cooperate actively with other Commission services and with the social partners, notably in the context of the social dialogue. I have raised this very issue with Member States at the Fisheries Council in March, and I have written, together with Commissioner Bulc, to all ministers responsible for transport and for fisheries. However, so far only one Member State has actually set the ratifications as a priority for early 2019. This lack of response and of interest gives the impression that ensuring fair and safe working conditions in the fishing sector is not a priority for Member States, and this is very disappointing. I am therefore extremely grateful for the European Parliament’s support in this respect, but also for the strong support shown by stakeholders during the high-level discussions organised by the Commission at the recent Seafood Expo in Brussels where, together with key players, we managed to increase international awareness on the issue of labour standards.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, first of all, thank the rapporteur, Mrs Engström, for her efforts as rapporteur. It has already been said that the European Union is the first importer of fishery products in the world. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure that imported products effectively meet standards of sustainability, traceability and food safety equivalent to those of the European Union. This is how we protect our consumers while preventing our fleet from perceiving unequal or discriminatory treatment. That is why we need to homogenise controls throughout the European Union we will see what proposal you are making next week, Commissioner; what cannot happen is that products that are rejected at the border of one Member country are then admitted in another. In this vein of supporting our fisheries and processing industry, free trade agreements with some countries, especially Asia, have to treat our fishery products as sensitive, and not be swept away by Asian competition. The Commissioner for Trade in these negotiations must be in close contact and coordination with you, Commissioner, and I am pleased that these two aspects are reflected in the report we will be voting on Wednesday. Finally, I would like to call for support for the amendment I tabled with my group, which wants to put into value the products of the EU fleet which, as you know, meet high standards. The formula would be, Commissioner, for the Commission to consider introducing a specific label for EU products, so that consumers are better aware of the value of these products in the European Union.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, I would also like to congratulate and congratulate the two rapporteurs for these two reports. We are therefore discussing two documents in this debate on fishery products, value chain, control and access to markets. Everything that is particularly relevant in the context of the outermost regions, such as the Azores from which I come. As such, the ORs are widely considered in the wording of both reports of this Parliament. I would like to stress that it is crucial that the transport of fish from the ORs is properly supported until it enters the national and international markets, in order to ensure fair competition with other fish products, whether fresh or processed. Only in this way can market access converge and become fairer and remain cohesion in the value chain. I would stress once again the possibility of creating a financial instrument that provides specific support to the fisheries sector, for example by restoring POSEI fisheries, with the ability to effectively improve the potential of the outermost regions for sustainable commercial fisheries.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, I think it is very important that we properly regulate the access criteria for fishery products to the European Union, because the European Union has a large market when it comes to products from fishery and aquaculture production. The figures have already been pointed out: with imports of these products, we represent a quarter of the total global market and we are more than 60% dependent on the import of marine products for our consumption. That is why I also support the Engström report, because the colleague stresses that imported fishery products must meet the same requirements as products from the European Union. We need to create a level playing field, and this report is an important step towards a balance between EU producers and non-EU producers. As far as labelling is concerned, we really need to work better than that. So far, only a small group of products have been labelled, whereas we really need to inform consumers about all products in terms of fisheries and aquaculture. These include additional requirements about where the product comes from, what flag is on the catching vessel and also need to be clearly indicated on the label whether it was a European vessel or a non-European vessel. Well, we are doing it well, and that is why we support Mr Aguilera's report.

name: João Ferreira
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Mr President, the fisheries sector is of strategic importance for the public supply of fish, for the balance of the food balance of several Member States, for the development and well-being of coastal communities. The insecurity of the incomes of fishery professionals, resulting from the way in which marketing is carried out in the sector, the way prices are formed at first sale and the irregular characteristics of the activity, implies, among other things, the need to maintain adequate public funding for the national sector and community. Mechanisms are needed to improve the first sale price in order to benefit fishermen by increasing the return for their labour and to promote a fair and adequate distribution of added value across the sector's value chain, reducing intermediation margins, valuing prices paid to production and exerting a restraint of prices paid in final consumption. It is necessary to improve market stability and support the processing and development of new products and forms of marketing. These are proposals and contributions that the report has received, and we would therefore like to point out and value it here.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President! These designs are designed to the detriment of inshore fishing, micro-enterprises and recreational fisheries, in favour of industrial fishing. Industrial fishing with its large-scale fleets uses its fishing harness and trawls to stir up the seabed to a metre depth. They mercilessly destroy everything that lives and grows there. Your text, Mrs García Pérez, says literally: 'The plan helps to ensure a decent standard of living for people who depend on fisheries', but it does not mention how many livelihoods have already been destroyed. Coshore fishing and its micro-enterprises have existed for centuries and are in harmony with marine life and nature. With such a draft, fisheries, which characterise all ports and coastal regions in particular, has no future. That is why I reject this draft.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, most importantly, a good job, Madam rapporteur, on the optimisation of the value chain. I fully support reciprocity when it comes to the trade agreements. Imported goods should fully comply with the same quality standard rules as EU fishing products. Tough competition, including from abroad, is a reality of many fishery businesses around Europe. Secondly, we need to invest in young people, engage and empower the next generation of fishermen, but in order to achieve this, we need money for training and educational opportunities. At the same time, we need to conserve fisheries and support our coastal communities through research, education, outreach, as well as leadership development. Lastly, I fully agree that we should expend and promote information provided by the EU Market Observatory for Fisheries and Aquaculture products (EUMOFA). Our job here is to study different dependencies and processes and to point out how best to maximise benefits for the sector.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: — Dear Chairman, fisheries is an important economic branch for coastal and island communities. If we want to preserve them, we must ensure that the greater proportion of the value created in the fisheries sector remains precisely for fishermen and the local community. Optimization of the value chain in fisheries is an important process that can ensure sustainability and thus save many coastal communities from depopulation and dying off. It is important to reduce administrative burden and facilitate association in producer organisations and placement of fish on the market, but also in public institutions in local environments. In Croatia, all this will be greatly hampered if the Commission insists on drastic quotas for small blue fish in the Adriatic. Such a policy would endanger the entire chain because sardines and anchovies, in addition to direct processing, also go to the processing of the tuna yard. That is why I hereby urge the Commission to drop quotas and, together with Parliament and national authorities, find a better, sustainable solution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Commission, Member States and regional governments must implement measures to support small-scale fisheries which, as I know, is going through from several years a period of great difficulty, encouraging local consumption, direct marketing and zero-kilometre commercial channels, as well as promotional campaigns also carried out in cooperation with private initiatives designed to promote local food products. The establishment of producer organisations should be promoted, the only way in the world to give fishermen greater negotiating power. Mechanisms to improve the selling price, to allow adequate pay for fishermen's work, reducing margins for intermediaries and enhancing the prices paid to the manufacturer. Finally, I would like to reiterate my concern about imports of fishery products which are often subject to less controls. The European Union, even in order to promote fair and fair competition, must ensure compliance with European Union conservation rules on all imported products and management, as well as hygiene requirements provided for by legislation.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, getting fishermen to work together in producer organisations should remain one of our primary objectives. We have very positive examples from across the EU of producer organisations bringing together small-scale fishermen which have succeeded in increasing their members’ profits. These experiences can be replicated throughout the EU, and we will continue to work in this direction. Giving fishermen the tools to understand the market in which they are operating is also crucial, but value chains across the EU are so varied and complex that an optimal exploitation of the opportunities can only be made by focusing on the specific characteristics of each chain and each destination market. Funding to support small-scale fishermen is there and it allows them to promote their products and to improve their position in the value chains. Funding is extremely important to promote innovation, skills and community-led local development. In terms of value and profit for the fishermen, I would highlight one key aspect which I found could be more present in your discussions. What benefits fishermen most of all is the state of the stocks upon which their livelihood depends. In order to build healthy stocks we need to have responsible fisheries, and all segments of the fleet should contribute towards that effort. One of our key responsibilities remains to ensure that the context in which fishermen operate remains a fair and a transparent one. I have enumerated actions we have already taken or are starting at present, but we have to perform continuously. Let me highlight that with regard to the conformity of fisheries products entering the EU market, the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (IUU) remains one of our top priorities. We will continue to support third countries to take actions to prevent, deter and eliminate IUU fishing and to encourage other states to apply measures to prevent IUU-caught fishery products from entering their markets. Speaking of the coordination between trade and fisheries policy, your report suggests that the EU approach to trade is frequently perceived as being counter-productive to good fisheries governance in the EU, as it opens up the EU market to fish products from countries which do not necessarily have the same standards as the EU. The EU’s recent free trade agreements include provisions on sustainable fishing, and this in itself is already a great step forward. But we will continue to work to strengthen our trade partnerships by including legally binding provisions on sustainability. Those trade partners which are granted favourable access to the EU market and which are commercial fishing nations and interested in access to the EU market will have to be committed to the requirements of the EU’s IUU regulation. However, let me be clear that IUU and free trade agreements are two independent instruments, and that any decision within the IUU dialog will be taken regardless of the situation of trade negotiations. As regards the origin of products, we are analysing what information would help consumers most to make informed choices. We will feed this analysis into the evaluation of the common market regulation which will be part of the future evaluation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The EU market is extremely dependent on imports since our demand significantly outweighs our production. Therefore our objective will always be to strike a fine balance between the requirements we set for the importing of products and the need to ensure the availability of supplies at reasonable prices for consumers. Finally, let me welcome very much the references in the report reminding Member States of the need to ratify international conventions related, as I said in my previous speech, to safety and working conditions and also to promote ratification internationally, as well as to cooperate actively with other Commission services and with the social partners, notably in the context of the social dialogue.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García
text: rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to mention Mrs Engström's report in this last speech. I think that a great job has been done on this report. Just highlight a small mention: this report clearly aims to draw attention to the fact that in the European Union the same rules must be and must be required for all products marketed in its territory. This seems like a no-brainer, but it is a fact that is not occurring. All fishery products in the European Union should be required to meet the same level of requirements in relation to management and conservation measures, as well as hygiene standards and working conditions. This will help create a fairer market and increase rules for the exploitation of marine resources in third countries. That is why it seems to me a very good report and I will support it tomorrow in the vote. Finally, Commissioner, I would like to say that strengthening producer organisations is undoubtedly a substantial element. I would have liked him to have said that we are going to have the EUR 260 million which we have been subtracted in the proposal for a financial framework for the sector, because I think that, with such a small fund, no cuts should be made. You mentioned it, but you said that the financial framework has to evolve. Yes, evolution, yes; cut, no. I would also like to say that I think there is a more risky bet on the issue of labelling. I mentioned FAO areas: they are made for something else, not for clarity to consumers; I think that does not contribute to clarity. It will therefore have to be worked on in the future, but also in the labelling of processed fishery products there is a need to make some changes. Finally, I regret the news you have given us today, here, about the necessary ratification of international conventions on safety and labour standards. It is very regrettable that the Commission has addressed all Member States and only one has shown readiness to answer. I therefore hope this will change, because I think it is a very substantial element.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: rapporteur. — Mr President! Thank you dear colleagues for all the encouragement, and thank you to Commissioner Vella, too, for your fine words. I hope that my report can give us a review of the challenges we face when it comes to fish products on the EU market and the double standards that still premium imported products produced under lower standards. It is important that EU consumers feel that they can rely on products on the EU market, that they keep good quality and that they are produced sustainably. The report contains many good ideas that the Commission can work further on to raise standards and quality imports of fishery products. It must not be that the lists of vessels approved for EU hygiene requirements become a backdoor into the EU market for smaller not-related vessels fishing illegally. The stamp from the Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety indirectly becomes a signal to the EU customs authorities that everything is in order. Unfortunately, there are several such examples today, especially for ships fishing in the fish-rich West African waters. That is because the regional fisheries organisations of West Africa, Cecaf and SRFC, do not list which vessels are fishing illegally. Since the EU also does not list vessels fishing illegally in the region, fish caught by such vessels will not be denied access to the EU market if they are at the same time on the list of vessels that comply with hygiene requirements. Coordination needs to get better to stop these kinds of skewed conditions. It is also illogical that third countries warned by the EU of the risk of trade sanctions by the EU under the IUU regulation are simultaneously negotiating free trade agreements. This needs to be better coordinated within the EU, between the Commission's different entities, so that it becomes logical and sends a clear signal that the EU does not accept illegal fish on its market. Once again, big thanks for all the valuable commentary and encouragement. I hope that we can work further on the ideas in this Engström report in a positive way, not least when it comes to the control regulation.

name: El presidente. –
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote on Clara Eugenia Aguilera García's report will take place tomorrow Tuesday and the vote on the Linnéa Engström report will take place on Wednesday.

name: El presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Herbert Dorfmann, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the future of food and agriculture (2018/2037 (INI)) (A8-0178/2018).

name: Herbert Dorfmann
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by warmly thanking all the shadow rapporteurs who have helped me a great deal of work in the last few months. In a report, the Commissioner presented new ideas on the future of the CAP and presented the idea of a new delivery model. It called for a new relationship between the European Union and the Member States and the regions when it comes to the common agricultural policy. We do not completely exclude ourselves from such an idea. But I believe that the 'G' in CAP, that is to say the common one — the fact that the common agricultural policy must be a common policy — must continue to be preserved. We must also continue to guarantee the competence of the regions and countries in the field of agriculture. But let me move on to the first pillar of the CAP, that is to the area where the most money is spent in the common agricultural policy. I think we should just ask ourselves: what kind of agriculture do we actually want in Europe? And we should promote agriculture based on family farms, an agriculture that is sustainable, an agriculture that is also innovative, which characterises our cultural landscape, and also an agriculture that is attractive to young people who will be able to continue farming in Europe tomorrow. If we want such agriculture, then we need to think about a few things in the first pillar, then we need a fair distribution of funds between the Member States. And just can not necessarily mean that everyone gets the same amount, but the payments must be at least equivalent. We need a fairer distribution of funds in the Member States, especially where there is still a historic approach to the calculation of payment entitlements. We must ensure that the money is effectively received by farmers and not by those who have claims in their hands and thus create their return. We need coupled payments that do not distort competition. We have a lot to do here when we look at what is happening right now. And we also need — and not everyone likes this — clear degressivity, and we also need efficient capping. And efficient capping means that it must also work, so it's not just on paper, as it is today. We need a new green architecture. A new green architecture means that we need clear conditionality in the first pillar, that is to say clear environmental requirements, and that we need strong agri-environmental programmes in the second pillar. Green architecture, sustainability must not be reduced, but it must be more efficient and simpler. Two words on the second pillar: the second pillar is important, and we must clearly de-bureaucratise, streamline and make the second pillar simpler. In the second pillar, we need to create incentives for sustainable agriculture, that is to say, for real, good agri-environmental programmes, and we must also ensure that disadvantaged areas can play their role and get the funding they need from the second pillar. A few words on market policy: we still have common market regulations in a few sectors: wine and fruit and vegetables. We should continue to do so, and we should even consider whether, for example, we could extend the fruit and vegetable model to other sectors, such as the milk sector in mountain areas. Let me say two words about the financing of this whole policy: of course, this policy needs money, and what is currently on the table — the Commissioner's proposal — cannot be accepted from an agricultural point of view. First of all, it cannot be accepted that the second pillar is significantly shorter than the first pillar. I don't think this is innovative, and it's not promising for the future. Nor can farmers now pay the bill for Brexit. They will also be the ones that will suffer the most from Brexit if market distortions really occur. Overall, I think, we have already succeeded in providing a good template here. I hope, Commissioner, that you will then take our proposals into account in your legislative proposals, which we will receive in a few days' time.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank the rapporteur, Mr Herbert Dorfmann, for this report, which is the outcome of a very intensive debate that you have been having over the last number of months, pointing to the importance of the future of EU agriculture and the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) as an enabling framework. I also want to complement Mr Dorfmann and all of the shadow rapporteurs and the membership of the Committee on Agriculture, and Rural Development (AGRI) for the efficiency with which they have gone about their work, culminating in what I hope will be a very strong endorsement of this report when you vote here on Wednesday. There is much that we could say in detailed response to the report, not least at this evening’s debate, which comes in the same week that the Commission, hopefully, is going to adopt and indeed publish the long-awaited legislative proposals on the future of the CAP. I do not want to pre-empt those proposals, which the Commission will publish; however, what I can say is that we have been following very carefully and listening very carefully to the views of the AGRI Committee, to the views of Mr Dorfmann and the shadow rapporteurs in the context of this report. We have met regularly and frequently. When you see the Commission’s proposals on publication, you will see very strong similarities between the content of this report and the recommendations contained in the proposals that will be published. The background against which all of us are operating is the budgetary one, which has been referred to by Mr Dorfmann. It is one in which one of the largest net contributors, the United Kingdom, is leaving the European Union. Against this reality, the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) is set at a level of 1.11% of gross national income of the remaining EU27. The Commission, which cannot run a deficit – like any Member State – has to propose a budget in the context of this reality. We have proposed a budget of EUR 365 billion for the 2021-2027 CAP, which is a cut of less than 5%. The cut for direct payments is less than 4%. For rural development, the proposal is to rebalance EU and national support in the context of the co-financing rates. If Member States, of course, choose to increase their level of co-funding, there is no reason why public support to rural areas cannot be maintained at current levels. Alternatively, of course, if all Member States agree by unanimity to provide more finance to the European Union budget in various ways, then improvements to the agricultural funding can be made possible. A key feature of the Commission’s proposals and one I have flagged clearly in the communication which was published on the future of food and farming in November is the new delivery model, and I want to thank Mr Dorfmann and the shadow rapporteurs and the AGRI Committee for supporting this new initiative. It is a new relationship between the European Union and Member States. The motivation behind this delivery model is to take better account of EU diversity, to better target and simplify the support and to ensure performance-orientation and a result-oriented CAP. At European Union level we will maintain and define a strong and common framework to ensure the achievement of common objectives, and Member States will make the detailed choices and operational definitions, in line with their needs and integrated into a single and streamlined CAP strategic plan which will cover interventions in both pillars. An area of obvious common interest is our shared objective for a viable and resilient EU agriculture throughout Europe. Direct payments play a key role in this regard, and they must – and will – remain an essential part of the future common agricultural policy. We must also look at these payments through the lens of fairness and, in the context of the Multiannual Financial Framework, the Commission has made a number of important steps towards convergence between Member States. For all Member States with direct payments below 90% of the EU27 average, the gap between current level and 90% of that average will be closed by half over a six-year period. Without prejudice to the precise contents of the forthcoming proposals, they will offer various possibilities to better target support towards the needs of our small and medium-sized farmers. These are the foundation of European Union agriculture. These are our family farmers. As I think we can all agree, EU agriculture needs to better manage our natural resources, to limit our greenhouse gas emissions and to adapt to climate change. We have to bolster environmental care and climate action and contribute to the environmental and climate objectives of the European Union, which are already agreed by this Parliament. The CAP will therefore have to reflect the higher levels of ambition and focus more on results, based on these objectives and the legislation that is already in force and the contribution that agriculture must make to these objectives. The current green architecture will be replaced by a new one that is based on the new delivery model, with environmental and climate objectives which will be set at European Union level, not at Member State level. In preparing their CAP strategic plans, Member States will take into account their local conditions and can devise a mixture of mandatory and voluntary measures in Pillar 1 and Pillar 2 that are appropriate to those conditions. There are a number of other areas identified in Mr Dorfmann’s report where the Commission and the European Parliament have similar views. Support for young farmers should continue and be improved. Attracting new farmers and facilitating generational renewal will be one of the main priorities of the CAP post-2020. We will have the opportunity for a further exchange on this important matter later on this evening with MEP Caputo. Innovation and knowledge-sharing is a key issue for the future CAP, with benefits in terms of competitiveness, sustainability and simplification. We will continue to support farmers in areas where agriculture is constrained by specific conditions, for example in mountain areas, and the new delivery model will enable Member States and regions to address these and other important issues in line with their needs within a strong and common European Union framework. The Commission will present its legal proposals for the CAP shortly and I will be meeting Parliament’s committee on 11 June to discuss these proposals in detail. In respect of the MFF, I can only urge you to make every possible effort to conclude your work within the current parliamentary mandate, though I am under no illusions about the challenge that such a timetable presents. However, what you would be doing in doing so is providing security and certainty for our stakeholders, famers and our people living in rural areas, particularly our young farmers. You can be assured, of course, of my constructive cooperation and that of my services in trying to make this a reality. In conclusion, can I thank Mr Dorfmann and his colleagues for this report, which is an invaluable contribution to the work of reforming, modernising and simplifying our common agricultural policy.

name: Seán Kelly
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Mr President, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (INTA), I want to say that I am very proud of our farmers and the food they produce in the European Union. Indeed as the trade committee, the INTA committee, we are very pleased also to note that we have had a positive trade balance in relation to the products we have produced for eight years in a row now. This is because of the standards which are applied within Europe and which are set and monitored by the Commission, and they deserve great credit for that. And, of course, because of the high standards of our food, the safety of our food, there is growing demand for it worldwide. I would like to compliment Commissioner Hogan in particular on his efforts to grow new markets, especially in places like China which is growing rapidly, and here again, standards is what will be the key issue. I think this is a very positive story where we are concerned. One point, though, that I would make is that we need to continue to have research and innovation in Europe because that way we will maintain our leadership.

name: Angélique Delahaye
text: draftswoman, ENVI committee. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this report is of paramount importance. European policies lead to price volatility in markets. It is therefore important to incorporate tools into the CAP to ensure our food sovereignty and protect farmers' incomes. I thank my colleague Herbert Dorfmann for incorporating in his report my proposals adopted in the ENVI Committee. The Commission proposal suggests the renationalisation of the CAP. It is the European Parliament's duty to recall that this policy must remain a common policy, otherwise we will create distortions of competition within the single market itself. The CAP must have a harmonised environmental ambition at European level and thus help farmers wishing to go further in more environmentally friendly practices. We must promote double environmental and economic performance, and recognize the essential role of farmers: they are the first environmentalists. I therefore urge the Commissioner to take into account our remarks and recommendations, made in a very constrained timetable, and not to rush for an umpteenth reform which would be sloppy. European farmers deserve better.

name: Maria Noichl
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. — Mr President, I would also like to begin by thanking Mr Dorfmann and the shadow rapporteurs. Personally, I think it's a small step in the right direction, a small step. It's good to worry about necessarily introducing the capping. It's right to necessarily put the degression on the table. It is important to establish a conditionality that there is public funds for public services. These things are right. I would like to say, however, that personally I also lacked the courage to go beyond these things. In concrete terms, payments without consideration should have been clearly denied. It should have been made clear that income support for farmers is actually a social benefit and is on a completely different paper. However, I would like to mention one more point from the point of view of the DEVE Group: the question was whether we should not include another chapter in order to highlight the specific responsibility of European agricultural policy in the field of development policy. And this does not happen, unfortunately. I very much regret this, because our agricultural policy has an impact on Africa, our agricultural policy with soya import has an impact on Brazil, our agricultural policy and our fisheries policy have an impact on whether or not there are refugal movements on the other side of the world. And here from the perspective of the DEVE Group, from the point of view of the development aid group, the report is unfortunately, unfortunately not far-reaching. It is a missed opportunity to make it clear that agricultural policy in Europe is closely linked to flight movements around the world.

name: Nedzhmi Ali
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, among the most important sectors within the EU are food and farming, employing more than 60 million people and providing the food security for all of the Union’s citizens. Rural areas, including remotely-located mountainous areas, are not only used for production of food but are also home to a substantial number of Europeans and support the recreation and tourism industries. We should also not forget the environment protection measures. Having regard to the aforesaid, in order to deliver the objectives of the common agricultural policy in the future, there are some important aspects which should be underlined. Firstly, provision of an adequate level of funding within the next MFF, thus ensuring sufficient resources for the sector. Secondly, simplification and modernisation of the CAP should be done while at the same time, the financial and performance control and audit functions should be performed to the same standard and under the same criteria across all Member States. Finally, a fair distribution of direct payments among Member States will allow faster closing of the gaps between the different regions of the Union. Supporting the small farms and increasing efficiency of farming is essential.

name: Albert Deß
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group. Many thanks to Herbert Dorfmann and all colleagues who contributed to this report for their quick and reliable work. The report is a first landmark for the future of the common agricultural policy. It calls for the two-pillar structure to be maintained and clearly rejects further renationalisation. My group and I personally, Commissioner, are very sceptical as to whether the proposed proposals will lead to less bureaucracy. I am more concerned that bureaucracy will only be shifted from the European to the national level. But we will look into your proposals, and then we will continue to see how we deal with these proposals. The task of the common agricultural policy is to avoid distortions of competition and it is therefore necessary to balance payments not only between Member States but also in the Member States. I have tabled a request with colleagues to limit not only payments per farm but also per hectare. I hope that we will find good conditions for ensuring that agricultural policy will continue to be solidly financed at European level.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, I would first of all like to thank Mr Dorfmann and all those who have collaborated on this report for the result and the work they have done in a very short time. I would like to highlight, in my speech, the common response we have given from the Group of Socialists and Democrats to the European Commission communication. We have worked hard to do this, although with little conviction that this own-initiative report by Parliament will be taken into account, as legislative proposals are presented earlier this week. However, our work has been hard and I would like to highlight some of the proposals put forward and supported by my group. The common nature of Community agricultural policy must be upheld and the renationalisation of this policy should be rejected. The flexibility granted to Member States should not lead to distortions in competition, either at an economic or environmental level. The new application model raises many unknowns about this, ladies and gentlemen, because although the Commission insists on denying it, the unknowns are on the table. There must be 100% European Union funding of direct payments, and coupled payments should be maintained. We think it is important for productions and sectors at risk. An adequate budget for the CAP is necessary, at least at the same level as the current one, in constant euros, Commissioner. That is what we want, as well as a compulsory European, job-modulated 'capping', support for the generational shift and, finally, a CAP that supports farmers in the transition to more sustainable agriculture.

name: James Nicholson
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would also like to pass on my congratulations to the rapporteur for a very efficient and effective job that he carried out in an excellent way. The CAP is first and foremost about supporting agricultural production. EU farmers proudly produce food to some of the highest standards globally and they must be able to continue to do so in the future. The sector has faced a number of challenges from all angles in recent times, such as volatility in domestic and international markets, climate and weather conditions, food supply chain issues and, of course, the decision taken by the people in the UK to leave the EU.  The next CAP needs to be able to give farmers the necessary tools to address these challenges so that they can support high-quality EU food production in order to keep EU farmers competitive in the international marketplace and to protect the rural economy from extreme volatility and market crises. Of course, there needs to be adequate funding and I believe – and I have made this point a number of times – the biggest challenge will be the budget, and I heard what the Commissioner had to say. A large net contributor does not leave you without having effects, but who knows, it would be a brave person tonight who would actually tell us what the final arrangements or deals may well be when the UK finally leaves the EU. But I certainly believe very strongly that farmers should not be made to pay the price, whatever price has to be paid.  Aside from Brexit, the CAP share of the market may also come under pressure as a result of spending in other areas, particularly security and migration. I would like to thank Mr Dorfmann for his work again, and I look forward to hearing what the Commissioner has to say, because the future of the CAP is going to be as important to the rest of Europe as to those of us who will remain in the United Kingdom, as it is what our future with regard to agriculture may very well be in the long term as well.

name: Ulrike Müller
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, I too would like to thank the rapporteur very warmly. This report is a clear commitment to agriculture, forestry and food security within Europe. Together we have recognised the need for sustainable development. But we need targets and guardrails, Commissioner. Indeed, the future strategic plans of the Member States must not undercut the internal market and the competitive balance. We stand by the common sustainable agricultural policy with two pillars. The primary objective for us must be to achieve administrative simplification for farmers and foresters and to ensure planning security. If the large holdings are to be capped, it must be ensured that the money remains in the agricultural budget and benefits medium-sized and small farms and young farmers. Science, innovation and digitisation must also be able to be used by small and medium-sized enterprises, and I am sure that there are many good points that we have in our report that we can implement.

name: Thomas Waitz
text: Mr President, Commissioner. With the new agricultural policy, we will have an impact on farms, we will have an impact on the health of food for our citizens and on the environment. The first objective, however, must be to preserve our rural agricultural structures. To this end, we producers need fair producer prices and reasonable payments, even for small and medium-sized enterprises. My second objective is the production of healthy food by European farmers for European citizens. Because we are using European tax money to award subsidies here. The aim should also be the production of food for European citizens. The third objective is to focus on climate benefit rather than climate damage, to create the basis for clean water, to ensure healthy soils, to get along with a minimum of pesticides and to manage agriculture in the best possible way in harmony with nature. And as a fourth objective, I hope that support for agricultural industry, livestock farming and for an economy will end at the expense of the next generations. We did not inherit the floors from our parents, but we borrowed them from our grandchildren. That should be the top principle of our policy. Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Dorfmann and my co-rapporteurs for their constructive cooperation.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, thank Mr Dorfmann for the work he has presented to us here today. I wanted, first of all, to say, Commissioner, that solving the serious problems affecting rural and peasant farmers today at European Union level requires more than a distribution of aid: it requires political decisions; it requires a strong public agricultural policy. And in that regard, I would like to mention the major gaps in both the Communication you have tabled and the report we are discussing. The question of prices: prices are necessary to cover costs and production work; if not, we will not install anyone in rural areas. Secondly, the regulation of production is another fundamental element which cannot remain solely and exclusively on a matter of voluntariness. Thirdly: production model compatible with the environment, with water, air and soil conservation. And, as time is over, I did not want to end this speech without referring to another aspect forgotten in this Communication, which is the issue of equality between women and men in the countryside. We need the CAP to recognise shared ownership and to distribute the aid at 50% between both spouses or between both partners.

name: Marco Zullo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have worked in the Committee on Agriculture to define a position on the agricultural policy of the future, and to respect this work Citizens we represent, I expect that you, Commissioner, will take into account what is done. We are concerned about cuts, which today appear greater than originally announced. Again I want to reiterate that indiscriminate cuts will hurt the sector. Instead, focus is on savings and in measuring the results of the proposed actions. As for the transition to the so-called new delivery model, it is presented as a greater autonomy for the Member States, but it risks being a step backwards towards nationalizing the sector, where controlled and controller coincide, thus effectively going to further fragment the market and leaving room for national practices of unfair competition. We have the opportunity to draw an agricultural policy that is, yes, more environmentally friendly, but also that promotes a more sustainable model of food production and consumption, and above all profitable for everyone the actors of the supply chain. We must be ambitious, simplify procedures, reduce bureaucratic burdens, provide funds under a premium scheme, supporting those farmers whose activity really contributes to the good public. We reiterate the opportunity for a cap on direct payments, so as not to incentivise financial speculation and land concentration. We need to help small and medium-sized companies, and that is why aid should be modulated, to be really a help and not to drug the market for the big ones. Socio-economic circumstances should be taken into account in the allocation of funds between Member States. In fact, if the cost of living is different, the same amount granted as aid can have a very different concrete impact, and we do not want to generate further distortions in the single market. Finally, we will not accept tight timelines for the rush to close. We need a thorough debate so that this reform can really put the agri-food sector at the heart of the economic development of the European territory.

name: Philippe Loiseau
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Rapporteur, if only the next CAP could stand out from the current one. When the European Union presented the 2014-2020 CAP, it welcomed, self-congratulated, and even sent a message of hope to the rural world: agriculture would be greener, more remunerating, more respectful of the territories. The CAP would even allow farmers to live with dignity from their profession and I'm going on... We are now at the sunset of the current CAP and on the next. Have all these pious vows been fulfilled? Ask the producers if their situation has improved. Ask grain farmers if they are happy to sell their grain below their cost of production. Ask the cattle, sheep and goat sectors if they welcome the free trade agreements. Ask the peasants. They are the users, so they will be the best and only justices of the peace in the common agricultural policy. On Wednesday, we will vote on Parliament's position on the future CAP. It is a fairly complete text that contains, again, many beautiful promises — and I would point out that they only commit those who believe in it. Nevertheless, I welcome the signal sent to the Commission, particularly on the maintenance of the budget and hence aid. The rural world is focusing on this reform of the CAP, as you know, so I am taking this spotlight to highlight one very worrying point: do farmers only know that, in recent years, through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), hundreds of thousands of euros have financed programmes to support the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD). the settlement of migrants in rural areas? Our group has tabled an amendment so that the future CAP can no longer ruin our farmers of their priority. Ladies and gentlemen, I hope you will assume your responsibilities on this crucial amendment.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: - Mr President! The solutions proposed today will have implications over a ten-year period. For agriculture it's an exceptionally long period. What could happen then? There will be a collapse of thousands more farms, heralded today by the shortage of young farmers and the ageing countryside. What are the causes of this? There are many: firstly low incomes in agriculture, secondly a lack of price and market stabilisation, thirdly weaker technical and social infrastructure in the countryside, and low levels of services, fourth a large nuisance of labour in agriculture, fifths unfavourable international trade agreements. That in total translates into lower living standards for farmers. These adverse processes lead to excessive concentration and industrialization of production, to the disappearance of the European model of agriculture, sustainable agriculture, environmentally friendly farming. The proposed drastic cuts in the common agricultural policy — more than 15% — will also worsen our competitiveness on the global market and consequently lead to a breach of food security, which seems unimaginable and yet possible.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, we need an ambitious CAP. We have been repeating it for many months. Thank you to rapporteur Herbert Dorfmann, as well as the shadow rapporteurs for the quality of their work. Many elements are contained in this report, from securing farmers' incomes, the position of agriculture in free trade agreements and the reorientation of agriculture to take into account the environmental and climatic aspects of biodiversity. It's all there. I only hope that you will have time to read the contents of this report before Friday, since it seems that it is Friday that you are going to propose your legislative text to us, although I regret that you are proposing it first to the press, then to the Council and finally to the European Parliament. But that is your vision of democracy. I want to tell you that it is a matter of studying with great precision the content of this report, in a budgetary framework not less than 5%, as you have said to us, but less 25% for the second pillar and at least 14% for direct payments to farmers. Because we have to reason in constant euros and to be very specific on this particular issue.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! The report discussed today includes demands that deserve attention, such as rejecting the renationalisation of the CAP while bringing decisions on the shape of national agricultural policies to the level of Member States, retaining the bi-pillarity of the CAP, reducing payments direct to large holdings or ensuring that direct payments go to farmers engaged in plant or animal production. But despite these positives, I would like to draw attention to the transcript contained in the 64th point of the report, which speaks to the impossibility of full alignment of direct subsidies between new and old Member States due to production costs, in particular land costs and purchasing power money. In my opinion, maintaining this inequality beyond 2020 will expose the Commission to the allegation of discrimination against agriculture in the Central and Eastern European countries, and the dispute on this issue may move to the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, I would like us to have a discussion here in the European Parliament about what we would like to do with the long-term agricultural policy and that we do not get bogged down in detail. What I do not want, for example, is that the agricultural budget is still necessary to provide a certain income for the farmer and that the agricultural budget is spent to subsidise land ownership. I would like farmers to be able to stand on their own feet, keep their own pants on, and that the money from the agricultural budget is actually invested in the sector in order to face the future in this changing world. I want us to be able to deal with price fluctuations, that we can deal with unsuccessful harvests, but also that the sector can offer solutions to combat climate change, to reduce environmental impact, to preserve biodiversity and landscape features. The world around us is changing. The farmers want to move forward. Now the European Parliament.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr President! It is gratifying that the reform of the CAP has finally arrived in Parliament. As we have been emphasising for years, the preservation of the European cultural landscape is of great importance and, in particular, small and medium-sized farms make a significant contribution to this. The fact that large farms are to be deprived of the possibility of obtaining six-digit aid per year through the mere fallow land in their arable land is also to be welcomed. Politicians must once again appreciate the quality of our domestic products and, above all, also clarify the safeguarding of prices. It is also worth highlighting the idea of simplified management in order to obtain grants as a farmer, without having graduated in EU bureaucracy.
