However, as long as it is not ensured who will ultimately be the net financiers of this CAP reform and of the multiannual financial framework, I would like to point out that we should not welcome these well-intentioned promises too soon.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank Mr Dorfmann, the rapporteur, for the work and work of Mr Dorfmann, and all the shadow rapporteurs, who have carried out this dossier in record time so that we can vote on it, as the Commissioner said, before he submits his proposal to us in a few days. We are at a decisive moment for the CAP and, on the one hand, the future multiannual financial framework must not entail a drastic cut in the funds allocated to this policy. Of course, from the Committee on Agriculture in the European Parliament, I think that our intention is to work on this line. My second major concern, which is also present in this report, is directly linked to the budgetary issue, because excessive subsidiarity must be avoided, over time, to the renationalisation of the common agricultural policy. We cannot tolerate that this Community policy, which plays a very important role in the European Union's food sufficiency, ceases to be common. This would only generate imbalances and competition problems between producers in different Member States. Therefore, the report we are discussing today is the first step in the reform process in which we will be involved until the end of the term. And as such, it's a good step.

name: Paolo De Castro (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the report that this House is preparing to vote sends a clear message: the European Parliament will never accept a renationalisation of agricultural policy common. We would have hoped that this position could be transposed into the now public reform proposals. Instead, it was preferred to accelerate sharply — overstepping the prerogatives of normal interinstitutional dialogue — with a proposal from the Commission that risks winding down the largest and important experience of supranational policy of the history of the Union. We do not want this reform to turn into the anteroom of the decline of the same agricultural policy, which must remain “common”, guaranteeing growth, productivity, sustainability and competitiveness to all of our farmers, without risk of distortion of competition between states, or even between different regions. The sole responsibility for controls for the Union is not enough, Commissioner, to define it common.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: - Mr President! On behalf of Polish farmers in accordance with the accession treaty and the resolutions of the Polish Parliament, I request that the full alignment of direct payments between Member States be completed. I oppose further discrimination against farmers from Poland who have to compete on unequal principles, for example with their neighbours in Germany. I do not condone the equalisation of subsidies with the absurd, unfair criteria in the Dorfmann report, which instead of equalizing living standards, fill the gap between countries, create an inferior category in the European Union. Poland — the country I come from — has been a member of the European Union for 14 years. The Union assured Polish farmers in the accession treaty that in 2013, which is after ten years of membership, the gradual alignment of subsidies would end. We are 2018, and the discrimination against farmers from the so-called new member states is still no end. Maintaining the unjust system of direct subsidies in force infringes Articles 18 and 40 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to speak for the People's Party's Amendment No 2 and ask you to vote in favour in the vote on Wednesday. It's about the irrigation. In irrigation, the European Union stands only at 9%. The European Union stands at 6.2%, the whole of Europe is 9%, even America is 12 -13%, Asia is 41% and the World is 21% in terms of irrigated areas. There's a big problem. EU investment aid is very complex and difficult to access. Licensing procedures are anti-host and irrigation development aid is too strict. These regulators need to be simplified and easily enforceable in these areas. I ask the Commissioner to take this speech extremely seriously.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, in pursuit of the idea of colleagues Adrieu and De Castro, I would also like to emphasise, in particular, that we protest and do not allow anyone to cut down European Community funds so far spent on agriculture or rural development. This will lead to the loss of solidarity, which is still in fact incomplete, which would otherwise be quite reasonable between cities, cities, well-performing cities and impoverished regions. In this current race, however, smart villages and smart technologies appear as a key and new element — already in the Commission's proposal — as well as smart technologies. These instruments are further strengthened by this report. In order to successfully implement smart villages and effectively develop rural areas, the available resources must be linked together. We need an integrated, multi-fund and investment promotion approach, so we need a second pillar within the common agricultural policy, which is linked to the funds that affect other regions. Let us allocate 5% from other funds, such as regional funds for complex development of smart villages.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: — Dear Chairman, the Common Agricultural Policy is the longest-running and most successful policy of the European Union. I want it to be in the future. So we need to make it simpler and more flexible, but not in a way to bring bureaucracy down from European to national level, but for farmers to feel real relief and benefit. The agriculture budget must not be reduced, and grants should be directed to small and medium-sized farms that are real carriers of food production and rural space conservation. It needs to be further mobilised under the Second Pillar for Young Farmers to achieve generational renewal. Young farmers need to make it easier to get into business by removing barriers and introducing specialised programmes that will also allow older farmers to retire easier. So far, no Member State has introduced a thematic sub-programme for women in rural areas and I urge them to do so because we aim to improve women's overall position in rural areas and have their work recognised and paid for.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: — Mr President, the agricultural sector needs a reform that takes account of the previous difficulties faced by farmers. At the same time, it must adapt to new social and economic realities that allow farmers to live better, but also increase their capacity to produce cheap and affordable food for the population. In this respect, beyond the financial envelope of the PACs, which is also important, I appreciate that simplification is much more important. I call on the European Commission to establish a single set of rules, valid both for farmers in the West and for farmers in the East, while prohibiting Member States the possibility of coming up with additional rules for farmers. I welcome the maintenance of direct payments, but at the same time, I draw attention to the need to support farmers fairly according to their needs. Equally important, however, is the balancing of direct payments between Member States due to the fact that we are players in the same single market.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this report begins a new round of debate and negotiation on the CAP. We need a fairer policy that addresses challenges such as climate change, but above all we need an agricultural policy that persists in its common aspect and which effectively meets the needs of farmers, because there is no agriculture or rural world without farmers. Member States should continue to have room for manoeuvre in the first pillar of the CAP to provide support linked to sectors of particular social, economic and environmental relevance. It is essential to continue with the adjustment of national direct payment appropriations towards greater convergence between Member States. I call for the maintenance of a robust European budget for European agriculture, with no national co-financing under the first pillar of the CAP. Finally, I would like to take account of the particular situation of the outermost regions in the process of CAP reform.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, first of all, we should point out that the new CAP must return to the principle of Community preference, as it was when it started, which means direct support for farmers in the European Union themselves. And certainly not to rely on the famous international trade agreements which are dismantling the rural world, particularly in the South of Europe. The second point is that there should be no reductions in the new CAP. Although we will have Brexit, although we will have a reduction in revenue, new resources will have to be found so that the funding for the common agricultural policy does not really fall at all. The next issue is support for agriculture in the small islands that are really in need, as well as support for small farms, as well as support for young farmers. Delays in payments must be stopped and provision should be made for low supplies and low agricultural oil.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, thank you for your work Mr Dorfmann. I have to say I am worried when you look at what happened with a package that was designed at home in Ireland – GLAS. It was meant to be simple because it was designed at home and people would understand what they were at and we ended up with mayhem on it and it was anything but simple; but the biggest problem that we had with it is that when farmers then came to us and were told that they had to do x, y and z, when we brought them to the Commission, the Commission told them they could do nothing about it. They couldn’t help them and they were sent back and forward and back and forward and the problem was never solved. So who will take ownership of it if there is an issue there? There is good news definitely, the idea that farmers will not be paid for what they did decades ago – that’s a good move. The idea that areas of natural constraint will get more funding – who could disagree with that? Unless of course you’re on really good land. And the idea that farmers would get paid for public goods, which they are already delivering and not getting properly paid for, that’s a good idea. A bit of a curate’s egg.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: — I congratulate the rapporteur, colleague Mr H. Dorfmann, who has produced a really good report, but it is regrettable that it has not been possible to harmonise the unification of benefits since 2021. Back in 2003, when Lithuania joined the European Union, the European Council decided to equalize payments to Lithuanian farmers by 2013, but so far this has not been done and I would like to inform that payments amount to only 60%. The average of the European Union. I want to ask when will the Commission implement the European Council's decision to equalize payments for all farmers so that both farmers and Member States are competitive and do not feel second-class?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, the future of agriculture will also determine to a considerable extent the future of production of products, which will meet the food needs of the generations of the future. That is why the common agricultural policy must be flexible, flexible and be able to meet the challenges of the future. It is true that agricultural policy must be common. However, if it is to be successful and pragmatic, it must also take account of the specificities of each Member State. Other are the needs of the countries of Northern Europe and others of Southern Europe. Moreover, it should be borne in mind that needs are not addressed only by grants. Of course, the needs of farmers and small businesses must be addressed, but the interests of farmers should be protected in their broad sense. This will happen if we do not import uncontrolled products from third countries in order to create unfair competition for European agricultural products.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President! Four brief remarks — firstly, agricultural policy can deliver on time. Thank you again to the rapporteur for having managed to discuss the agricultural report in plenary on time today. Secondly, we have embarkoned with the new so-called new system of the Commissioner's new 'delivery' system — that is the good news. Commissioner, you know my opinion. I ask you again, this is not just about relations between the Commission and the Member States. We also need to look at relations with the farmer, because the farmer is at the heart of our political interest. And there too, the de-bureaucratization must really take place. Thirdly, agricultural policy must become fairer and more explicit, especially for the taxpayer. Capping, degression, overpayment for the first hectare — something needs to be done. However, I believe that the conditions in the Member States are so different that we have to define the toolbox in Brussels, so to speak, and the application must then be decided in the Member States.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner Hogan, the money from the European Union budget for agriculture has made the Union one of the largest producers of agri-food goods worldwide, clear proof that we must maintain the same CAP budget and the two pillars. Yes, targeted funding is needed for small and medium-sized farms, but large farms also need adequate funding. I do not agree with capping and I recommend the idea of having a greater redistributive payment. If the majority of Member States vote for capping, then I will speak strongly for voluntary capping. On the external convergence side, we need to achieve an equalisation of direct payments between European farmers. The rationale which was envisaged when determining the different amount of subsidies between European farmers, i.e. different production costs from one country to another, is no longer relevant. Oil, agricultural machinery, workers' food, pesticides used in agriculture, labour, all now have an equal cost in all EU Member States. For European farmers to have equal opportunities in a single EU internal market, the Romanian farmer must have the same subsidy as the French farmer and not half, as is the case today.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Vice-President, first of all I want to reiterate my thanks to Mr Dorfmann and the shadow rapporteurs for the work that they've done. I have read the report and I think, based on your report, I can tell you that we have a lot of common ground in relation to the proposals that will emerge. Your contributions from several committees this evening, other than Agriculture, shows the wide level of interest that there is in the common agricultural policy right across this House. The CAP is, as I've said many times, an economic, environmental and social policy and the legislative proposals that we are bringing forward must reflect that. The proposals will also reflect the principles that we have identified in the communication last November.  I agree with Mr Kelly, when he expresses his pride in our farmers, and I think everybody agrees that the key role of farmers in providing high quality food in a sustainable manner is crucial from the point of view of the policy that we are trying to improve. And since we published our communication, there have been some concerns expressed about the rise of renationalisation and these have been repeated by a few Members this evening. I want to reassure you that I'm confident that you will see in the proposals that will be adopted that there is no intention whatsoever to renationalise the CAP.  Our proposals would provide for genuine subsidiarity in the implementation of the policy, while also containing sufficient safeguards to ensure that the common nature of the policy will be maintained and farmers will not be put at a competitive disadvantage as a result of our proposals. The internal market and its integrity are essential to our agricultural policy and essential to our farmers, and that will remain the case. The budgetary situation has been mentioned by Mr Nicholson and others. It's a challenging one, based on the fact that we have 12 billion less from the fact that the United Kingdom is leaving. That is the present situation and I agree with Mr Nicholson, the end result of course nobody can predict at the moment, but we cannot predict as well whether we will have unanimity or not by the other Member States, the other 27, in relation to putting more money in various ways into the total EU budget.  So, it's a matter for the Council and the Parliament to negotiate. Madam Senra Rodríguez is right when she says that the CAP is about political decisions. I will be bringing shortly the Commission's responsibility in this regard and it will then be a matter for all of us to work together as co-legislators, particularly the Council and the Parliament, to take responsibility and we will be there to help in whatever way we can work closely with you to achieve a satisfactory outcome.  The issue of fairness and equity in payments is very important and it has been frequently raised, and one which we highlighted in the November communication, and we will be making proposals with regard to convergence. We will be making proposals in relation to capping and we will be making proposals in relation to small and medium-sized farmers. Also, we will be making proposals in relation to internal convergence.  Just to clarify issues for my friend Mr Eric Andrieu, but I don't know where you're getting your figures about 25% and 14%, you're talking to too many academics. But, anyway, the budget proposals that I have been involved in actually are generated on the same basis as the last occasion, which many people here were involved with. So, comparing like with like, I want to just reiterate that the proposal in the MFF for agriculture is less than 5% cut in direct payments and of course it is a cut in rural development, but the overall budget is less than 5% cut. So I don't know where you're getting these figures. But anyway, I'd be anxious to hear. The average cut in direct payments as I mentioned earlier is closer to 3% than actually 14% that you have mentioned and, with envelopes increasing from a number of Member States, the figures in relation to rural development can improve. These figures represent in the same way as was agreed seven years ago, and they'll stand up to any scrutiny.  The reduced level of EU co-financing of the second pillar can be compensated by Member States or by more contributions from Member States into the budget.  I want to assure my friend Professor De Castro that he doesn't have to worry about respecting any proposals or rejecting any proposals on renationalisation because there won't be any. There is no intention to make any such proposals and I hope there'll be no amendments put down in that respect either for to do the opposite. This will be explicitly clear in the Commission's proposals that I will publish. You don't need a straw man in order to push the haystack, we won't need to have to do that. Vice-President, the rapporteur’s report is a welcome and constructive contribution to the debate about the modernisation and simplification of the CAP and I look forward to presenting the Commission's proposals to the Parliament's Agriculture Committee, and when you do, and I am confident that you will see significant similarities, as I said already. Can I say to my friend Mr Marias, who is no longer here with us, from Greece, who was against free trade agreements in relation to agriculture, and I have just approved some promotion money for feta cheese, which is a very important product in Greece and which I regularly am asked by Mr Marias and others in Greece about how we can do to promote feta cheese internationally. So should I withdraw the money that I've already approved for this promotion programme and actually eliminate any prospect of feta becoming internationally well-known and actually able to get a market share in our free trade agreements? I'm not so sure. I'm sure he didn't mean that. In the meantime, thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen, for your support. Thank you Mr Dorfmann and your shadow rapporteurs for the great work that you have done, I think there are a lot of similarities that we have discussed on many occasions in COM AGRI and I don't think there'll be too many surprises when the proposals emerge from the Commission.

name: Herbert Dorfmann
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I have now heard many very coinciding speeches in this debate, and I do not really want to go into the content at all. The common agricultural policy is one of the oldest policy areas we have in the European Union. We have been pursuing a common policy for our farmers since 1962, and we should now simply develop this policy carefully and sensibly. We do not need a revolution, but we need a further development of this policy which is in line with the new circumstances. And we must not call this development into question — on the one hand, not through renationalisation, which I believe would only open the door to market distortion in Europe, nor through an austerity policy that ultimately eliminates this policy. Commissioner, you know as well as we do here that inflation should, of course, be taken into account for the fact that all occupational groups are also allowed to reduce the inflation of their income. You should also admit that to the farmers. And if you take that into account, then, unfortunately, the savings will be slightly higher than you have indicated here. But we will also be very clear about this with your colleague, the Commissioner for Budgets. In conclusion, I would simply like to thank the shadow rapporteurs once again, including those responsible for the opinions that have been made. I think it's just us now. We have really succeeded in finding a common position in this report on very important key points, and I hope that this common position will also survive the vote here in Parliament the day after tomorrow. And then, I think, it's up to us. We would, of course, be delighted, Commissioner, if this opinion were included in your proposal. But if not, then we are legislators here and we will also have to ensure that our opinions and our positions on various areas are then introduced and that Parliament will then process your proposals accordingly. Thank you very much. I hope that we will continue to work very efficiently on these issues over the next few months.

name: El presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing. — I consider the debate on the future of food production and agriculture to be extremely important and necessary. I am pleased that the Dorfmann report addresses such important issues as the need to ensure adequately high funding for the common agricultural policy or the fair distribution of direct payments between Member States. However, I would like to point out a specific, serious threat to the future of agriculture, more specifically pig farming, namely the African swine fever epidemic, which has been increasingly spreading in Central and Eastern European countries for 4 years, also threatening other countries Union. I would like to stress that without decisive, solidarity, the future of pig farmers across the European Union will be seriously threatened, and I would therefore urge the Commission to pay close attention to this problem.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: in writing. – The strategic report represents the EP’s position on the CAP’s future ahead of the presentation by the Commission of legislative proposals, expected 1 June. The compromise of the last CAP reform was not satisfying yet with the new proposals, we have to go further now. It is important to ensure a level playing field and equal competition conditions for farmers across the EU single market. Hence, the Baltic States insist on convergence of the direct payments despite Brexit and the new EU priorities like defence and migration. The direct payments for the Baltic States’ farmers are still among the lowest in the EU and remain considerably below the European average. This is not just and sustainable, given that we face almost the same costs and challenges across Europe. Let us change that! I support the EPP lead report which calls for the future CAP to retain funding at least at current levels and for fair distribution of direct payments between MS, is against renationalisation and for the maintenance of the Two-Pillar Structure; any new model for implementing the CAP must maintain a level-playing field within the SM, respect the different competences within MS and entail genuine simplification for farmers.

name: Carolina Punset (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Between 2012 and 2016 organic farming grew by 18.7%. Retail sales in the EU organic market grew by 54% between 2010 and 2015 and the total area of organic farming in the EU increased by 21% over the same period. Globally, the green sector continues to grow strongly, driven by a significant increase in consumer demand. Although the CAP allocates organic farmers an 'green' payment and can also receive support for conversion, the challenge facing the sector is to ensure a steady growth in supply and demand. With prices of organic products higher than conventional products, the market struggles to meet demand and the premium consumers are willing to pay has the potential to encourage some fraud. Increasing consumer demand, market opportunity for producers and, above all, the great advantage as mitigating emissions in a sector that does not intend to reduce them, mean that the greening of the CAP is not sufficient, and therefore even targets for organic agricultural production should be set, as in others sectors of the economy.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ECR)
text: in writing. — I believe that the common agricultural policy needs to be modernised and, moreover, it needs to be simplified. I support the Commission's proposal to put into operation a programme to develop, implement and control a results-based approach so as to support performance. This programme should be implemented in such a way as to lead to simplification in the true sense of the word and not to add new administrative burdens for farmers. Modernising the common agricultural policy must envisage the renewal of generations of farmers and providing incentives for young farmers, which will lead them to enter the agricultural sector, but also to remain in this area. Similarly, a favourable environment for the development of farmers must be created through financial support for the establishment of producer organisations, the elimination of unfair practices and the adaptation of environmental architecture to local needs.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. — We are once again at the point where we need to reform the common agricultural policy. I want the new CAP to be better able to respond to the current challenges. I wish there were no more differences in payments between Member States or regions. I wish farmers could have a decent income and better access to the market. I want young people who want to stay in the countryside or settle there, to be able to enjoy more consistent support. I want agricultural enterprises and farms benefiting from subsidies to be constrained to respect the environment and produce in a sustainable way. I want the struggling sectors to be able to receive coupled support, and local markets and short supply chains to be encouraged. Agriculture is not just an economic sector, it is a vital sector for humanity, which provides us with quality food and manages limited resources such as water or soil. That is why I hope that this sector will enjoy adequate funding. I hope that in the forthcoming negotiations of the multiannual financial framework, we will be able to maintain a significant budget for the CAP.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Nicola Caputo, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the implementation of CAP instruments for young farmers in the EU after the reform of 2013 (2017/2088 (INI)) (A8-0157/2018).

name: Nicola Caputo
text: Rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the European Union only 6% of the total of those who run farms are under 35 years old, while more than 50% are over 55 years old. Generational renewal in the agricultural sector therefore needs incisive policy measures in the new CAP to promote generational change. In the text approved by a large majority in the AGRI committee, various policy recommendations have been made to improve the existing support scheme and to assist young farmers in access to agricultural activity. Access to land, as it is known, is the main obstacle preventing new agricultural entrepreneurs from starting agriculture businesses in Europe. Access to land is limited by poor land availability and of course also competition from other farmers and investors. The problem of access to land has been sharpened essentially as a consequence of the current structure of direct payments, which often leads to increases in land rent and purchase prices. Too many owners or renters tend to stay in business for as long as possible in order to continue to qualify for subsidies, using service providers to farm the land or working to a minimum the cultivated land they have. In my view, the levels of activity needed to allocate payments intended to support the achievement of certain targets should be increased, just as I think a ban on cumulation must be enforced not relevant to subsidies with the use of pension allowances. Member States must implement new measures to give new agricultural entrepreneurs and young farmers priority access to agricultural land by making full use of all instruments regulatory and also taking its cue from best practices already successfully implemented in some Member States. For example, tools such as rural banks could be envisaged, which could further facilitate access to land, but also provide a complete picture of land availability for young people farmers. Generational replacement with regulations, for example on succession and taxation, rules on access to land, territorial planning and corporate succession strategies should be facilitated. The current CAP does not provide incentives to foster the transfer of farms from older farmers to younger generations. It is a gap that needs to be filled, and it must be filled early, if we really want to incentivise young people. We can do this by introducing, for example, measures that can effectively motivate the elderly to transfer ownership of land, such as those on the early retirement scheme or other types of retirement incentives. With regard to the budget, it is vital to continue to provide support for the young farmers programme, but increasing the maximum level of national funding to more than 2% for payments compulsory first pillar, and increasing the percentage of support of the second pillar to encourage generational renewal. We recommend an improvement in measures to facilitate access to finance with facilitated interest rates on loans to new agricultural entrepreneurs, including by operators private financial instruments, implementing financial instruments to provide zero-rate loans for the investments of young farmers. Better cooperation is also needed with the EIB and the European Investment Fund, in order to promote the creation of ad hoc financial instruments dedicated to young farmers in all States members. An important point is simplification: the overall management of direct payments and measures of the rural development programme is considered extremely complex and difficult, in particular for new agricultural entrepreneurs who are not particularly familiar with the payment system, and therefore need a strong simplification of procedures and the reduction of time related to payment instructories. On training, the Commission and the Member States should be able to provide more opportunities for training and advice to young farmers, both potential and potential farmers confirmed, including competence for the start of business activities in agriculture and agricultural and technological skills related to new technologies and entrepreneurial, such as marketing, networking, communication, innovation, multifunctionality and diversification and skills finance. Innovation, finally, is one of the tools that can most contribute to improving generational replacement. Young farmers represent a great potential for innovation and diversification, given that they tend to have greater skills and managerial skills and to be more likely to access new markets, develop new production methods and make the best use of technological developments and innovations in the agricultural sector, able to enable them to respond to the environmental challenges of agriculture. It is therefore necessary to give strong support to young people who wish to introduce innovative production techniques and processes, such as precision agriculture and conservation systems, which are designed to improve the viability and environmental sustainability of the agricultural sector. Only by fielding these actions will young farmers be able to offer long-term prospects that can prevent the rural exodus. A strong support for young farmers is a sine qua non condition for securing the future of rural areas and should therefore be identified as the top priority in the framework of the new CAP for the period after the 2020.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Nicola Caputo and the shadows for this report. It comes at a very important time for European agriculture, not least for our young farmers. As you are aware, the Commission will adopt and publish its legislative proposals for the future of the CAP shortly, and I am very confident that you will see clear consistency between the recommendations that you have made, and the proposal that the Commission intends to bring forward in respect of young farmers. As Mr Caputo has pointed out, only 6% of European farmers are younger than 35 years, compared to 56% who are older than 55 years. Therefore, with an ageing agricultural community, generational renewal is increasingly important, and it needs to be accompanied by adapted policies. Currently, measures in Pillars one and two provide support to young farmers, notably the young farmer payment under Pillar one, which was introduced to provide an enhanced income support to newly-established young farmers during the initial setting-up period. In 2016, more than 300 000 newly set-up young farmers in the EU benefitted from this additional payment, which amounted to support of about EUR 360 million. The rural development policy also makes fundamental contributions to creating the best possible environment for young farmers. According to the targets that have been brought to the attention of the Commission by Member States and the rural development programmes, specific support for 176 000 young farmers will help a new generation of farmers to develop their businesses. So the Commission shares the views of the European Parliament that support for young farmers should continue and be improved. This is a position that I have consistently articulated over the last few years. This is why attracting new farmers and facilitating generational renewal will be an important objective of the CAP post 2020. Young farmers will benefit from a wide range of instruments, which will include a combination of mandatory and voluntary aspects. But the Commission will not be able to do this alone, and Member States will be requested to establish a generational renewal strategy and address key issues that your report has clearly highlighted, particularly those for which the Member States and not the European Union has competence. It will be important to describe how national instruments – for example taxation, inheritance law, regulation of land markets, territorial planning – can complement EU-supported interventions, and Member States will not get approval for their plans unless they are able to have a very important package for generational renewal, which is a good example of where we will have a common agricultural policy supported and approved at EU level. In relation to access to land and land transfer, the Commission shares the rapporteur’s view that this is a major barrier to young farmers setting up. This is why we have proposed to support forms of cooperation that could encompass farm partnerships between generations of farmers; farm succession or transition-planning services; brokerage for land acquisition; innovative national or regional organisations engaged in promoting and facilitating matching services between younger and older farmers. These are some examples that we can utilise more fully. On top of this, young farmers will benefit from investment support and knowledge transfer and training interventions, which are important to ensure the long-term sustainability of our farms. Member States will be allowed to establish financial instruments supporting working capital. This instrument can be of primary importance for young farmers and new entrants, who face more difficulties given the high investments and low returns of a start-up phase. The Commission continues to engage with the European Investment Bank, especially through our fi-compass platform, to learn from experiences and best practices on specific schemes for young farmers and new entrants. As part of the CAP planning process, the Commission will fully engage in accompanying Member State authorities to develop sound schemes for generational renewal, depending on the specific needs, focusing on innovative approaches, best practices and knowledge-sharing. So the Members of the House, particularly those who are members of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI), who have taken a very keen interest in, and constructive approach to, the needs of young farmers, can be assured that the Commission shares this view and will be bringing forward proposals accordingly. It is essential that we have more young people involved in farming in order to develop an efficient, competitive European agriculture and food production sector in the future. This report from Mr Caputo, together with the report that we have just discussed by Mr Dorfmann, are important contributions to the Commission’s policy development, and as I said at the outset, I hope that they will recognise many of the proposals and recommendations that can be seen in the Commission’s forthcoming proposals.

name: Nuno Melo
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (PT) Mr President, this report is important and timely; we have to consider that at European level there is one farmer under 35 for every nine aged over 55. In some states such as Portugal, Spain, Italy, the United Kingdom or Bulgaria, the proportion of young farmers is very low, only one farmer per twenty over the age of 55. It is obviously about maintaining our food self-sufficiency, and the problems mainly lie in setting up farmers, access to land, the transfer of farms from the oldest to the youngest and access to credit. Finally, as amendments that we are tabling, there are several suggestions that make sense to us, such as the creation of an Erasmus programme linked to vocational training to improve skills and the exchange of experience between young farmers, support for young people who want techniques and procedures for innovative production. Finally, no one questions the strategic nature of agriculture, but there is a serious abandonment of land and young people in rural areas must be given the same conditions as young people in urban areas. I wonder, finally, whether it is understandable that, for example, farmers in my own country are now receiving less money for selling their products than in 1986, when Portugal joined the European Union. Certainly, when this is the case, agriculture is not attractive.

name: Eric Andrieu
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to thank Nicola Caputo for this very good report. The European agricultural population is not renewed. This is the observation that is made and it is not new, unfortunately. For more than 50 years, agricultural development, supported by the CAP, has promoted the concentration and expansion of farms and has led to a high capitalization that has made some farms difficult to transmissible. However, the issue of generational renewal — as we see it today — is a crucial problem for our food security, and it is also so if we want to maintain living territories. Faced with this major challenge, we must put in place a proactive policy, combining European instruments with national arrangements, in order to ensure better access to land, financing and training. The entry of young people into agriculture is a key element of dynamism and innovation if we are to foster a change in our agricultural models. It must be said forcefully, as Nicola Caputo does. Renewal of generations is not only desirable, not only possible, but it is essential, Commissioner. Thank you for a take into account in your legislative proposal.

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, Commissioner, the average age in the agricultural sector is high, above average high, and only 6% of the people working in the agricultural sector are under 35 years old. However, it is not an end in itself to bring down the average age. I am concerned whether the agricultural sector still remains attractive for people to start working in. We are not going to solve this by giving young farmers more direct income support, direct income support paid by reducing the direct income support of the other farmers. Is that fair? Older farmers are also working hard every day to produce sufficient and good food. No, this can only be done by making the sector more competitive, making it more innovative and ensuring that the sector comes up with solutions to climate and environmental problems. I believe that this can be done in two ways: through technical solutions — such as big data, solar panels, precision agriculture — and ecological innovations — such as making soil healthier, breeding, and using insects to combat pest insects.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. It is really very important and necessary to discuss young farmers today, because there are three major problems in the existing support. The first — Commissioner, Mr Caputo, you both mentioned it — is access to land. This is the biggest hurdle for newcomers. And the existing young farmers support does not address this problem at all. We really need a very determined European Union strategy here. My second point is public money for public goods. This principle is completely ignored by young farmers. It is not those farms that contribute most to the environment, animal welfare, landscape protection, but all without differentiation that are promoted. And the third thing: we want to make agriculture a place of the future. This requires fair incomes for peasant work. New entrants in particular are often pioneers in organic farming, direct marketing, joint financing models, artisanal food production. And we should support these innovative projects in a very targeted manner so that they are also economically viable. This is far too little reflected in the existing report.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, if it was any other profession, we wouldn’t really be asking this question. If we were talking about a carpenter that went off to work every day and they come back with less money than they left in the morning with, you wouldn’t be asking why they were leaving the profession. Likewise with a hairdresser, if they couldn’t make money off it, you wouldn’t be asking why they were leaving the profession – you’d know why. Likewise with an electrician, if they couldn’t make a profit doing it, you wouldn’t be able to get anyone to do it. But you wouldn’t say the problem with the carpenter was access to wood, the problem for the hairdresser was access to scissors, or the problem for an electrician was access to copper. The problem is there’s no money in it and they’re not making any money out of it, and why would any young person go into a profession where they can’t make a living? So how do we help them make a living? We help them make a living by paying them for their produce, by a fair distribution of the CAP and by paying them for public goods. Then you’ll solve the mystery. Would any of you do a job that you didn’t get anything for? No, you wouldn’t. The problem is profitability.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I’d just like to remind Mr Flanagan, who has just spoken, that farming isn’t a profession, it’s a trade. There are three barriers to preventing young entrants to agriculture. The first is access to land. In the UK, local councils owned small farms and rented them out to young entrants as a first step on the ladder. The problem was that there were so few opportunities for the next step that young tenants became old tenants and the system just froze. The second is bed blocking by the older generation. Public money might be used to allow such individuals to retire with dignity and let the younger generation take the reins with new ideas. The third is access to capital by young tenant farmers. This could be facilitated by government loan guarantees. The guarantee would have to reduce in time, as the tenants should be able to demonstrate a profitable enterprise to interest commercial lenders on its own merits. The initiative by the Commission to give marginally more area aid to young farmers is fraught with bureaucratic problems and open to abuse. It won’t resolve bed blocking, it won’t increase access to serious capital, and on tenanted holdings, it will just roll out to the landowner.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, in the name of age renewal and support for young farmers, their demise and the concentration of land in a few hands is accelerating. A coup of grace will be the proposal to ban farmers from receiving at the same time as their meager pension and subsidy. Challenging now offers opportunities, you say, to activate insurance in the event of frost, drought and flooding. In other words, compensation is an opportunity and not an obligation of the state and the right of the affected small and medium-sized farmer. A new blow is also the proposal that part of the subsidies be converted into entrepreneurship seminars, which will even be a condition and condition for any subsidy that will be paid only if it is accompanied by a corresponding business plan. The direction of the CAP is clear: flexibility according to market appetites, producer groups and concentration of production on a few. The only way out for small and medium-sized farmers is to fight against the CAP, the government and the European Union with a social alliance against the policy that destroys them with demands based on their real needs.

name: Albert Deß (PPE).
text: Mr President! No future of agriculture in Europe without young farmers. No future of rural areas in Europe without young farmers. Without young farmers, no food security for half a billion people in Europe. That is why we are well advised to set up programmes, both financial and socially, so that young farmers are ready to act here again. I note that the situation in Europe is very different. There are more young farmers in some Member States and fewer in others. That is why, Commissioner, we have already expanded the scope for the Member States in the bus and coach procedure. However, I am also sceptical as to whether the support we have granted so far, namely to grant a supplement per hectare, is justified. The differences between the farms are too great. I give two examples: a young farmer can take over from his parents a farm where all the investments have been made, and another young farmer, whose father may have died prematurely and whose mother kept the farm afloat, must make huge investments in order for him to continue. This means that we need to focus more on investment and not necessarily provide flat-rate support so that young farmers are ready to take over farms here again.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: — Mr President, generational renewal and knowledge is fundamental to agriculture, because in this way we have managed to bring new people, new practices, new technologies and better ways of producing agricultural products with lower costs, less risks to the environment, human health and in a sustainable way. However, this renewal does not mean taking away some to put others, but rather to integrate new knowledge into the secular practices of our more experienced farmers who have contributed, and much, to the public good of agriculture. Nor should we forget that in many cases young people already work together on family farms but unfortunately rarely manage to own their own farm because of the funds involved in setting up the new farmers. I therefore believe that young farmers should have an increase in support whenever they take responsibility for family farms, in order to continue this activity, not least because, as we know, young people have greater difficulties in accessing capital. It is therefore essential that the European Union allows a dignified withdrawal from the sector of the most experienced with clear support, thus making room for the youngest.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, agriculture in Europe, like any other economic activity, lacks, and has been said here, young people who will provide the generational renewal necessary for the continuity of the sector with greater dynamism and openness to innovative solutions. In addition to the socio-economic trends that may justify the ageing of the countryside in Europe, access to land, vocational vocation, access to insurance and credit condition the setting-up of young people in agriculture. It is essential to provide Member States with appropriate instruments under the CAP to promote the rejuvenation of the agricultural sector through specific measures under the first and second pillar. It is also important, and this must be emphasized, that national policies can comfort these mechanisms with policies that facilitate access to credit, lease, land inheritance and tax subsidies with the aim of attracting young people and requalifying the rural fabric.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, measures to support young farmers are a social necessity for all young farmers in the European Union, especially in Greece, which has been hit by the harsh austerity, the brutal budgetary adjustment imposed by the troika and lenders. This means that concrete measures must be taken to support young farmers, especially young farmers in remote areas, and I am talking mainly about the Aegean islands. Furthermore, there must be financing tools and, at the same time, reducing the cost of supplies, reducing the cost of agricultural oil, and finally stopping the seizures of agricultural subsidies. Mr Hogan, the seizures of aid for young farmers must be stopped in Greece. I have denounced this matter on several occasions. The European Union must take action on this matter.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, if the common agricultural policy is to be successful and primary production is to be increased, the problems of access for young farmers to rural employment will have to be tackled. It is true that the land allocated has been considerably limited. It is also difficult — because there are no incentives — to withdraw old generations from farming and to transfer employment to the younger ones. Furthermore, the benefits given to young farmers should be social and not just financial support and subsidy. The problem faced by farmers, and of course young farmers, in Greece, which has been financially destroyed by the implementation of the memorandum measures, must also be tackled with great care. It is therefore an obligation of the European Union to protect mainly Greek agricultural production and the possibility of young Greek farmers to engage in agricultural activities.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: - Mr President! The introduction of a new reform of the CAP and a modern approach to its implementation should be entrusted first to young farmers. They have better competence, more skills in management, a lot of openness in the approach to innovation. The rapporteur and the Commissioner spoke of the barriers that young farmers must overcome, particularly the many national solutions related to counting, taxation and land harvesting. They require good solutions, more open to farmers. In the past, we have talked a lot about financial instruments, their role in the implementation of the CAP. I hope they will be included in the legislative proposals of the European Commission and in the national strategic plans. I think they'll be taken up by young farmers. Guarantees, surety facilitate access to capital. Innovation solutions, the introduction of modern technologies, more need to be based on young farmers to use this as their development opportunities. They are, after all, more open to knowledge and intelligent development. Finally, young farmers need the development of the village as the place of their lives.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, farmers over the age of 65 make up 31% of the working population in European agriculture, while young people under 35 account for only six percent. Farming of the future cannot be sustainable and performing without young farmers having financial support and access to state-of-the-art technological mechanisms. Depopulation of rural areas is a reality whose solution is concrete measures for young farmers. In order to attract and maintain farmers in rural areas, we need the second pillar, investment in agricultural infrastructure. Access to land is indeed the biggest obstacle to young farmers in Europe. In this context, I find very good for farmers the report that we will vote on tomorrow in plenary, but I call for the exclusion of the final part of Article 2.2 from the report on restricting farmers the possibility of benefiting, in parallel, from the state pension and agricultural subsidies, in the context of the fact that the pension in Eastern European countries is much lower than in other Member States of the European Union.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I am alarmed and concerned that only six percent of all farmers are under the age of 35. I am alarmed and concerned that young farmers in the EU have declined by one third — from 3.3 million to 2.3 million. The total operating ratio declined by 3.8 million, while the average farm size increased by 36%. For me, the two reports we are debating today belong together, and we will judge your response by following these two reports in the legislative proposals to be presented on Friday, not the other way around. Both reports are not about net contributors or net recipients. The beneficiaries of competitive, sustainable, fair and comprehensive rural agriculture, social cohesion in rural areas, high food standards, a livable cultural and natural landscape, a young generation of confidence who likes to operate a farm with confidence, are all citizens and citizens. Therefore, we should do what needs to be done and not let agriculture spoil the Brexit soup.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Caputo, I think this is a good report, but, in my opinion, the fundamental problem of young people's lack of interest in joining agricultural activity is the price they receive for products. And therefore, the question is to have a decent income. I think — and some colleague has already mentioned it — that is not an attractive profession for young people today, and that is why we have this main problem, because they do not get a decent income. And we must contribute to that. I would also like to point out that sometimes we mention the Commission's making policies for access for young farmers. But not only the Commission: Member States with their powers can also do a lot; they have the powers to allow access to these young people. And the problem of land use — is true. How is it possible that we get a low price for agricultural products and yet the value of the land is exponentially very high? What's going on? A big bubble? I don't know; something must be happening.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: — Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, young people across Europe are leaving rural areas, which calls into question food production and the survival of rural space. It is necessary to make rural environments a desirable place to live, and agriculture an attractive interest if we really want a generational renewal that underlies the future of European agriculture. Better support is also needed than the one that young farmers have today through additional mobilisation of financial instruments in the second tier. Inability to access agricultural land, late transfer of ownership of the farm, unavailability of credit at favourable interest and unfair trading practices are obstacles in the business of young farmers that must be urgently eliminated. All young farmers should have the same starting position regardless of which Member States come from, so they should be given access to financial instruments and loans on the same terms and interest rates. By introducing appropriate programmes that will encourage earlier transfer of ownership of farms can help young people get into business earlier, and the old to have a dignified old age.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank all of those who have contributed to this important debate. It is clear – and not at all surprising from the debate or indeed from the previous debate – that there is significant support for young farmers, and rightly so. We also spoke quite a lot tonight about the importance of innovation and knowledge transfer. The one idea of which we have no shortage, of course, is of innovative, knowledgeable young people who are anxious to get involved in farming, but sometimes there are many barriers in their way to doing so. The challenge is to remove those barriers and to encourage young farmers’ interest. Also, the challenge is to help them to overcome the many barriers to entry by Member States or, indeed, how we can help in the European Parliament and in the European Council, through the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). As I have indicated in my opening remarks, there are a suite of measures available in the existing Common Agricultural Policy and often they are not being used by Member States. These measures have different but complementary objectives. Of course we need complementary measures between those which come within the competence of the EU and those which are within the competence of the Member States. We have to get the Member States to utilise more policy options than today in order to help people and encourage them to become involved in agriculture. Member States have competence, for example, on taxation, and more can and should be done in this area in order to incentivise young people into farming.  When the Commission makes its legislative proposals later, we will include proposals to support our young farmers and I hope and I know that we can rely on your support in respect of these measures, but I would also encourage you to press your national governments to provide appropriate and complementary measures at the level of the Member State.  The European Parliament, and in particular through Mr Dess, Mr De Castro and Mr Siekierski, through the Omnibus, played a very important role in highlighting and increasing the support for young farmers. The provisions in the Omnibus certainly should be implemented in full by the Member States, especially the increase in the farmers’ top-up payment from 25% to 50%. Many Member States have taken advantage of increasing the top-up, but many Member States have not taken advantage of this particular new opportunity to give additional income, as Mr Flanagan has said, which is essential to ensuring that young people are, at least, given more attractiveness in terms of the support that is available through the Common Agricultural Policy. The fact that so many Member States have chosen to use the facility is encouraging, but let’s hope that we can find a way where all Member States will be able to support these measures.  One of the ways in which we will be able to do so is by having a specific objective in the CAP strategic plans, which will not get approval from the Commission unless they are able to show that they have genuine proposals to encourage more young people into agriculture and the food sector. It will be very important to see the reaction of the Council and Parliament in relation to how the specific objective of generation renewal for the first time will give a clear indication, as I said earlier, of the competence of having a harmonised but also common policy in relation to the specific objective of generation renewal. When I spoke earlier of the CAP, I referred to it as a social policy. We have a responsibility to maintain the fabric of our rural communities and that cannot be done if we don’t encourage or get more young people into the heart of our rural communities through agriculture and food. Several of you have referenced the demographics of the farming population, and you are correct in doing so. Generation renewal is not only desirable but essential to secure the future of our rural areas and to create the much needed jobs for many people in the non-farming sectors in our rural areas. This is a very important objective that we must get right in the context of the co-legislative process that we are about to embark on under the CAP.

name: Nicola Caputo
text: Rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will be forgiven for passing the minutes in my introduction, simply to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and all those who have contributed to this debate. I would also like to thank Commissioner Hogan for his words and for also saying that he wants to incorporate many of the comments that we have indicated in his proposal. I think we all agree that agriculture in Europe can improve and can only take off if we favour this generational change, because young people are better able to promote innovation as well in agriculture. I am sure that if we achieve this, we will also be able to grasp the other objective which has been highlighted by many colleagues, to improve the profitability of agricultural enterprises. So: younger and more agriculture in Europe.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 29 May 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The new regulation recently adopted by the Council, laying down new rules on organic farming, finally eliminates the last obstacle to the modernisation of the sector and the harmonisation of organic production standards, within the Union and beyond. The organic sector has grown by 125% over the past decade and is recording a remarkable ascending parable, gaining increasing importance. Growth, however, was strongly hampered by rules that were no longer fit for purpose and were absolutely revised. It is for this reason that I welcome the regulation adopted by the Council, as it will play a vital role by supporting the growth of the sector and providing an appropriate regulatory framework for purpose. I generally believe that the Commission and Parliament should direct young farmers and new agricultural entrepreneurs on the choice of crops to target. Many crops do not offer sufficient or reasonable margins in terms of market, demand or profitability, and this would greatly increase the entrepreneurial risk for young people entering the sector. Providing more tools to young agricultural entrepreneurs is the direction that is being taken, aiming to encourage generational replacement, to increase access to land and finance , for young farmers.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: in writing. — The participation of young farmers and the renewal of generations in the agriculture sector are essential to maintaining viable food production, as they ensure the sustainable development and long-term competitiveness of European agriculture. The latest reform of the CAP has given particular attention to this issue, increasing the scope of measures provided for in rural development policy and introducing a new programme for young farmers as additional support for direct payments. Despite these efforts, it appears that the current measures are not sufficient and that some adjustments will be needed in the future. The report calls on Member States to give new entrants and young farmers priority in access to agricultural land. Addressing this requires reassessing the direct payment system and creating an incentive for older farmers to pass on farms to younger generations. It also recommends that the focus be on reducing additional obstacles for young farmers, i.e. access to capital, lack of business skills and insufficient inheritance plans. It would also need to be addressed to reducing administrative barriers. Bearing in mind the welfare of young Polish farmers, I will vote in favour of the report.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The recent report on the implementation of the CAP young farmers’ tools in the EU after the 2013 reform highlights key issues such as improved access to land and credit, encouraging knowledge transfer and succession planning, the setting up of more advisory services, and the reduction of administrative barriers for young farmers. Unfortunately, there are more issues, which we should address such as demographic picture in some regions of the EU that are very unbalanced, with few or no young people living there. Obviously to counter these negative trends the EU and Member States should support young farmers. Young farmers and new entrants represent important sources of innovation and entrepreneurship within agriculture, bringing benefits such as the introduction of new knowledge or techniques, the development of new business and organisational models, more sustainable farming systems (e.g. share farming, pre-financing, crowdsourcing), the increase of connections between farming and the local community, and the adaptation of traditional knowledge to develop business innovations. Therefore, EU and Member States have to provide systematically consultancy and support for young people who want to become young farmers. Because young people are capital, which EU agriculture needs in order to be sustainable and developed.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. — By adopting the resolution on the review of tools in the CAP to support young farmers, the European Parliament has once again reaffirmed its strong commitment to renewing generations in agriculture and making it a modern and attractive sector for young people. Support for young farmers under the CAP should be maintained and strengthened in any subsequent policy reform to encourage young people to a career in agriculture. A strong CAP aimed at young farmers will also help address the main challenges of access to land and finance, reducing administrative barriers, additional training and developing business skills. Young farmers are easily embracing new technologies and are a bearer of innovation and entrepreneurship. The CAP should therefore encourage a new generation of young farmers who implement new end-user-based business models and develop smart solutions for sustainable and environmentally friendly farming practices. Generational renewal is also key to maintaining viable rural areas. The attraction of young people, respectively young farmers to rural areas, is linked to the availability of appropriate material, social and digital infrastructure, as well as providing conditions and standard of living similar to those in urban areas.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the Mechanism for Connecting Europe after 2020 (2018/2718 (RSP)).

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to exchange views with you on the European Parliament’s expectations concerning the Connecting Europe Facility after 2020. The Commission plans to adopt its proposal for the new self-regulation on 6 June. The MFF package adopted on 2 May already provides some key orientations concerning the possible design and priorities of the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF). We all have in mind the high investment needs in transport infrastructure in Europe for the period 2021-2027. We estimate that the TEN-T Core Network development alone will require EUR 350 billion of investments. In addition, we need to tackle much more decisively the challenge of decarbonisation and digitalisation of the transport sector. The cross-border dimension remains at the basis of the EU added value. However, efficient and interconnected mobility also needs to be smart, sustainable, inclusive, safe and secure. This is why I have proposed to modernise the Connecting European Facility. CEF is among the very few programmes for which a reinforced budget has been proposed by the Commission. The overall CEF budget proposal amounts to EUR 42.3 billion, of which EUR 30.6 billion would be dedicated to transport. Our proposal is thus to keep the current budget levels both for the general and for the cohesion envelope with 12.8 billion and 11.3 billion respectively. In addition, we propose to deploy a EUR 6.5 billion budget for transport infrastructure of dual use: civil and military. I would like to refer to six points raised in the Parliament draft resolution that I consider particularly important. First, on the priorities. I fully agree that it is important to strike the right balance between the development of new infrastructure and the modernisation of the existing infrastructure. On one side, I agree that focus should be maintained on the development of the network, with particular priority on cross-border sections and missing links of the Core Network Corridors. This is clearly where continuity has to be ensured in order to complete the big projects supported by the current programme. On the other hand, a much stronger and broader emphasis should be put on the modernisation of the existing infrastructure. We currently need to keep up the efforts as regards ERTMS and SESAR to complete the deployment, but digitalisation should also be supported further. We want to accompany the mobility transition towards connected, cooperative, automated and autonomous mobility, as well as modal integration and new mobility services. At the same time, we want to make our network safer, more secure and more resilient to climate change and natural disasters. For these topics, the geographical differentiation between the comprehensive and Core Network is not always relevant, so we are planning to propose to also cover the comprehensive network where relevant. But this can only be achieved by a team effort – which brings me to my second point, which is synergies between the transport, energy and digital sectors. For instance, on automated mobility we will open possibilities for these synergies. Importantly, while providing a framework that is as open as possible to synergies, we should re-establish a list of areas of topics. This should be done during implementation with sufficient flexibility. My third point concerns the cohesion envelope. Based on the first positive experience, the Commission has proposed to transfer from the Cohesion Funds an amount of EUR 11.2 billion to the CEF for implementation and direct management according to CEF rules. Of course the cohesion and co-funding rate would apply. However, we are considering a higher rate to apply to cross-border links. Fourth, I would like briefly to mention InvestEU and blending. In order to streamline the instruments, the Commission has proposed to merge most existing financial instruments into one single investment – InvestEU. It will have a specific window for infrastructure and it will complement the CEF, which in turn will no longer have specific financial instruments. As regards blending, we should keep the possibility to blend CEF grants with InvestEU, but also to use CEF grants in combination with non-EU financial instruments, for instance from commercial or national promotional banks. My fifth point focuses on the new component of CEF – military mobility. This is an important component of the new initiative proposed in the area of defence. The proposed budget of EUR 6.5 billion would be implemented through CEF to support civil transport infrastructure in order to adapt it to military mobility requirements. In other words, investments necessary for military mobility purposes will also have to be serving fully the needs of civilian mobility. And finally, my sixth point, on energy. The European Union’s climate commitments require an unprecedented level of investment in energy infrastructure which enables decarbonisation of energy systems. Electricity grids will need to undergo massive reinforcement. Grids will need to become even more digitalised and smarter, to allow for efficient demand management. Some gas grids may be transformed to carry synthetic gas, reduced with surpluses of renewable energy. Therefore, a targeted public financial assistance will continue to be required to deliver the necessary investments. This will be potentially important where the infrastructure includes significant positive externalities such as security of supply, solidarity or innovation. The CEF has a very important and growing role to play here, so an ambitious financial envelope is required, as well as support for synergy costs as I mentioned before, where transport, energy and/or digital can act together. Furthermore, CEF will be needed to support some more outstanding investments in projects to ensure energy security. So we are set for an ambitious but realistic future CEF, and I hope I can count on the support from you, the European Parliament, to move it forward.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for the information presented. It is clear that transport, energy and telecommunications infrastructures underpin economic development. The Connecting Facility for Europe now, in this financial year, has been highly appreciated by both the Member States and the Commission, which considered it a successful project. Important investments have been made in railways, in SESAR, in airports. That is why the amount allocated for this facility after 2021 is surprising, even though there is still some confusion in the figures presented, both by the difference between current prices and prices in real terms, and by putting together military infrastructure and financial instruments. I hope the regulations will clarify this. However, I want to remind you that in 2011 the Commission proposed EUR 50 billion for this facility. The amount now proposed is lower than that of 2011 and is lower than that of the current financial year, for transport in particular. For energy or made some improvements, and also for telecommunications. So, I think, you need to work until 6 June, when you said you were presenting the proposal to amend this amount in support of transport infrastructure.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (ES) Mr President, the truth is that, in this exercise, some of us would have preferred to be able to go together and not for Mr Marinescu to come out, let's say, alone. That is why we Socialists have preferred to go hand in hand with the Liberal Group and, of course, to invite the whole Parliament to finally have a position of strengthening and calling for a strong CEF for the next decade. The truth is that the previous one, of which we are in recent years, has been a success story at a time of clamorous lack of infrastructure investment in Europe for almost ten years. Precisely, the added value it has generated has been a great help to us. Also, thanks to the enormous energy of INEA, and you have to recognize it. However, for the next period we find that we have to be realistic. We find that there is, at the moment, a cut of 12% and 13%, something to be recognized and therefore the battle involves replenish it. Secondly, we would need urgent synergies between transport and energy, because clean cars are already leaving factories and buyers do not know what to do, where and how to manage them. Finally, we also need implementation in countries whose national programmes do not correspond to European commitments. That is also urgent.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! I am very pleased that you have recognised this Connecting Europe programme as very important. It was a fund that serves well for the integration and modernization of infrastructure in the European Union. The question about its future after 2020 is really a question about the future of trans-European networks and related regional projects. A key element of this endeavor — Europe's transport corridors — is still unfinished. It is necessary not only to fund this project in the next budget perspective, but also to increase investment expenditure, among other things, in the area of inland transport. There are also new challenges to which measures are needed: the real and not just the apparent transition to low-carbon transport, the development of autonomous mobility and the whole package of ambitious objectives the Commission sets itself in the third part of the mobility package. Connecting Europe (...) of the whole infrastructure investment finance architecture, which could be seriously compromised by drastic cuts in cohesion policy. The “Connecting Europe” instrument cannot fall victim to the same austerity policy. In other words: more money, Commissioner.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I am looking forward to negotiating the joint motion for a resolution with my colleagues tomorrow. I am sure that we are going to have a good paper and I hope that the Commission will take it seriously. You personally should take it as support for your efforts.  There will be a number of invitations, challenges and also negative signals. One has already been mentioned. CEF is a success story.
