We are doing very well and are oversubscribed, but if we look at the allocation of financial means, in constant prices we have 12 to 13, respectively, percent cuts. This is something that this House and the majorities in this House will not understand. Taking into account the question of assessment, where we could also do better from the side of the European coordinators is in really assessing the actual progress that is being made so that we can show it to our citizens. It is not a question of how much money has been allocated, but what the real result is. I will make three brief remarks. Firstly, regarding the complex relationship with Horizon 2020 or EFSI, this has to be our focus. Secondly, yes to blending. I think we have got some positive results. Let’s work on it with public money. Thirdly, I think that we need to understand that there is basically an excess of everything, that is: use it or lose it. That is the reason why this programme has been successful.  My apologies for going over my allocated time.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, if the Connecting Europe programme is properly used, it can really help to create the necessary energy and transport infrastructure that is vital to the people of Europe. It is therefore necessary to stop the cuts and to stop allocating part of the envelope to the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which, instead of promoting projects in the public interest, invests where it is in the interests of private investors. The most important thing, however, is that this programme should not be used to further militarise the Union by financing transport infrastructure to improve military mobility, as the Commission has announced. The aim must be to promote projects that society really needs, which will contribute to strengthening regional cohesion, long-term growth and the creation of quality new jobs, while at the same time fulfilling all environmental rules. An important priority is to promote projects to remove the isolation to which certain states and regions in the Union are condemned.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: Mr President, this evening we are dealing with a very successful programme. The so-called CEF programme is not only about transport, but also about energy and telecom. I think we have shown over the past few years that this is one of the best investment programmes in the European Union. This is not about subsidies or transfer expenditure, but rather about good investment in the future of the same European Union. This debate tonight, Mr President, is intended to give Commissioner Bulc the last push to keep that CEF programme alive and to extend what my colleague Marinescu said if possible. This is really about the future of the EU, and it is more than worthwhile to hold a debate at this late hour this evening.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: Mr President, Dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a speech on the funds allocated to the mechanism for connecting Europe can only be made in the long term. In fact, we know that when we talk about infrastructure projects, the resources needed are large and the appropriations need unexceptionable planning. For this reason, I believe that the CEF's endowment should not only be restored, but must be implemented in order to conclude at least the projects of the core network of TEN-T. It then needs a net change after the cuts that have been made to fund EFSI. I am of the idea that European unification is also a physical factor, and never as at this moment do we need a network to ensure development, growth and territorial connectivity even in the areas remote. And finally, Europe must maintain, I say, control not only over the corridors but over the entire logistics network in general.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the resolution proposed by Mr Marinescu on the CEF is really aimed at achieving one of the absolute priorities of the European Union: to ensure connectivity and ensure innovation. The CEF's merit in these seven years has been to ensure, in addition to enormous firepower on infrastructure investments, to ensure precisely a space for innovation within the C- ITS, alternative fuels, all that space we need even for the challenge of digitisation and decarbonization. So a complete and successful plan. So you don't justify resource cuts, but I add an element. The element concerns not only the amount of resources, but the type of structure of the mechanism, because that also worked and it is useful to maintain it. So lost funding and an independent management board. These aspects of method will also have to be the subject of our attention.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, transport infrastructure is a fundamental element of European Union action and one of the most visible ones. The Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) has a high European added value: infrastructure investments improve competitiveness; strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion; enable connectivity and access to the internal market in the most peripheral regions; they are an engine of growth. Therefore, the CEF needs to be strengthened in the field of transport in order to complete the basic network by 2030. I would particularly like to stress the need to increase the connectivity of the regions and ports of the Atlantic facade of the European Union. To this end, it is essential to incorporate new sections into the Atlantic corridor of the CEF. I therefore ask you, Commissioner, to include in the review of the CEF that you are carrying out these days, the amendments to the Atlantic corridor submitted by the Government of Spain and which affect the northwest of the Iberian peninsula. Finally, I hope that the CEF budget will be able to meet the needs of this very important initiative.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: — Mr President, the Connecting Europe mechanism after 2020 is indeed important. But first of all, it requires funds. That is why there should be no reduction in funds. The emphasis must be placed on connectivity and innovation. At the same time, however, there must be aid for the countries and regions which are isolated. This applies, in particular, to Greece, which is at the utmost point of the European Union, but also to the Aegean islands, which have been literally cut off. In this context, the so-called transport equivalent must be regulated and operational actions and actions for the transport equivalent should be financed through the Regional Development Programme. At the same time, I agree with the emphasis on new infrastructure or the modernisation of the infrastructure that exists at the moment.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, we could call the 'Connect Europe' Facility 'the Fund for futile and imposed infrastructure', and I explain why. Over the past four years, this Facility has allocated EUR 1.2 billion to fossil gas pollutant infrastructure. In addition, the largest investment will go to electricity interconnection between Spain and France in the Gulf of Bizkaia, and it should be stressed that this interconnection has received EUR 578 million, but, on the part of the public, it has received 6,800 allegations against it. In Gatika and Bizkaia numerous groups are organizing against him. And reasons are not lacking. Interconnection has a high risk of overcosts that people and businesses will pay: according to a report from the regulators themselves, with all infrastructures planned the rates will increase by 3.5%. Interconnection will not at all help renewables: for example, with the entry of interconnection through Catalonia, restrictions on wind farms were multiplied by six. If you really want to help the entry of renewables, consider the end of coal and nuclear energy.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I believe that we do not need a budget to advertise the European Union. It is enough to promote the results that the Connecting Europe Facility is producing, because on our European roads there is more politics than tarmac, I believe. We all agree here that the biggest cause of car accidents is bottlenecks, and at the same time, the best tool we can provide to solve bottlenecks is the Connecting Europe Facility. We all agree here that we have to complete the trans-European transport (TEN-T) core network. We all agree that we need half a trillion to complete that network, and still we do not provide a sufficient budget for the Connecting Europe Facility. I think we should do better than this. Although at the moment we have to agree that the progress made in the Connecting Europe Facility is significant, I believe we should create additional tools of influence to the Member States in order to push them to make it possible to complete the TEN-T network as soon as possible.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the Commission is continuing its strategy of gilding the policy pill it proposes. There are adjectives left, but practice does not accompany your speech. Instruments such as the Connecting Europe Facility or the so-called trans-European transport network have served as an ice cream for public money for the private sector or fuelled the harmful public-private partnerships, political strategies that have promoted the privatisation of public service supply, divestment in equipment and infrastructure, the degradation and the increased service provided to the populations, the precariousness of labour relations. The Commissioner spoke of a financial package that enables decisive responses to the development of the sector. Sprey promises, when we know the budget axe that the Commission is preparing for the next MFF, particularly with regard to cohesion, which, we have known for a long time, has never been the real objective of the European Union. It is necessary to increase cohesion funds free of conditionalities, allowing countries like Portugal to strong public investment in the sector, policies and public responses that serve the needs of the population and the country's development.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this debate, which demonstrates again the positive aspects of the current Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) and the common willingness to reinforce the instrument after 2020, both in terms of budget and priorities. The period after 2020 will be crucial to ensure the successful delivery of the TEN-T core network within the given deadline by 2030. Various improvements to CEF 2.0 will significantly contribute to achieving these goals. I have, in particular, taken note of your interests, priorities and synergies concerning the support for infrastructure projects. Let me elaborate on some of your comments. First, regarding the CEF budget. The Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) proposal incorporates an ambitious proposal for the future of CEF, which is among the very few programmes with a reinforced budget, amounting to a total of EUR 30.6 billion for 2021-2027, circa 20% more compared to the current period 2014-2020. Not only has the MFF proposal preserved existing elements of CEF in the general and cohesion envelope; the CEF has been further reinforced with a new pillar of military mobility. During the difficult times surrounding the withdrawal of the UK, this is an impressive achievement, showing that the CEF has been recognised by the Commission as an effective instrument, adding real value to the European single market. Let me stress here again that all the money allocated to military mobility is allocated to dual use; all the infrastructure is civil infrastructure used for civil purposes and then reinforced also for military mobility. On synergies: synergies between transport, energy and the digital sector will be implemented through a joint work programme, jointly financed and with the possibility to apply to the highest co-funding rate in the sector concerned. We are yet to define clear criteria under which the synergies will be taking place. Again, let me stress that the ‘use it or lose it’ principle will remain part of CEF. This was one of the most successful principles. It allowed us such a high level of delivery that, already in the first three years of this Commission, our deployment achieved more than 90%. One last comment regarding the priority projects that was raised by a respectful Member. Let me say that many of the Member States proposed new sections. We could not take all on board, but many of them will be taken on board, only of course those that were aligned with the Annex of the Regulation. Finally, thank you very much again for allowing me to introduce the initial structure of our proposal that is coming in the first week of June. Thank you very much also for your support. I will ask you to continue to demonstrate it, and I really look forward to continuing discussing it in the coming months, in close coordination with my colleagues in charge of the energy and digital sectors, to allow swift progress on this very important file.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 31 May 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – The development of transport infrastructure is currently fragmented across the European Union with repercussions on territorial cohesion and economic growth. Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) is one of the main instruments that aims to address this shortage by focusing on facilitating cross-border connections, leveraging funding from both the public and the private sectors. CEF Transport triggered successfully already EUR 41.6 billion of total investments by 2017 and statistics indicates that every billion euros invested in the TEN-T core network creates up to 20 000 new jobs. Therefore, the instrument brings a massive EU value added, enhancing cohesion, long-term sustainable growth and economic competitiveness. It also contributes considerably to the EU’s achievement of decarbonizing its economy in the context of the Paris Agreement. I stress the importance that Member States and the European Commission remain committed to the CEF’s main policy objectives, especially with regards to completing the TEN-T core network and the European Rail Traffic Management Systems (ERTMS). Lastly, in the context of the next Multi-annual Financial Framework 2021-2017, I underline the importance of ensuring proper investments for digital and innovative transport projects and further reinforce CEF instrument by ensuring complementarity with other programs such as the InvestEU Fund or Horizon Europe.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the following reports: report by Pavel Svoboda and Richard Corbett, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the interpretation and application of the Interinstitutional Agreement 'Better legislation' (2016/2018 (INI)) (A8-0170/2018).

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, the report on the interpretation and implementation of the Interinstitutional Agreement on improving lawmaking follows the work of the Working Group formed from the members of the Committee for Legal Affairs and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, so let me first thank all the colleagues who participated in the activities of this Working Group. Similarly, I would like to thank my co-rapporteur Richard Corbett for the excellent cooperation. Of course, our task is to evaluate the interpretation and implementation of the agreement, which came into force in April 2016. In general, it can be concluded that the existing application of the Agreement is satisfactory and in principle the Agreement fulfills its purpose. I believe that there has been goodwill for all institutions to fulfil the purpose of the agreement from the outset, and I believe that will continue to be the case. This is an interinstitutional agreement, which is why our assessment has included efforts to preserve and strengthen the elements of cooperation in which the European Parliament can contribute its expertise. One such theme is adherence to the correct legal basis. Unjustified changes in the legal basis are, of course, unacceptable to the European Parliament. On this interinstitutional level, I would also like to mention the question of the participation of representatives of the European Parliament in the deliberations of the Council working groups, also as an example of some disproportion, which still is in the field of awareness of the Council's deliberations, compared to the awareness of the deliberations of the European Parliament and its institutions. I think that in the long run, eliminating such disproportion would be of benefit. However, it should be emphasised that the report does not only cover institutional matters. First of all, they evaluate how much we have managed to fulfill the basic purpose of the agreement, which is to try to improve the adoption of legislation. I would like to mention here a few elements of the legislative process that are mentioned in the report and can illustrate how the principles of better law making — improving the creation of legislation. For example, we think that the European Commission should clearly state the legal nature of each proposal within its work programme and supplement it with a clear and realistic timetable. This, too, would contribute to better clarity of the European Union in its citizens. One of the basic things is a quality impact assessment of the proposed legislation. Personally, I have always supported the maximum possible consideration of the impact on small and medium-sized enterprises, which I do not see as favouring them over other entities or employees, but as taking into account reality. And the reality is that small and medium-sized enterprises are quite fundamental to the European economy. The big theme is gold plating. I consider it obvious that we need to demand in the future that, in the framework of the implementation of Union regulations, it is recognisable what is still a Union regulation and what is already a national initiative that introduces obligations beyond those adopted at Union level. That's what a regular citizen practically has no chance of finding out today. The European Union is a community of law, so it must take care that its law constitutes truly modern, effective, lucid and understandable standards.

name: Richard Corbett
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank my co-rapporteur. This was very much a team effort, not just between two co-rapporteurs but between two committees and indeed among multiple political groups. Our task, of course, was to assess the implementation of this important interinstitutional agreement that we made with the Commission and the Council two years ago and, overall, our assessment is a positive one, even if there are still two strands being negotiated on international agreements and on the delimitation between implementing acts and delegated acts – they will come back to this Parliament – but what has been agreed so far has, on the whole, been well implemented.  We have moved to having greater transparency in the legislative process. We have moved towards having better legislative planning. We have moved to improve our legislative procedures. We have improved the consultation of stakeholders and we have looked at and improved the process of impact assessments, which are very important. All this, of course, is a question of getting the right balance and take impact assessments and the whole issue of what we are trying to do with them. Yes, we want to be better informed about the potential impacts of laws that we adopt in this Parliament on those who will be affected by them. Absolutely right. But it’s not just how laws affect small and medium-sized enterprises as some campaigners seem to sometimes imply, it is about how the legislation affects other stakeholders – consumers, workers, third parties, government finances, the environment. It’s a question of getting all of these things in balance.  Secondly, this is not about deregulation, it’s about better regulation. When we adopt legislation it is usually for good reason and especially at European level. If we adopt legislation at European level, it is not, as some in the media sometimes portray, the European Commission spewing out regulations on hapless Member States who don’t even know that it’s being inflicted upon them. No, there is a high threshold to adopt legislation at European level. It needs the approval of this Parliament and of the Council, the Council composed of national ministers, members of national governments, accountable to their national parliaments, who need the high threshold of a qualified majority representing 65% of the population to approve anything. So the idea that we inflict legislation on hapless Member States is nonsense. We only legislate at European level where there is a high degree of consensus that it is advantageous to do so. That is an important political safeguard and I would remind those people, usually sat over there, but I see none of them are here tonight, those people who claim that the EU inflicts all this red tape and bureaucracy on small and medium-sized enterprises.  I’d add one further thing. When we get it right, European legislation is an exercise in cutting red tape for businesses, because having one set of rules instead of 28 different, divergent set of rules in a single market, makes things simpler for businesses. They don’t have to adapt to every single segment of the market, adapting their product, changing it, changing the labelling, changing the marketing everywhere. They have life simplified when we get European legislation right. So it is not about deregulating it’s about regulating better. At the moment we see actually an example of a Member State, my own country, beginning to discover the multiple problems that arise if you begin, as it intends to do, to diverge and its regulations from the rest of its main market, all the multiple extra costs that will arise, all the extra difficulties, all the economic problems that will ensue.  I leave you with that final thought.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, one thing that I would like to highlight, to continue what Mr Corbett has already said, is that the impact assessment needs to be developed further. This is not a question of deregulation, but of a better and adaptive regulation. Issues that are still lacking with regard to the impact assessment include a better understanding of the impact on citizens, especially on gender, which was agreed in the Beijing Declaration but is still not in the majority of the legislative action budgets. As we are discussing sustainable finance next, what would be crucial is to add the cost of not acting and not regulating. Quite often in environmental and climate cases, people do see the cost if you have to invest or regulate or de-invest, let us say, away from diesel cars. But, then again, there is no comparison with what the huge cost of climate change will be if we do not act, and I hope this can be added in the future.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR).
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the co-rapporteurs for their work on this file. As the Employment Committee’s draftsman, I welcome the fact that several of our proposals have been taken on board, but I want to talk about the annual burden survey (ABS), which I think is one of the most innovative elements of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making (IIA).  In its first annual burden survey, the Commission undertook a survey of businesses’ perceptions of regulation. I am sure that was worthwhile but we must be much more ambitious in implementing the annual burden survey. The point is, we may create a simple piece of legislation at EU level, easy for businesses and others to understand and comply with, but when it is transposed into international legislation it does not always stay like that: additional, or completely unrelated, elements are added to the legislation. The ABS should identify these cases of gold-plating. Member States must always be free to adopt higher standards where only minimum standards are defined in Union law. That is not gold-plating. By using the ABS to bring transparency to the legislative process, we can ensure that legislation remains simple, clear and enforceable and we can make sure that Europe is not blamed for unpopular legislation that has, in fact, been created by Member States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, in the interinstitutional agreement on better law-making, said competitiveness becomes the first and absolute criterion in determining the timeliness and content of European Union legislation. Nothing new, just the assumption of a long-adopted principle, now stripped of any social or environmental rhetoric. It is not the interests of SMEs what we want to defend, but the interests of big business, the major economic groups and the main European powers. As expected, impact assessments have been and are subverted and underestimated. More serious limitations on the democraticity of the open legislative and decision-making process, which was the door to a greater concentration of power in the European Commission and to the limitation of the legislative capacity of legislators, especially Members, are confirmed. Look at the perverse amendments to the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure which limit Members' ability to speak. The transparency of the legislative process has also been diminished, as should be. Because it is in the shadow that factic powers assert themselves and it is to them that this agreement is used, it is for them that we want to legislate better.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, this February the General Court of the European Union in its decision De Capitani v European Parliament ruled that for democratic legitimacy, co-legislators – that is Parliament and the Council – must be held accountable for their actions to the public. Citizens cannot, according to the General Court, exercise their democratic rights if they are not in a position to even follow the legislative procedures and have access to relevant information, and the Court ruled that this also goes for the trilogue documents, including the four column documents on request.  The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union obliges us to work as openly as possible. If we fail to agree to fulfil our transparency obligations to the citizens, we run the risk that the European Court of Justice will once again condemn us. Let’s not make it happen. And on Wednesday we should all support the report by Mr Svoboda and Mr Corbett, and hopefully we can include an oral amendment about the importance of the implementation of the De Capitani v European Parliament judgment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the report by colleagues on the interinstitutional agreement on improving legislative work seems to me to be of particular interest. Of course, we should bear in mind that legislation must serve citizens and not, of course, the various centres of power. At the same time, it should be legislation that reinforces democratic control, and that is why there should be an enforcement of transparency at the same time. We also need to make use of the citizens' initiative, which also raise issues on which legislative initiative should be taken by the European Union. The legal basis to be chosen is certainly a serious issue. I think that there are issues that need to be addressed, such as impact assessment, intervention by the European Parliament in matters of international agreements and also Parliament's intervention in matters relating to delegated acts.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission is pleased to see the continuing interest in the better law-making agreement and welcomes the report prepared by Mr Richard Corbett and Mr Pavel Svoboda. It raises some important issues and will deepen further our interinstitutional cooperation.  In its short lifetime, the agreement has delivered some real improvements in how the institutions work together, as mentioned by Mr Corbett, for example the Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities and the new interinstitutional register for delegated acts. We are also still busy working together on various follow-up actions such as the criteria to distinguish delegated acts from implementing acts, as mentioned already, the traceability of the legislative procedure through joined databases and the cooperation and information sharing on international agreements, as already pointed out. I hope this will also come to fruitful completion this year.  The report contains several criticisms, many of them aimed primarily at the Council. But, as you know, our agreement contains a monitoring mechanism to which the three institutions are committed. These issues will be for our next three-part, detailed stocktaking meeting, the first of which took place last December in Strasbourg and which already addressed some of the issues.  We should also recall that the agreement was a delicate compromise between the three institutions and it is important to bear this in mind as we identify how to follow up on issues where Parliament now calls for more ambition. A number of issues have indeed already been addressed. To improve transparency and predictability since 2017 the Commission Work Programme provides further information as far as available on the initiatives in its work programme. This information includes indications on the type of act, planned adoption, legal basis and whether an impact assessment will be carried out.  As a general rule, the Commission is committed to present an impact assessment in support of its legislative proposals and I can assure you that when an impact assessment is necessary, we do it. There were, of course, a limited number of cases where, typically for reasons of political urgency, we have not been able to. When this is the case, we explain the reasons why. Your resolution states that the Commission should complement its original impact assessment when deemed necessary. I want to underline that it is not an obligation, but a possibility. The Commission will launch a stocktaking of its better regulation tools in the course of this year, and this will include the regulatory scrutiny board. This will be accompanied by various consultation activities and we will, of course, be in touch with Parliament to hear your views. We intend to publish a report with findings in the first half of 2019.  Also, as stipulated by the interinstitutional agreement, I encourage Parliament to pursue the endeavours in their own impact assessment work related to the substantial amendments. The first best is that Parliament and the Council, in line with the commitments, assess their own amendments. The Commission may do this for them if it considers this appropriate. We assess in the impact assessment what kind of policy instruments we need for a specific initiative. We have to look at all the possible options and we have specific guidance for that in our better regulation toolbox. Sometimes soft law is just better to achieve the desired policy objective because it is more proportionate and better respects the principles of subsidiarity.  Let me use this opportunity to clarify that all responses to Parliament’s resolution are endorsed by the College and hence are political in nature. They constitute a particular form of communication to Parliament. Own-initiative legislative resolutions receive a specific attention. As foreseen in the Treaty, if the Commission does not submit a proposal, it always informs Parliament of the reasons for such a choice.  I would like to thank the rapporteurs again for their comprehensive work and to state that the Commission is ready to engage collectively with Parliament and the Council to give even greater effect to the agreement in our regular meetings.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 30 May 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — I appreciate the visible progress we have made in the creation of Union legislation through this interinstitutional agreement. I see positively mainly provisions that contribute to increased transparency, such as the establishment of a database for delegated acts. I also welcome that the report highlights the so-called gold plating. The fact that a Member State will implement Union legislation more broadly than necessary into its legal order is not negative in itself. Member States may, for example, provide citizens with an even higher standard of protection. But not always wider national arrangements by citizens are welcome, and the problem is that citizens cannot distinguish between which changes in the new law are brought by the EU and which state. Gold plating is fuelling Euroscepticism in such situations and is partly to reinforce populist sentiment in the EU. Therefore, I consider it extremely important that the Commission monitor that Member States actually make a clear distinction in transposing directives or adopting adaptation laws Union legislation and which go beyond its scope. We need to establish a practice that allows us to lead citizens out of the notion that “the EU is responsible for everything.”

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the brief presentation of Molly Scott Cato's report, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on sustainable finance (2018/2007 (INI)) (A8-0164/2018).

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I must begin my remarks by thanking my colleagues for their engagement and for the way they entered thoroughly into the spirit of compromise that has enabled us to have such a positive and wide-ranging report to vote on tomorrow.  As a former professor of green economics, I am delighted to see that this agenda now has almost universal support, not only in Parliament, but also from the Commission, who have made this a priority agenda, as well as from world leaders, especially President Macron of France. This indicates that the sustainable finance agenda has moved beyond the realm of partisan discussion. It is not the property of any political faction. It also shows that protecting the health and vitality of the planet we depend on is a cause that transcends normal political differences. While we may continue to debate about how banks should be regulated and what is the appropriate level of profits for enterprises, there is no longer any argument about the fact that we need to embark urgently on a transition to a sustainable economy and that finance offers a powerful tool to accelerate that transition. The urgent need to respond to the threat from climate change has led to innovation in the field of sustainable finance in different EU Member States: the French law of disclosure, German leadership in the field of public investment in the energy transition, the Bank of England’s timely action in encompassing the threat of financial stability from stranded assets, the Swedish FSA’s ambitious agenda to integrate sustainability into its daily work, and the consideration of the threat to pensions and insurance from the tragedy of horizons by the Netherlands. The aim of the European Parliament should be to encourage a race to the top on sustainable development, to take the best from this innovation across our Union and to combine it into minimum standards for all, guiding investment to ensure a just and rapid transition towards a sustainable economy and society. The sustainability transition is, as its name suggests, a dynamic environment. This is true of the hugely exciting technological innovation as engineers and designers respond to the sustainability imperative, and so it needs to be in terms of how we define and measure sustainability.  This is why our report takes a different stance from the somewhat static taxonomy proposed by the Commission. Our proposal would be for something that time limits the value of different assets, based on their sustainability potential measured by already existing indicators. This would allow investors to shift their asset holdings gradually through time and would enable an orderly transition away from unsustainable investments. The systemic risk posed by stranded carbon assets could thus be avoided, an important first step towards sustainable finance, but we also need to eliminate other stranded assets from investment portfolios. My report recommends extending the stranded assets concept to include fundamental ecological systems and services, so if an investment in intensive agriculture causes soil loss or the death of pollinators, it too should be considered a stranded asset.  When it comes to sustainable finance, my report makes clear that we look to our own institutions, particularly the ECB and the European Investment Bank, to set an example and to rise to the challenge of the Paris Agreement. This must mean an end to any investment that locks us into fossil fuel infrastructure and the inclusion of ESG (environmental, social and governance) goals in the ECB’s investment policy.  We welcome the excellent work of the Commission’s Expert Group on Sustainable Finance and applaud its level of ambition. Our report lends political support to their recommendations and we seek to convey to the Commission and Council our firm belief that the citizens of the EU look to them to show global leadership on this agenda.   Finally, but crucially, we need to hold the line as politicians as those who will lose value as we move towards sustainability seek to undermine our resolve. Oil will always be able to move vehicles and coal will always be able to drive turbines. For this reason we, the politicians, are deciding that these fossil fuels will lose their value – because the survival of our planet depends upon it. Future generations require us to stand firm and united to ensure that we use the power of finance to protect their future.  (Applause)

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the question of sustainable finance is not the cherries on top of the cake. It is not primarily having 8% or 10% of the financial resources geared to green bonds and green investment. I dare say that this is the biggest change in financial markets since the application of general accounting and auditing principles, and indeed the auditing should take place in integrated reporting based on those indicators that go in parallel with financial reporting, having all the major environmental impacts taken into account. As our rapporteur has already mentioned, those kinds of indicators do exist, and it is only a question of putting them in place. It is a question of having a review of financial regulation and the pervasive incentives sometimes, be it in fiduciary duty of investors, be it MiFIDs, be it the duty for credit raters to grade the environmental risks and in Basel for the banks to reserve higher capital buffers for environmentally-risky investments. To conclude, I would just like to thank my colleagues for their excellent work. I think that this is the first step, and I hope the Commission will have the courage to follow these guidelines.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur. We must build a financing system that works for people and planet and not just for the market players. Sustainability, responsibility and ethics should be at the core of our finances, as should all EU policies and actions, in line with the sustainable development goals. I therefore welcome the focus of this report on green finances and the call to encourage the financing of projects which contribute to the fight against climate change. I also want to highlight the key role of collaborative economy actors such as cooperatives and social businesses, which are particularly important for women. These alternative economic models must be able to access finances in order to contribute fully to the economic development of our countries and our communities. We should not simply talk about entrepreneurship but always about social enterprise, if we want to build a fairer world.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, sustainable funding is, of course, crucial for environmental protection. For this reason, there must be support for green funding. Of course, we need to revise the conditions under which this funding takes place, the planning itself. Allow me, however, to raise a serious issue relating to the famous quantitative relaxation, from which Greece has been completely excluded. All other countries participate except Greece. At the same time, the Bank of Greece, as part of the Eurosystem, participates in quantitative relaxation and buys bonds from foreign companies, non-Greek, and has spent 42 billion euros in 2015 and 2016. Do you see that reasonable? Should the Bank of Greece invest in bonds of non-Greek companies and, at the same time, Greece be out of quantitative relaxation? Can this process proceed like this?

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, there can be no sustainable finance unless there is transparency of the supply chains of the companies and here, one of the very interesting actions in the action plan on sustainable finance was to assess the need for due diligence reporting. This report of Molly Scott Cato shows that we are getting closer to a tipping point and the time has indeed come for a mandatory due diligence legislation at the European level. That legislation would finally give all companies a level playing field. It would make sure that good companies are rewarded for their actions, and that the unsustainable ones cannot just escape their responsibilities as they do now. Indeed, sustainable finance and responsible business conduct are possible, but if we want it, we just need to make decisions that are ambitious enough and we have no time to waste.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: Mr President, 180 billion a year is needed for the transition to a sustainable economy. Yeah, that's a lot of money, but that money's there, only in the wrong place. One million loans banks to the fossil sector, apart from the many billions that disappear into the arms industry, land robbery and other practices. It must be durable. That is not possible with quarterly capitalism, where only profit counts in the next quarter, and banks and other financial institutions do not look beyond their noses. It has to be different and it can be different, by radically improving the rules of the game, by rewarding good behaviour and punishing bad behaviour, and by giving clear responsibility to traders, investors and banks. I therefore hope that the Commission and the Member States will accept the recommendations contained in the report. Then we will have the 180 billion together, and we will avoid having another experience of the 2008 crisis in a slightly different way. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation and for this fine report.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, thank you to Molly Scott Cato. The environmental, climate and biodiversity challenges we are facing are so momentous and radical that we do, indeed, need the race to the top that you are talking about. It is a basic experience of human civilization that, at times, without radical innovation there is no survival. Today is such a time. We need social and political creativity and we must battle firmly against old thinking and old habits that tend to block the emergence of new perspectives. This is why we pursue carbon divestment together with promoting green finance. While we cherish Molly’s report and applaud the work of the Commission, we also cherish the fact that a green finance leadership programme is presently being set up in China, led by academics from Tsinghua University. This is the kind of competition that we should all savour. On this front, Europe has an obligation to the whole world and in particular to future generations. Let us not fall short.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur. I would like to sincerely congratulate you, together with the shadow rapporteurs, on this report. I would like to stress, as a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, that sustainable funding is not just about economic issues, but about the quality of prosperity of the whole of the European Union, and by extension, of humanity. Environment, green economy, climate change. I'm staying at the last, climate change. Their terrible effects can only be effectively addressed through long-term planning. Unfortunately, a great truth has been said: the economy as it is, cannot be left free to function and ensure that the quality of prosperity is done in the right way. This requires adjustment through our own design. Congratulations again!

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Scott Cato, for taking the initiative to present this report. I welcome the support that the report gives to the work on sustainable finance. I also welcome the large consensus among political groups on the best way forward. This is encouraging in view of our future work and discussions on the legislative proposals on sustainable finance that the Commission presented last week. These proposals already address some of your concerns. First, we will start the process of designing an EU classification system for sustainable economic activities which can inform future EU standards and labels for green financial products such as green bonds or investment funds. We are looking forward to the European Parliament support on this important proposal. Second, for those who manage investments on behalf of others, we propose to clarify that their duty towards their clients includes the systemic incorporation of sustainability risks into their investment processes. They will also have to disclose how they take this risk into account and what impact they expect these risks to have on returns. In addition, for investment products that actively pursue sustainable objectives, the way these objectives are incorporated into investment decisions would also need to be disclosed. Third, we propose to create a new category of benchmarks consisting of two specific types of benchmarks: low carbon benchmarks and positive carbon impact benchmarks. We also propose to establish minimum standards for the methodology of these benchmarks. This will increase transparency towards investors on how these benchmarks select and weigh their underlying assets and measure their carbon footprint. In addition, providers of low carbon benchmarks will have to disclose how their methodology takes into account the ESG factors. Finally, we propose that investment firms and insurance distributors consider the sustainability preferences of retail investors when giving investment advice. In the coming weeks we will establish a technical expert group (we’re going to call it TEG) that will further work on developing an EU classification for sustainable activities or taxonomy standards for green bonds and sustainable matrix. These are the first steps towards a more sustainable financial system. There is still some work ahead to address other concerns stated in your own initiative report. For instance, the Commission is evaluating the mandatory reporting requirements to make sure they provided the right information to market participants, enabling them to assess companies’ long-term value creation and their sustainability-risk management. Of course, further clarification of the role of European supervisory authorities in this process is really important. Let me conclude by stressing again my appreciation of the work of the European Parliament in this field. Now we count on you to move as fast as possible in the coming months to adopt these measures that will encourage sustainable and green investments in Europe.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow 29 May 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — According to the report, European investors must increase their investment in environmentally friendly technologies in order to achieve internationally agreed climate targets. The Commission estimates that the Sustainable Development Goals will require annual investments in sustainable infrastructure of between €4.7 and 6.7 trillion. Currently, investing in environmentally friendly technologies is not very profitable and rather risky. According to the report, investors underestimate the wage and social advantage of a decarbonised, green and sustainable economy. The report calls on the EU to learn from 'best practices' such as the German energy transition and to make them minimum standards for all Member States to direct investment and to ensure a fair and rapid transition to a sustainable economy. Investment incentives include market mechanisms such as the disclosure of climate risks, but also strong public investment and the issuance of green bonds. Although I fully support an investment boost for a greener and more sustainable economy, I think it is rather risky to interfere politically in forecasts of the creditworthiness and profitability of green investment opportunities. Such interventionist measures are vulnerable to market bubbles. I fully share the warnings of Dr. Elke König, Chair of the Systemic Risk Boards, who says that sustainable does not necessarily mean risk-free.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report by Jytte Guteland, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the EU Justice Scoreboard 2017 (2018/2009 (INI)) (A8-0161/2018).

name: Jytte Guteland
text: rapporteur. — Mr President! I would like to begin by thanking the shadow rapporteur for very good cooperation. This is Parliament's response to the Commission scoreboard for 2017, and this scoreboard is made every year since five years back. It is a comparative overview of the effectiveness, quality and independence of the legal systems of the Member States. In relation to previous years, in 2017, the Commission raised new aspects about the functioning of the legal system, such as how consumers can access justice and the length of Member States' criminal proceedings in money laundering. It is very good that it has come along, but we believe further improvements could be made so that the scoreboard becomes even more relevant. For example, we address in our report that an independent judiciary is the basis of a democracy, and in order to ensure this, legal systems must be free of pressure, both political and economic. We stress the importance of independent prosecutorial authorities and urge the Commission to produce reports to strengthen the position of prosecutors. This I think is very important. We also regret that there is still a lack of data in certain categories and we urge Member States to make more effort to provide comparable data. We call on the Commission to develop new criteria to better evaluate whether legal systems are in line with EU rule of law. Here I have suggested, among other things, that we should take on the Venice Commission's list of rule of law criteria. We also stress the importance of strengthening citizens' access to justice and legal aid. Information tools are needed so that people with disabilities, national minorities and migrants have better accessibility. We also regret that the scoreboard showed that the proportion of female judges in some Member States has decreased compared to previous years. Member States need targeted measures to improve outcomes. Better equality work is also needed in the justice system. It is an important basis for efficiency and independent legal systems and so we propose increased educational interventions, including which judges should be offered, such as education on norms and stereotypes. For me as rapporteur, it has also been important to broaden the scoreboard for the types of litigation processes the comparison refers to. And I am pleased that we call on the Commission to produce in future scoreboards a new indicator to monitor more carefully access to justice for discriminated groups. We also want the Commission to produce a new indicator of information on national procedures in respect of collective trials in the face of next year's comparison. The possibility of class-action is increasingly important in strengthening the protection of consumers, the environment and public health across the EU. The wide-ranging diesel-street scandal, for example, testifies to the right to claim compensation for improper business practices. It demonstrates the need to facilitate the status of citizens to judicial review and effective dispute resolution. Therefore, it would be reasonable and timely to look at this too in next year's scoreboard. Finally, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs once again for their excellent cooperation. We would so clearly urge the Commission to take on our recommendations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the independence of justice in the Member States is certainly of fundamental importance. However, in Greece in particular, the independence of the judiciary is under attack. At the moment, there is a regulation in the memorandum that says that, if a court order is issued that cancels the budgetary measures imposed by the memorandum, then the government must proceed with new fiscal measures having equivalent effect. In other words, the troika itself imposes, through the memoranda, the failure to respect the decisions of the Greek justice system. Secondly, the recent resignation of the President of the Council of State in Greece is a serious sign that the institution of independence of justice in Greece is now shaking. The report ought to look at how the troika works and how, in essence, it dissolves any sense of independence of justice in the Member States under the troika.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I want to thank our rapporteur, Ms Guteland, for her report and for the excellent cooperation through which this report was produced. This report asks the Commission to add collective redress procedures to next year’s comparative exercise because it is a major legal tool in strengthening consumer, environmental and health protection in the European Union.  I am very happy to see that the Commission shares this view as it published a legislative proposal on this matter while we were working on this report. The legislative proposal by the Commission on collective redress does not, however, make the call in this report redundant. On the contrary: collective redress could provide efficient dispute resolution and the means to eliminate unreasonable barriers to access to justice in cross—border cases. The Commission should also examine how the collective redress could be used in cases where companies or other organisations have committed or contributed to human rights violations in third countries outside European borders. Often, due to legal technicalities or underdeveloped legislation, there may be no effective ways for access to justice and remedy at all.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on their report, but I would like to make two specific remarks. The first concerns the fact that, unfortunately, there is no homogeneity in the application of European legislation, and in particular the guidelines by the European Court of Justice. And I refer in particular, because I have a personal view, to decisions concerning the banking sector. It is a huge issue that we need to reconsider, because the heterogeneity in the implementation of these decisions also affects the concept of the administration of justice, but also affects many other issues, such as unfair competition, for example. The second point, and I shall conclude, is that I believe that there should be even one proposal in the report stating that in the northern occupied part of Cyprus, which is part of the European Union, the rule of law is unfortunately not applied because the Turkish army prevents it.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Guteland, and the Parliament very much for their work on this file. We share the same commitment and interest to strengthen the independence and effectiveness of judicial systems in our Member States. These are essential for economic development, social peace and a secure Europe. The 2018 Justice Scoreboard was adopted by the Commission today. I am glad that your report takes into account many of its elements. It is important to remember that the Scoreboard is a tool which is being continuously improved, and your recommendations will be considered for the future as well. Your report calls for the expansion of the EU Justice Scoreboard into the field of criminal justice. The 2018 Scoreboard expanded the coverage of money laundering and now shows, for nearly all countries, the length of court proceedings in money laundering cases. It shows that, while in about half of Member States the first instance court proceedings take up to a year on average, these proceedings take around two years on average in several Member States.  You call for covering the status of public prosecutors and their autonomy. I am pleased to say that the 2018 Scoreboard shows for the first time an overview of how prosecution services are organised in Member States. The EU Justice Scoreboard feeds into the European Semester country analysis in this respect.  With regard to judicial independence, we are assessing the effectiveness of the national legal frameworks and safeguards in close cooperation with the judicial networks. We have developed a measurement of perceived judicial independence among companies and the general public. We also fully share Parliament’s prioritisation of the use of ICT tools, which is reflected in the 2018 Scoreboard, for example the use of electronic means in judicial procedures and access to judgments online. These are indicators on how the needs of specific groups of users of justice systems – for example, children, visually impaired people, non—native speakers – are being taken into account in the provision of public information on the justice system, in the training of judges and in surveys of court users. As regards judicial training, the Commission is currently evaluating the 2018 strategy, including public consultations. Having said all this, it is important to recall that one of the key challenges for the development of information tools like the EU Justice Scoreboard is the collection of data. We would like to thank Parliament for having called on Member States to cooperate with the Commission. When considering any new area of coverage, it is important to keep in mind the objective of the Scoreboard and the ability to collect reliable data from all Member States, based on a simple and clear indicator in line with European standards. Your resolution comes at a time when upholding the rule of law is high on the EU agenda. I am convinced that with your support the EU Justice Scoreboard will continue to evolve in order to further help the Member States improve the independence, quality and efficiency of their justice systems, which is crucial for upholding the rule of law.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, there are 50 million citizens in the European Union who belong to a national or linguistic minority, yet there is no single legislation in their defence. Thus, indigenous national and linguistic minorities are most vulnerable to the Member States responsible for ensuring their rights. The Minority SafePack citizens' initiative started from the need to create a framework for minority protection at EU level, emphasised by more than one million signatures. I hope that the European Commission will draw up a proposal as soon as possible for the survival of national minorities and their languages. A unified framework for the protection of minorities is also needed for the associated countries of the EU, as assimilation and the continued narrowing of the rights already acquired are a major threat here. Ukraine became an associated country to the EU as of 1 September 2017. Unfortunately, it was right after that that the legal restrictions against minorities increased, the most serious of which is the language article of the Education Act, which abolishes native language education in the secondary schools of minorities. It is unacceptable that, for more than six months, despite the proposals of the Venice Commission and international resolutions, no amendments have been made to this article. Honourable Members, Commissioners, We, responsible European politicians, must act to protect minority communities both in the member and associated countries of the European Union.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, war crimes and crimes against humanity in recent years have come to the fore thanks to the terrible crimes of jihadists and other terrorist organisations operating outside the territory of the European Union. We in the European Union believe that the rule of law applies in all Member States at least in relation to such heinous crimes. However, the other day in the northern occupied part of Cyprus, a Turkish Cypriot, named Turkut Genagrali, boasting that he was accompanying the Turkish army during the 1974 invasion, as an officer, and he was cold-blooded murdering defenseless Greek Cypriots, who were often tied behind the back. Another Turkish Cypriot, Sener Levent, who defends the principles of the European Union against Erdogan, lives in the same place, controlled by the Turkish army. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we must do something to prevent the deletion of crimes and to proceed also to examine the crime of settlement in the northern occupied part of Cyprus.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the European Parliament's recognition of the genocide of the Pontus Greeks by Turkey is now a historic necessity. All the more so, as 2019 marks 100 years since the genocide of the Greeks of Pontus. In 1919, after the decision of Kemal Ataturk in Samsun, Pontus, the Young Turks proceeded to mass massacres and murders of thousands of Greeks of Pontus. Men, women and children were the victims of the genocide of the Greeks of Pontus, which exceeded 350 000. Executions, rape and forced labour in the labour battalions have wiped out our 350 000 compatriots of the Pontus. This is genocide because the Greeks of Pontus were exterminated from Turkey because they were Greeks and Christians. On 21 May - a few days ago - in the European Parliament in Brussels, I organised, as a member of the ECR Group, an event on the need for the European Parliament to recognise the genocide of the Greeks of Pontus. In other words, the European Parliament should finally do its historic debt by completing, in 2019, the 100th anniversary of the genocide of the Greeks of Pontus.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, three days before the entry into force of the GDPR Mark Zuckerberg testified before the European Parliament. He stated that in three days’ time Facebook will be fully compliant with the new regulation, but as was rightfully said, how do we know that you are telling us a truth? Is Facebook being honest with us? The question answered itself on Friday. Hours after the GDPR entered into force, a lawsuit has been filed against Facebook and two of its companies, WhatsApp and Instagram, in three countries for breaching the GDPR. It is alleged that these companies never gave the users the real choice regarding the use of their data. If you don't agree you simply cannot use your Facebook account anymore. This is unacceptable. Apologies and handshakes are not sufficient anymore to get Facebook off the hook. I welcome the lawsuits filed by digital rights activists and encourage action on a European level. It is great to see Europeans defending their own rights, but we are the ones who should be protecting them.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it was only this year that the people of the west of Ireland learned that, back in 2011, the then Minister for Transport, now Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, intervened to prevent EU funding to the western and border regions of Ireland, including funding for the vital western rail corridor. That this outrageous action hardly surprised anyone living in those parts of Ireland is itself telling. The truth is that a privatisation and centralisation agenda on the part of successive Irish governments has led to huge regional imbalances, massive disparities in economic growth and job creation, and an inexistent public transport system across many parts of my constituency. The questions that the European institutions now need to ask themselves are these: do they want to be complicit in denying citizens to access to public transport, and are they going to allow Irish governments to continue to treat the trans-European transport network (TEN-T) objectives with contempt? There is massive demand for rail transport across parts of Ireland that have been ignored by Irish governments. But will the Commission now step up on their behalf or will they ignore them also?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I want to draw attention to the situation in Syria in my speech. This war significantly affects the political situation in the countries of the European Union, and citizens should know the truth about this war. The war was unleashed by Bashar Assad to quell resistance from the democratic opposition. The Assad lineage and the Ba'ath Party have ruled in Syria since 1963, or fifty-five years. It was President Assad who released imprisoned Sunni radicals in 2011, enabling the emergence of Islamic State. Assad profiles himself as a fighter against Islamic State, but he has only used the entire situation to liquidate those who have demanded freedom and respect for human rights in Syria. Seven years on from the outbreak of protests, the situation is alarming. Of the original twenty-two million inhabitants, six and a half million are refugees across the border and seven million internally displaced. Ladies and gentlemen, Bashar Assad and Putin are the ones responsible for five hundred thousand dead and millions more wounded, and they should stand before the tribunal.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, rail passengers in the East Midlands deserve better – better than the cancelled electrification of the Midland Main Line from Kettering to Leicester, Nottingham and Sheffield; better than the East Midlands Trains St Pancras ticket barrier shambles; better than fare increases for late, overcrowded trains; and better than bailouts to companies like Stagecoach and Virgin. When companies fail on one rail franchise, they should be banned from competing for others. Passengers want fares that are fair, trains that run on time and the promised investment in the network, like full electrification of the Midland Main Line. This is why we need stronger rail passenger rights in the European Union and in the UK. Instead of cancelled trains, it’s time to cancel the failed privatisation of our railways. It’s time to publish a new timetable, a new timetable for renationalising our railways – as a Labour government would – to give passengers the services they deserve.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr President! Since the institutions of the European Union are actively interested in adhering to the rule of law, I want to draw attention to the campaign of hatred, particularly against Catholics in Poland, which consists of defamation, based on the slander of left-liberal-feminist backgrounds spreading untrue information to lead to elimination. Attacks of hatred and blasphemy have long been directed at the founder of Radio Maryja and Television Trwam and many other works serving Poland and my nation. I raise this point in the European Parliament because hate campaigns have been carried out inadmissibly, admittedly by the Polish-speaking media, but with completely non-Polish capital allowing anti-Polish rhetoric for a long time. As you know from the history of France or the struggle against faith in Soviet Russia, this often ended up being an apparatus of violence, which, fighting religion, takes a toll in the form of up to millions of victims of crime and persecution. Not only media attacks of a potentially criminal nature unjustifiably discriminate against both the priest and the entire environment of believing compatriots, they combat independent media without incurring any consequences for doing so.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, on 3 May the Council of Europe identified Spain as one of the countries that have not fully implemented a single recommendation relating to the fight against corruption. On the other hand, recent Council of Europe recommendations to Spain mention the negative burden that corruption has on economic recovery in our country. The ruling on the Gürtel case directly points to the People's Party as directly and collectively responsible for a plot of corruption that embarrasses our country and also limits our economic options. Corruption does undeniable damage to the economy, but also to democracy: looting the coffers of the state is not to love Spain. But this problem is also a problem for Europe, a problem that splashes and calls into question the democratic quality of the European institutions and their commitment to transparency. It is time to act consistently and, above all, forcefully against corruption.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Romania will assume the presidency of the Council of the European Union in the first part of next year. It's gonna be a first. But its preparation is in great danger. The fault belongs to the government led by Viorica Dăncilă, primarily because many ministers are incompetent. Even worse is the fact that the Prime Minister abandoned his prerogatives. The government's power was usurped by a criminally convicted person - Liviu Dragnea. He runs the PSD and, in a non-transparent way, dictates government action. The drift of the rule of law is worse in Romania than in Hungary or Poland. The majority of the PSD - ALDE is not ready to assume the presidency of the Council of the European Union. I remind you that negotiations for the MFF will have to be completed in the first 6 months of 2019 and the UK's exit from the European Union will be managed. There are political resources to overcome the crisis in Bucharest, but I believe that only early elections can give a legitimate and competent power, as in Italy Mr. President.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I was recently with the trade union Usdaw outside a Lidl distribution centre – outside, because the management won’t let UK unions in. ‘There’s an unreasonable workload to achieve productivity targets’; ‘Lidl have a culture of health and safety that is only important after something goes wrong’. These are direct quotes from worried workers.  This isn’t new and there is a similar story to tell across Europe. Back in 2004, Verdi published its ‘Black Book on Lidl’, exposing a low—pay, high—fear culture. Lidl cannot be allowed to continue to expand at the expense of its workers. They need a voice, through an independent trade union. So my message to Lidl is: end your opposition to unions and meet with Usdaw. Talk about recognising it as the trade union for Lidl staff. Until you do that, we will keep campaigning outside your warehouses and stores. It is time for a ‘Lidl’ more understanding.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: — Mr President, on Wednesday we will discuss the impact of the relocation of production in relation to the Embraco case when production has been transferred from Italy to Slovakia, for which we have earned international criticism. In such cases, it is important to encourage corporate social responsibility and to promote the development of industry in the European Union. I agree with that. But as companies come to Slovakia, they leave it and leave the trigger behind. Example: At Bodet&Horst in Vrbovo, a large proportion of over three hundred employees had to submit mass statements because they were going to bankruptcy. For over thirteen years she's been producing in our house. She received up to five and a half million subsidies from the budget of the Slovak Republic for development. Meanwhile, it has also launched production in Romania. In April, it announced that it was quitting in Slovakia and moving to Germany and Romania. This must be accepted within the free market of the European Union. But it is inconceivable that he is leaving Slovakia with unpaid wages and claims. Only the social and health insurance company owes over six hundred thousand. Of course, mismanagement can also be behind its collapse, but it cannot be agreed that companies will leave debts behind, leave and we support them in business in another country. I therefore ask the Commission to establish a legislative instrument to prevent the transfer of firms between the countries of the European Union, unless all claims in the original country of operation have been resolved.

name: Marie-Pierre Vieu (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, this Tuesday, 29 May, before Parliament, there will be a European demonstration of road workers, who ask us about their situation, even though on 4 June next, in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, votes on the mobility package will begin. What do employees ask for? In a sector ravaged by competition and overly precarious, which is experiencing extreme working conditions, drivers claim dignity denied them today, recognition of their rights and occupational safety. Faced with this urgency, you answer them with an extension of working time, a framework for rest time that too often leads them to no longer leave their cabin, a lex specialis for posted road workers, which will deprive them of the progress made in the general posting directive. Therefore, in the end, more precariousness and more social dumping. To paraphrase the poet Aragon, “is this how men live” or should they live? For my part, I will take my responsibilities in voting, as on the street, and I call for solidarity with road employees.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, dear European colleagues, lift Romania's cooperation and verification mechanism. For more than 10 years, Romania has been monitored by MCV. Romanian citizens are wondering, and rightly so, whether this mechanism of cooperation and verification has not been used, in all these years, against public persons, as a pretext. At the same time, Romania fulfilled the recommendations that the last MCV report, the one in November 2017, made to our country. Moreover, Romania is the country that will take over the presidency of the Council of the European Union from 1 January 2019, and the non-establishment of the mechanism by this date will weaker the negotiating power of the European Union within Brexit. Romania has suffered quite and unfairly, as an image, because of this mechanism, which must now be urgently lifted because absolutely all the technical conditions of the lifting have already been met. Countries like the Netherlands, France and Finland use MCV against my country as an argument for Romania's non-accession to Schengen.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: — We are discussing today the infamous Mobility project. Scandalous because it's the brightest manifestation of a double standard this room has ever seen. President Macron's proposals are anti-European and eurosceptic. They are because they aim one thing only — to ruin the entrepreneurs from the East and attract their workers as black workers to their companies. This project proposes not market practices, but administrative practices, infringements of the free market, infringement of freedom of movement, distortion of competition, and this is all hypocrisy and a double standard. There can be no European Union in which there will be firms that will work in the eastern markets, and eastern firms will not work in Western markets. This is wrong, unfair, and again I say, anti-European. These proposals themselves show a clear trend for dividing Europe into “two speeds”, which is detrimental to the eastern countries and would turn carriers from Eastern Europe, including from Bulgaria, Romania, etc. into guest workers. This is unacceptable and unacceptable. Honourable Members, you need to understand yourself and vote against this.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the conflict in the north Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir goes back 70 years. The departing British left Kashmir’s destiny in the gift of a king, rather than in the hands of its people, and wars between India and Pakistan followed. A settlement now in Kashmir is essential to peace and to progress in a complex region. There have been times of hope, there have been signs of progress, but in recent years and months the situation has deteriorated. The infringement of human rights by the Indian military has been widespread and systematic. Several generations of Kashmiris now have no civil experience other than conflict with the Indian state, but the iron fist has failed, and it has cost India dear. In elections in Kashmir virtually no one votes, so in developing relations with India, the European Union cannot ignore human rights abuses, and the world cannot afford to ignore this flashpoint between nuclear-armed powers.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: — Mr President, dear colleagues, our project to organise a united Europe seems to be thinning, losing its consistency, and the cause is simple: the European citizen, regardless of the Member State to which he belongs, no longer feels that Brussels is working for him. One of the ways in which the European citizen should be brought alongside European values is that of European health policy. Therefore, if we want a credible European Union with the confidence and support of the citizen behind us, I think it is necessary to start a structural reform of the health system. We should, despite the national differences in approach to this area, lay the foundations for the construction of a single sanitary system, which has the focus of man, with his problems, not just the profit and profitability of businesses in this system. In this context, I ask the decision-makers in the European Commission to come up with an initiative in this respect, which can become a reality by the end of the next parliamentary term.
